description:
Home is where the heart is, and Chong Zing Xiao Mian has my heart. These noodles and soups are the ultimate comfort food, and I look forward to many more experiences here! They do have a kick of spice, but it adds an extra punch of flavor to the food. I will admit it is greasy like others mention. I don't mind this, however. I like to think it adds to the flavor of the broth. 

I've only had the Tan Tan Noodles and was impressed! I do want to try the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup and many other items. During lunch, get cozy with those around you. If it's busy and the tables are taken, you'll be sat in the long row of connected tables where you could be eating next to strangers. I thought it was unique as this is only something I'd seen in China. I'm glad they aren't afraid to keep their ways in America.

The service is quick and to the point. Don't expect the server to come to you. You have to wave them down.

Groups larger than four may be a mistake if it is too crowded. The smaller the better in my opinion! It's location is in the less touristy part of Chinatown, and the prices are reflective with most items ranging around $10-$11. You'll also get a view into the kitchen with the staff rushing around and yelling orders. I cannot wait for my next stop here and sharing it with the world!
author: Brandon S.

description:
Doesn't get any better than this --- BOMB Sichuan cuisine, good portions, fast service, and the prices are right. I've gone to MANY Sichuan restaurants throughout California, and this is one that's definitely got it on point. I haven't written a review for a while, but after eating at this place, I just had to. The people who work here definitely hustle, we got our food about 10-15 mins after our order was taken. 

Beef w/ Spicy Five Flavor: only $4.95!!
- Good serving size for the price (enough for 2). Served cold, but still delicious. 
- Very good spice flavor -- not spicy though, but you can add the red chili oil that they have on the table.

Tan Tan Noodle: $9.95
- Pork, cabbage, noodles in chili oil. 
- Perfect balance of spicy-ness and umami, not too spicy but the chili flakes will get to your throat if you eat it too fast. 

Won-Ton with Spicy Chili Oil & Chicken Broth: $9.95
- Big bowl of pork won-tons, cabbage in chili oil and chicken broth. 
- AMAZING combination. Won-tons made fresh (you can tell that they made them to order, not frozen). Perfect texture when taking a bite with a little bit of broth. 
- Loved the broth so much, added the beef in and ate after eating the won-tons. 

This place is truly a gem, I can't wait to go back.
author: Cindy M.

description:
I love spicy Sichuan food and when I found this place, I was really excited especially after I saw how many Asians dined here on a regularly basis. My favorite dish is their pickled vegetable with beef noodle soup. It is a giant bowl and I was never able to finish the noodles, the broth and the beef. I also tried the hot and sour glass noodles, which is very unique and tasty. Both noodle soups are quite authentic and flavorful. During lunch and dinner time, they are quite busy so expect to wait a bit. 

One thing that I hope they would improve is the greasiness. The soup is super tasty with all the spices and chili oil but it feels like a big oil pool. Unfortunately, I don't drive much of the soup due to the greasiness. Otherwise, I am in love with their food!
author: Athena C.

description:
Great hole in the wall to visit. Cramped, but relatively clean inside. Food is pretty cheap and decent size.

The chili oil here is really fragrant here, which makes every dish it's put in really stand out. The fu qi fei pian was like 70% tripe and 30% beef, which isn't a bad thing since I just wanted to eat everything that had touched the chili oil. 

The pork belly slices were smaller than I thought they'd be in the pork belly and mustard dish. However, the flavor is solid and the meat/fat melt in your mouth once you start eating it so no complaints here.

The dan dan noodle enormous. The broth had a really strong garlic flavor to it, but that was all there was to it. Didn't get that much spiciness from it.  I think next time, I would go for one of the drier noodles.
author: Steven Z.

description:
Wow. This place is amazing! I had the pickled mustard green noodle soup, absolutely bursting with flavor. The meat was perfectly tender as were the noodles, and the broth is something you want to just chug down, even though that's probably a bad idea since it's spicy. Great place to go for an authentic experience. There could be a wait as it's a very small place, but my group just happened to get a table in two minutes on a busy day.

So with the amazing authenticity, quality, cool location in Chinatown, and extreme flavors, it earns itself what I was expecting to give it from the beginning; 5 out of 5 stars.
author: Dakota C.

description:
Quite authentic, and great value for money. 

I came here for a quick weekday lunch w/ my coworkers. There was a bit of a wait (around 20 mins) but the turnover is pretty fast, and the whole middle section is one large table that you can sit at. Service was pretty chill, I speak chinese so the ladies were all quite nice to me. 

The noodles were pretty good! I came with one of my Chinese friends, and she said they were quite authentic. We got the Tan Tan Noodles and the Shingle Noodles, both were wonderful. Not too spicy but plenty of flavor, and delicious ground pork. A little on the salty side, but I wasn't surprised. Noodles were a little overcooked and a little too soft, but that might also be personal preference. We also got the Lamb Skewers and the Sweet and Sour ribs. Both were well favored and quite authentic. They were both on the fattier side, so be warned this isn't going to be the healthiest place to eat. 

Overall, it was A LOT of food for a very decent price ($10/ bowl of noodles). I'd def come back for another very filling lunch
author: Sophie W.

description:
Ever since I was little the only restaurants that I would visit in SF Chinatown would be either 1) dim sum or 2) one of the restaurants that had bbq duck/pork hanging in the window. Now I can add this hole in the wall as a third. 

I grew up eating Schezuan food so the numbing spicy sauce has never bothered me and it's rare for me to eat it when I'm not with my parents. This past weekend, I was in the city doing a photoshoot and one of my friends highly recommended this place. The store itself is tiny but there was a semi-long wait for the dinner rush. Timing wise, we beat the majority of the line and ended up picking a few things from the menu as we waited. 

Tan tan noodles - Solid bowl of noodles, highly recommended as a main dish since everything else is small
Pork Belly w/ mustard greens - OK, these were a lot smaller than expected and the majority of pieces were super fatty
Lamb Skewers - MUST GET, probably the best thing we ordered, the spices and everything were perfect (beware if you can't handle the heat)
Green onion pancake - Highly recommended, super crispy and well flavored

FYI, the pictures make it look bigger than it really is. In reality the dishes are pretty tiny, hence the affordable prices
author: Wiseley F.

description:
I love noodles. I love spice. So spicy noodles just make sense to me. I went to Chong Qing Xiao Mian with a girlfriend to indulge in two of my favourite things. Usually during lunch time, the place is pretty packed but we got lucky and got the last seat before the rush. 

Service is not great, typical Chinese restaurant where you have to call the waitress a couple of times before she takes your order, brings you extra napkins, refills your water etc. 

We ordered two types of noodles and the lamb skewers but unfortunately the noodles dishes weren't as spicy as I would have liked and the lamb was mostly fat. I was hoping for some burn your mouth, numbing spice but it was probably about a 4 on a scale of 10. That being said, portions are huge and prices are reasonable.
author: Eunah T.

description:
I'm a fan of this hidden lunch spot. Cheap good noodles. 
The Onion Pancakes you can skip because they are so paper thin that you can get something much better at a dim sum place near by. 
Per usual, the bowls are large so a Medium bowl ($7-10) is good for almost 2 people. The Large bowl ($10-13) is good for 3 average people. 
I would go to this place for the best bang for your buck!
author: Miguel E.

description:
I've been here a few times and it's decent. Most recently, I ordered the spicy beef noodle soup and it was very spicy but still flavorful. I'm not giving more than three stars though because the broth was EXTREMELY oily. I've had other noodle soups here before like the hot and sour and they have all been oily. Since the food is so heavy and oily, I wouldn't recommend this place all the time, but once in a while it's nice if you're looking for decent Chinese food with intense flavors. 

The food here is pretty cheap too which is a nice plus. It's clean and there usually isn't a long wait (5-15 min) on weeknights.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Diners be aware.  While their health score is 85, not sure how they got away with serving food in dirty bowls. I only discovered this after dining in as I almost finished my dish and then notice the inside of the bowls are kind of brown.  I thought perhaps it's just an old bowl and it's permanently stained.  Sadly, no!  I scratched against the brown part with my finger nail and it came off.  Yuck yuck gross. 

When I told them about it, they said they always wash dishes with the dish washer. That explains it.  No one is actually checking if the bowl is actually clean or not.  In this case this bowl need to be watched with a scratchy scrubber and the dirt that was touching the food I ate would come right off 

Gross. ;-(
author: Lei H.

description:
Okay guys, I don't know how this place has so many good reviews but it's either fake or people don't know how Chong Qing / Sichuan noodles are supposed to taste. This place is not authentic so if that's what you're looking for don't come here. 

他们的面都没有味道。We ordered 3 soups and the spicy chicken (口水鸡）， all bland. 

The workers speak Cantonese so maybe it's Cantonese owned. My biggest problem with this place is the menu, I don't know if they purchased the same stock photos as the store up the street but they have the EXACT MENU. 

I have attached photos of the restaurant menu down the street from them. Tell me if you guys can tell the difference. 

Also don't expect good service. I'm not going to comment about the cleanliness, it's Chinatown.
author: Lynn K.

description:
When my friend said to meet here for food, i legit got a little sad. The old Vietnamese place really hit the spot after some happy hour drinks! Plus, with Z&Y up the street...i was skeptical.

Shouldn't have been. I had the beef noodles with pickled veg, and it hit the spot really well. The noodles were really nicely done, the beef melted in my mouth, and the sour from the veg gave the spice from the soup a different dynamic.

We also had green onion pancake, which is always good. This one was flatter and denser than I'd like, but it was solid.

 The food is much more street food style, which helps differentiate it.
author: Lily W.

description:
I'm still crying how delicious my Braised Short Rib Noodle dish was and it was probably one of my fave highlights from my recent San Francisco trip. Visiting China Town is a must for anyone visiting SF; however, I am now going to be an advocate for Chong Qing Xiao Mian because not only do you get your bang for your buck (is that how the saying goes?); however, your taste buds will be crying tears of joy.

Now there are a ton of options around this area, but we were in much need of a soup or noodle dish to soothe our throats as they were a little rough from all the drinks/shots last night. Plus noodle dishes are perfect for illness and hangovers...

The broth from my dish had such a punch I should've fallen out of my chair with every sip I had. The noodles were cooked perfectly and the dish honestly could've served two people. What really had me in awe was how the meat fell off the bone so quickly. My friend let me dig into her Spicy Mustard Noodle dish and that is another great option.

Keep in mind this isn't an open-seat restaurant as you'll need to sign in at the very front.
author: Tomas R.

description:
A bowl of noodles here is one of the cheapest good meals you can find downtown. Last night I tried the Tan Tan noodles ($9.95) and I came back today around 1pm for the Pork Bone Broth noodles ($7.95). Since noodles are a pretty quick meal, I was seated within five minutes both times. 

The Tan Tan noodle broth - spicy, rich, and slick with oil and ground pork - is great if you're craving flavor. It was a little too oily/salty for me, but the cabbage in the broth helped strike the right balance. 

The Pork Bone Broth noodles were more up my alley. The broth delivers a slight spice, but it's clear for the most part and not as overwhelmingly oily as the Tan Tan noodles. The boiled turnip and peanuts were a great touch too. 

Expect a generous portion of elastic noodles no matter what you order. I'll be back to try the rest of the menu!
author: Laura C.

description:
This is the first place I ate at when I moved to SF. My friend told me it was "okay" but I'm not sure what he was talking about - this place is great.

Be warned, if you don't like spicy food this place probably isn't for you. They do have a pork bone broth noodle that's pretty good and not spicy though, so don't worry if your masochist friends drag you here.

For me, I live for the pain, so the first time I got the dan dan noodles. The noodles had a nice chewy texture to them, and the broth and ground pork made me sweat a little. Good stuff.

I tried the pork bone broth the next time, along with scallion pancakes and liangpi (cold skin - it's made of rice flour not human calm down). Both side dishes were pretty good, but the scallion pancakes won out in this round. Nice and flaky and crispy... everything I could want in a scallion pancake. 

The pork bone broth noodles were great too, with a nice variety of pickled vegetables in the soup, with the same great chewy noodles. I had to add chili oil to it though because I'm no wuss.

If you're looking for a solid noodle joint in Chinatown, come here. Don't expect stellar service unless you speak either Cantonese or Mandarin, and expect to wait during meal times, but food is good enough that it makes me crave it randomly during the week when I'm having a mediocre catered lunch at the office.
author: Calvin Z.

description:
This restaurant is a little hole whole in the wall but don't let appearances deceive you! I was visiting SF for the weekend and because I'm not used to the cold weather... for basically my whole trip, I wanted hot soup and I found this place on Yelp. 

The place is a bit cramped so I wouldn't recommend a large party for this place, unless you don't mind sitting separately or waiting for the long table in the middle. I ordered the braised spareribs noodle soup while my friends ordered the tan tan noodles, lamb skewers, and sichuan style pork belly.

My noodles were BOMB. The broth was delicious and not too salty. The number of spare ribs they gave me was a lot! The ONLY thing I do have to complain about was the ribs were a bit dry. Other than that it was good! I think the best dish hands down was the sichuan style pork belly! The pork belly they used wasn't super fatty but actually had meat on there! My friends devoured the tan tan noodles and lamb skewers. Be warned though apparently the lamb skewers are a bit spicy!
author: Diana L.

description:
Delicious, unpretentious Chinese food. The kind of Chinese food that Chinese humans living abroad would see as rare and to be cherished in the Bay Area.

It's not quite right to say that this is just as spicy as what you'd find in Chongqing (haha, it's not even close), but it is well-tempered for my liking!

For side dishes, I'd recommend the cucumbers (拍黄瓜) and spare ribs (糖醋小排骨). (Those were the two that we got and both were solid! Oh, and sorry, I cannot remember the exact way that they decided to translate these dishes.)

We got the 重庆小面 and the 小锅米线. Both were solid, too. I'd recommend maybe getting the first one if it's your first time, because it's the dish that gives the restaurant its name, but really it's just a very barebones but solid spicy noodles. It's like a subset of every other noodle dish.

They also don't hold back at all on their portion sizes. So in general, it's very tasty and authentic, but lacks polish.
author: Albert Z.

description:
Cleanliness: 3
Food: 3
Quality: 2
Service: 3

A friend of mine told me that this place had the best Dan Dan noodles; I love Dan Dan noodles so I knew I had to try this place out! 

I ordered the Dan Dan noodles (2/5), the sweet and sour ribs (3/5) and the tea egg (4/5). At first, I was eating the Dan Dan noodles without drinking the broth along with it; then I saw other patrons in the restaurant eating the noodles with the broth so I decided to follow. While this way had a little more flavor, I just found the noodles so underwhelming. It was bland, under seasoned, and just watery. I felt like a wuss added the spices. The noodles were a little over cooked and not chewy. The ribs were very fake tasting; the sauce coating the ribs literally tasted like it came from a can. The tea eggs were good; not as much flavor as I hoped for. 

Overall, I really wanted to like this place but the food was just mediocre
author: Xuan L.

description: Awesome noodle spot.  Super fair prices.  You won't be disappointed.   Had it once on Friday night then had to order it again Sunday for dinner.   Incredible broths and portions.
author: Justin S.

description:
This place is CHEAP! 

I've been here 3 times, and every time I'm blown away at the portion to price ratio. Giant bowls of noodles are less than $10. However, the food will make you feel super fat afterwards because the dishes felt very oily. 

Service is fast though and there was no wait on a Saturday afternoon. In an out.
author: Thu P.

description: What a great spot.  Dan Dan noodles are very popular and amazing.  Consider the wontons as well -- the dumplings are awesome but it's the broth that (unexpectedly) knocked our socks off.
author: Meghan F.

description:
A step up from a hole in the wall joint on the edge of Chinatown, Chong Qing Xiao Mian has become a personal favorite for a good bowl of noodle soup. The flavors are well balanced and the noodles nicely textured. Many of the noodles combos here you wouldn't necessarily find elsewhere, which is a nice change. There are plenty of ramen and udon places in SF but I have yet to find a good Chinese noodle shop. The service is fast but you should be open to sitting with a stranger as there isn't much space. I've been lucky and have rarely had to wait for a table.

The broths are definitely on the oily side and not very drinkable (in my mind but my bf thought it was amazing). Many of the noodles have chili oil in them and lots of seasoning, which makes the noodles great and balanced but the soup is a bit too much. There are a few noodles with clear broths like the Guiling noodles so just be aware of what you're getting. I personally like the Chong Qing noodles and the mustard greens beef noodles. I'd skip the Tan Tan (or Dandan) noodles though as I'm accustomed to them being more of a dry noodle dish but they serve them here as a sort of soup noodle. 

If you don't just want noodles (but that's why you're here!) you can also order some side dishes. I've only ordered the sweet and sour ribs and while the first few were pretty good, it was too much to share between two people and much too similar to sweet and sour chicken from Panda Express or some other Americanized Chinese restaurant. 

But certainly stop by as the noodles are not to be missed! If you find comfort in a big bowl of savory broth, this is for you.
author: Liza X.

description:
Great little restaurant, where there's always going to be some lively action happening in the kitchen... Sometimes yelling... Sometimes laughing.

Been here several times now, and the food is always consistently good. The spicy food is, well, not spicy enough for my taste... But they have enough chilies on the table so that you can doctorate to your liking if need be. Obviously, not everybody likes super spicy food.

Have been there several times, intend on going back many more.
author: Rick S.

description:
This place is authentic.  We came here after a conference to get real Chinese food and they did not disappoint.  
The menu is somewhat limited but all we had was good or great.  We ordered pot stickers (great) and sweet and sour ribs (good).  
One of us got duck noodles and the other two got tan tan noodles.  Both were spicy enough to bring a sweat to our brow.  Lots of flavor.  The duck meat had a lot of inedible parts (good not great).  Tan tan had small pieces of pork that were good.  
For a good authentic Szechuan Chinese meal this is worth a visit.
author: Alex D.

description:
A great spicy noodle soup? Say no more!

Doused in Chili oil and complimented by a generous heap of pickled mustard green, the noodles here might be one of the best noodle dishes I've had so far (dare I say better than the ones in NY...?).

I personally tried 'the Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup' ($9.95). The broth was rich and fragrant, and the noodles were fresh and bouncy. I was impressed at how balanced the dish was both in flavor and in portion. Nothing was overly salty or bitingly spicy despite the amount of chili oil that was added into the broth. The soup was both tangy and beefy, and the pickled mustard green cut through any excessive fattiness that might have otherwise been overwhelming.

If you are looking for some insanely delicious noodle soups, I suggest you make your way down to Chinatown for this great bowl of noodle soup. I definitely know I am heading back soon.
author: Ji-Sub J.

description:
Chinatown is sea of mediocre Chinese restaurants catered to be just a teeny bit tastier than Panda Express for visiting tourists to be able to go back to their lives and tell friends they had "real Chinese food" without scaring them off with the true flavortown and sometimes subtlety of actual Chinese food. Chong Xiao Mian is a clear choice for anyone that is actually familiar with asian food but being forced to eat in Chinatown by hunger or insistent visiting relatives.

Service is quick and friendly, prices are fair, food is delicious! I love that they have a giant vat of crunchy red chili and oil for you to add as desired.

I would recommend tendons in spicy sauce for appetizer and tan tan noodles. Neither are actually very spicy.
author: Jillian S.

description:
Chong Qing Xiao Mian is located on a busy street in Chinatown. The space was small, with a few tables against the wall and a row of tables, one next to another, going down the center. This made for an awkward dining experience. We could easily hear the conversation at the table next to us, and got complaints for talking to loudly when we really weren't raising our voices at all.

[ Tan Tan Noodle, Mild ] I asked for mildly spicy because these noodles are generally known to be really spicy. Although it was no longer very spicy, it tasted watered down. I really enjoyed the texture of the noodles and the ground pork was delicious. However, the soup was a little too greasy.
author: Annie Z.

description:
We first tried coming here Friday around opening but made the mistake of timing our visit smack in the middle of lunch hour. The restaurant has 8-10 tables on each side with a communal long table down the center. The entrance was packed with people waiting for a seat. A clipboard sat by the door that had names and party size though it didn't seem like any of the servers were looking at it. Since we were unsure how long the wait would be, we decided to try again Saturday before leaving SF and dipped out.

I absolutely would've regretted not coming here. While a more traditional dandan mian comes with much less soup, CQXM's dandan were so delicious and really hit the spot. It was the perfect hot (not blazing), soothing meal before a long road trip and there's definitely a lot of flavor, the little bits of pork you get in every bite was perfect and not at all overwhelming. Don't drink the soup, it's covered in oil for flavoring the noodles. The spiciness level isn't hot at all and my tolerance for spiciness is pretty mediocre. I actually added a giant spoon of their chili oil and it was still just okay.

My husband had their pork rib soup and rice. It comes with back bones therefore not a ton of meat. The flavor of the broth was rich and tasted exactly like many soups I had in China as a kid. I could've drank it all. They add a lot of napa cabbage to the bottom of the soup so if you aren't a fan, this probably isn't the dish for you.

We also had the lamb skewers (can't pass on trying this since Xi'an is my hometown), scallion pancake, and the sweet and sour short ribs. The skewers weren't my favorite; they could've been great, but I think the cook that morning didn't care too much and seasoned one side of the meat, leaving the other 3 sides pretty plain and gross. It's sloppy cooking. The parts where the cumin & other spices came through were tasty. 

Husband really enjoyed the sweet and sour ribs because they were basically char siu ribs repurposed with some vinegar, and he loves char siu anything. The scallion pancake was cooked unevenly though the parts that were neither overdone or underdone were crispy yet chewy, everything you'd want in your scallion pancakes. It was too oily to eat a lot of after the dandan noodles.

Service was nice for a Chinese restaurant, the ladies were very polite and made sure we had everything. It was a ton of food for around $50 which is not bad at all for the portion sizes. If we lived closer, I'd definitely make it a habit to come here!
author: Belinda J.

description:
I trekked all the way up Powell from the Cable Car turnaround.. on foot (cable car line ridiculous), to eat at Chong Qing Xiao Mian. It did not disappoint. They have a clipboard where you can put your name down but no one was using it and as a solo diner I was seated quickly at the communal table. The staff is very efficient here, but don't expect them to be warm and fuzzy. I'd say about 75% of the customers I overheard ordered their food in Chinese but I had no problem ordering in English. 

I decided on the Chongqing xiao Mian and an herbal tea, though the iced soy milk was a popular choice around me, I assume to cool off the spice. The herbal tea cane in a can and was sweetened and I probably should have just ordered water. The chongqing xiao Mian was huge and hot, the noodles chewy and plentiful. Despite the dish not having meat it was full of flavor with the chilis and bok choy. I've only had Sichuan noodles once before and I have to say these were not as spicy or numbing as what I've had previously. Kind of weird when that description is in the name of the dish but I was actually thankful I wasn't embarrassing myself eating something way too hot to handle. The restaurant itself was toasty for a June afternoon so don't plan on spending a lot of time in there. 

Overall a great meal and great experience in Chinatown. I think anyone can enjoy these noodles even if you've never had Sichuan noodles before. Make it a stop on your next trip!
author: Emily B.

description:
They secretly charge you for tips without your consent!!!

I used to order delivery a lot with this restaurant. Until today, I realized that they secretly charge the tips without your consent, and they did NOT tell you that! So this whole time I have been double paying the tips and I had no idea... How sneaky and greedy this restaurant is.
author: Elena H.

description:
I really wanted to love this place too! Maybe there was just a mix up on the day that I got takeout....

I ordered a beef noodle and lamb skewers. My takeout showed up, and I pulled out the dark, glistening bowl of chili oil. I was so ready to light my mouth on fire. Scoop 1: cabbage. Scoop 2: cabbage. Wait a minute, did they forget the beef? Yup, they did. Called them up and got a second delivery. I guess they must've thought they didn't forget it, because I got about 3 pieces of beef for my $13.50 dish. Yikes. To their credit, the beef itself was tender, with nice lines of sinew running through it. That being said, more beef would have been appreciated. The noodles were freshly made and had a great bounce. Taste: 3.75/5. Value: 2/5.

I lived in Beijing for four months and really missed getting lamb skewers on the side of the street, especially after a night of clubbing (so yes, this is like a bajillion years ago). Lamb was tender and chewy, and the value here was adequate. Nothing beats the nostalgia of Beijing lamb skewers though. 3.5/5.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I've been meandering into this spot every few weeks trying to figure it out and wavering on the edge of offering some thoughts, then on the further edge of a decision between four and five stars. After today, five it is.

Pro tip on what's going on here is to start with this:
http://spicykingsf.com/
The mothership is a spot called Spicy King and something else entirely if you read the hanzi name but suffice to say they started out a few years ago with that more banquet-y locale with the longer menu up the hill on Waverly and have been quietly carving out a minor Sichuanese empire throughout the Bay ever since.

Our present subject opened a few years later slinging noodle bowls priced to go pitched to a ravenous inter-FiDi/Chinatown lunch crowd. More pale faces in attendance now than a few months ago but still a distinct minority, and you'll do better on service with a few confirmatory side comments in Mandarin, or you can communicate that way exclusively and probably get through the process faster.

On earlier visits they seemed to present everything in a standard full-fire chili oil bath that overpowered everything else. More recently they've opted for a thinner but still flavorful broth with a bucket of hua jiao loaded oil on the side; spoon in to taste; and it works out better for everyone. I'll always take a few spoonfuls in my noodles and that does the trick for me; you'll always have that option unless you start with the eponymous Chong Qing Xiao Mian dish, in which case spice is the main event and you asked for it. My happy place is any of the noodle bowls with pickled vegetables. And until today I had put off trying the version with fish, but today I went straight for the Fish with Pickled Vegetables noodle bowl, and well, five stars, and it's going to be hard to explore very much else now that I know that's available.

The front side of the menu deserves attention too. I and a work colleague seem to have settled on a system of one noodle bowl each plus fried squid and steamed vegetables to start. Everything balances perfectly and it's about the right amount for two hungry people. I also haven't encountered the service issues others mention. This is a hole-in-the-wall version of a Chinese noodle stand presented in all its authentic, no-frills, take-it-or-leave-it style; the food is great; a dollar or two more than I'd like but a steal for FiDi; and everyone's always been nice enough to me to carry out the essential noodles-for-dollars business at hand. I say it's a great deal and we should all celebrate.
author: James D.

description:
My friends and I came to this place after we stumbled across it in Yelp. One of my friends was craving chinese noodle soup and this place had great reviews. I just have to say: Delicious!

I got the spicy beef noodle soup, with a request of less spicy. In general, I'm not great with spice, and it was pushing the limits of my spice tolerance. However, it was delicious! I'm not sure how they made the noodles, but I loved them. The soup was also very good (if I swiped away some of the hot chili oil on top). Would highly recommend this dish to anyone who loves spicy noodles, and might get it again if I come back, though probably with a request of even less spicy.

The store itself was a bit small, so we were crammed next to strangers. Didn't detract from the yummy food though!
author: Elaine Z.

description: Lots of excellent dishes here and service is top notch. Had the beef noodle soup, pork belly, dumplings, spring rolls and cucumber. All very tasty. If I lived nearby I would definitely love to try all the other dishes on their menu.
author: George W.

description:
The description "Amazing Food" doesn't even cut it. 

The Tan Tan Noodle Soup was out of this world. 

If you get a chance, give it a shot. You won't regret it!
author: Olli N.

description:
For me, noodles break or make a dish--springy and bouncy are key components in the perfect nood, and Chong Qing Xiao Mian definitely delivered. The broth could be more flavorful, but the noodles more than made up for it. Don't get me started on those floating bits of meat and veggies--they just complement the noods so well. Overall, the dish was very hearty and tasty and I can't wait to start slurping up those noods again.
I wouldn't recommend the jalapeños, however. It was too spicy!
author: Charissa S.

description: This spot is great for lunch or dinner. I just ordered the spicy noodles, with no meat, and the onion pancake. Wish they had chicken although. The noddles were good. Spicy, but bearable. The onion cake was nice and crispy- very good. My food was hot & delicious. Great for a cold, or rainy day too!
author: Kim H.

description:
Wonderfully flavored, great affordable prices. Little place tucked in Chinatown. Nice variety of hot pots and soups. The lamb shanks were buttery and melt in your mouth. The sweet and sour soup needed some seasoning but was delicious with glass noodles. 
Only caveat was the not so clean kitchen I got to found out on the way to the kitchen when I was done eating. Not pleasant but, sadly... all the tasty dishes are usually cooked in these kinds of kitchens. Would still go next time just cause it was one of the best dishes we ate in San Fran trip.
author: Mazal S.

description: I'm no expert in Chinese cuisine, but the hand-pulled noodles here sure are tasty and fun to eat! They're fast and friendly with the service and if you're starving I'd recommend starting with the house spicy cold noodle which comes out almost as fast as you order it. The tea eggs are buy one get one free which is cool if you're into tea eggs and they have many cool appetizers to accompany their noodle dishes. My friend said she thought the food was a tad on the salty and oily side of the spectrum but where would all that flavor come from otherwise?  (drink extra water just in case)
author: Phi P.

description:
This place is crap. It's not often I start a review like this, but I'm tapping into my memory and I'm frustrated thinking about it. First off, it's clear that it's made for tourists and to trap non-Chinese, but that's not my problem with it. I spent 10 minutes trying to flag down one of the waitresses here to ask a simple question. I wasn't trying to be rude or anything, but I saw at least 3 waitresses look directly at me and run away. One walked towards me, got pulled away by someone else, and never came back. I sat there with my hand up in the air trying to pipe up for service to no avail. I nearly went back to my grade school days where I literally shouted to get everyone to shut up because that's how irritated I was. Sure, I understand that you're busy, but there were waitresses deliberately ignoring me even as they walked by.
The food here is alright. I didn't love it much, but it was food. My entire experience was dampened really by my frustrations. I see that many people rave about this place, but I honestly don't think the food was that worth it, nor did my bf who didn't have the same frustrating experience as me. I feel like there are just better Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, even for Sichuan food.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Ordered the pork belly, tan tan noodle, and spicy beef noodle soup. 

I'm pretty familiar with that numbing Szechuan taste and enjoy it quite a bit. This place kind of fell short on that.

Tan tan noodle and spicy beef noodle soup were both okay. I know it's supposed to be oily, but it kind of just tasted like hot oil instead of that numbing Szechuan spice I love. 3/5.

Pork belly was good though. This dish actually did give me that numbing spice taste I enjoy so much.

I definitely recommend getting an order of veggies to cut the oil and spiciness. Prices were decent, but food was just okay!
author: Valerie L.

description:
This place straight up hits the spot. The namesake Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle is simplicity at its best. Really, this dish is just composed of noodles and soup. And cabbage, but that's just cabbage. But they really execute well on the 2 main parts of this meal.

The noodles have that perfect chewy texture that fresh hand-pulled noodles have, and didn't get even a little soggy even as I reached the end of my bowl. The oily spicy broth has a really deep rich meaty flavor layered with the flavor of the peppercorns, and isn't overly spicy. It's just a little tingly and has a much more complex flavor than meets the eye. If you don't drink the soup, you're missing out.

At around $8, it's a quality, simple dish. Even though there's no meat in here, it's sizeable enough to be a meal on its own. And they take credit card, so there's really nothing for me to complain about!
author: Eric Y.

description:
This spot is located in the middle of China Town. Street parking only! There was only about 10 individual tables and one long one in the middle where you share seating.

When I first walked in, nobody really helped me. There was only one person in front of me but the place was packed. So I waited about 5 min until I noticed a pen and paper on the left side. So I out my name down. At this point, I still haven't been acknowledged. 10 minutes passed and the guy in front of me has been helped. I noticed they were cleaning a table so I asked if we could take it. It was then she told me I had to put my name down. Luckily I already did. 

We ordered the spicy beef noodle soup (hubby's) and a fish noodle soup. I tried my husband's broth and it was way too oily! But the meat  was very tender and noodles were cooked to perfection. My fish soup had way too much white pepper. it was quite spicy. The pickle was too watered down and had no sour taste to it. But they loaded it with fish  which was a plus. 

I didn't expect this place to be super clean since it was so busy and they barely had time to clean tables inbetween each customer, but suprisingly it was clean.

Bathrooms are for customers only.
author: Lotus H.

description:
Come here if you want to come face to face with the kiss of death!

Excuse my ignorant self for not knowing how spicy these noodles would be but I should have known with names like "Hot numbing spicy noodle" and "Hot numbing beef tendon". I am so oblivious to this type of cuisine. Call me a noob but my favorite Chinese food is still Panda X because orange chicken is basic and rawks my sox ya'll and no where near as inflaming as the offerings here!

I ordered the Dan Dan noodles because I had never had them before. At first they looked totally intimidating straight out the gate because it's literally noodles with mince meat and slivers of cabbage swimming in a sea of chili oil -- yes folks, oil! Not broth, but oil. So don't sip this like you would most asian noodle dishes that have that comforting soup we all like on a cold chilly day. 

I sneezed so much from inhaling these fiery fumes, the intensity of the chili was so deadly for a noob like myself! Probably made myself look like a complete idiot for attempting to eat this and sneezing at the same time.

The liquid oil that the solids sit in are borderline industrial strength HOT. Kudos to the earthlings that are able to stomach this concoction. I'm weak and I know it!

This would be a great dish if you were stranded in the arctic in sub zero temps but definitely not 'cool' on a happenin' SF night. Oxymoron? 

All in all, I wish there were more veggies. The cabbage was minimal and pretty much transparent from boiling in the oil. The meat was also minimal. It was literally a heaping portion of noodles (the portions here are huge!) drowning in hot chili oil. 

I can't say that I'll ever order this dish again because it's just not my cup of tea but to credit the establishment, there were happy looking patrons dining here so I'm assuming this is a great place for Dan Dan or whatever floats your boat. 

+1 star for not giving me a pimple or too serious of heartburn the next day!
author: Connie M.

description: I came this with my family and we had a very frat time together. They have spicy noodle as well as non spicy one which kids can eat. Their noodle is very Chong Qing and that's why I like eating here
author: Patricia L.

description:
Don't come here if you're looking for a gleaming 90+ health score quiet white tablecloth restaurant to fawn over you.

Come here if you are down to get cheap, good quality, authentic food made made for anyone but which caters to a largely Chinese clientele. The majority of the staff and half of the clientele spoke Mandarin (a minority around the bay). Maybe I found the service to be very good because I spoke Mandarin. The staff are yelling at each other as if no one was listening, this place is pretty small - just barely more than a hold in the wall, and you get pretty cozy to your neighbors - feels so comforting and familiar! 

- TanTan Noodles - bland if you don't get it spicy, but you can add from the big jars of hot sauce on every table and it is very tasty. If you are looking for burn your face off spicy though, you won't get that here. Good to share between 2-3 people if you want to not overload on noodles. 
- Couples delight - Cold mildly spicy tendons, trip, beef thing, pretty good
- Steamed Gailan - I hate gailan b/c it is usually undercooked and too bitter, this was cooked very well and flavorful, best I've had in SF.
- Crispy Pigs Feet - they weren't kidding, this is CRISPY. I love chewy tendon so this was perfect, not too oily or salty. I love gnawing on the giant bone that they cut everything off of for you.

$~40 for 2 if you are pigs like us. Will be back to try everything else.
author: Snuffles B.

description: Had the tan tan noodles. I like spicy but just to be safe I ordered mild and was still like a 2 out of 5. They have chili oil at the table so you can always make it spicier if you'd like. I also got the sweet and sour spare ribs.
author: Eric R.

description:
Located in the heart of China Town, this place is definitely a must-go for me. I really enjoyed their Pickled Mustard Green Beef Noodle Soup. The noodles were cooked perfectly - not too firm, not too soft. I really enjoyed the flavor of the soup as well; the spicy flavor was enough to add another layer of taste to the soup without burning your tongue off. Pickled greens are so good! Beef was very soft and tender. Yum. 

Environment is pretty loud and you might have to wait for a table if you come during lunch or dinner hours, but I think the food is well worth it. 

NOTE: Takeout containers and bags are /NOT/ free here! They charge takeout containers $0.30 each, and throw in a plastic bag for $0.10 added to your bill without telling you. My friend and I learned this the hard way.
author: Cindy W.

description:
How often do you dine out with that one friend of yours? The guy who takes his ability of eating really spicy food and wears it like a badge of honor?

"Oh, your chicken vindaloo is already spicy? Sure, go ahead and make mine Extra Spicy." I mean, c'mon bro.. aren't you at least going to taste your mashed potatoes first before dousing it with Cholula? Well, a buddy of mine recently took one for the team and took me here -- because I'm THAT GUY. 

Sichuan cooking is the Maserati of spicy cuisine. And if you too are THAT GUY, then you already know that every Sichuan dish is brimful of a range of luxurious flavor and spice you never knew you needed until you've tasted it. 

What makes this place especially notable, however, is its approach to their non-spicy offering. Take their unassuming sweet and sour pork spare ribs, for example. Sure, on paper it's basic -- usually when you order this, you'll solicit acts of judgement from even the closest of kin. But there's a level-up achievement hidden here that you're rewarded with once you complete that ultimate test of friendship -- easily marked by my dining companion having to "jump rope" in each time I stopped to breathe. 

Whatever you order here, fresh handmade noodles come standard. The broth served here is especially good and aromatic, and there's a helping of hot sauce should you need additional spice. 

If your dish is of the beef variety, then pack your bags because it's a first-class ticket to FlavorTown! Ok, I apologize for that. Never again. Ever.
author: Mike T.

description:
Yes yes. There usually seems to be a line here but we lucked out. We came close to closing time (around 8:30) so I don't have much to say about service. Everything happened so fast.Super yummy Szechuan food. Flavors we're just right, not too heavy. I'll definitely come back to savor everything more instead of scarfing everything down the way we did. 

Hubby got the namesake noodles and we shared the green onion pancake. I got the Dan Dan noodles, my go to order. Will come again!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
This restaurant has been on my list for quite a while. I finally dined here today and was not impressed. 

I order the Tan Tan Noodles. When I first saw the dish, the broth had a thick layer of oil. I usually taste the broth first before eating any noodle soup, but I didn't this time. I was unable to drink any broth throughout the whole meal because of the high oil content.

Moreover, am I the only one here that thinks the portion size is small? When I dine at ramen or pho spots, I always leave with a full stomach. This time, I felt like I could eat 1.5 orders of the Tan Tan Noodle dish. Given the $9.95 price (before tax), I didn't feel like the dish was worth it given it's size. 

Here are some positive points. The dish was very flavorful, despite the oil content. The noodles were soft and the cabbage was tasty. I recommend ordering the Tan Tan Noodles with less oil and also an appetizer if you're dining alone. You would probably spend $20 on the meal.
author: Petunia M.

description:
This place is good if you like szchechuan Chinese food. Beware though some dishes can be intense like the numbing noodles. I don't know if I like that feeling literally the herbs in it make your mouth numb. It's more like medicine to me. So if you want something that's not as intense but still has some of the same delicious flavors, the tan tan noodles are good. 

Also always order the pancakes because they are so good! Fried and golden delicious. 

Last time I was here I also had the pork belly appetizer which is tons of chili oil sauce, garlic, and stuff. Really flavorful
author: Melissa L.

description:
Really mediocre. Wondering if there are more and better yelp reviews for this location because most people who come in seem to be tourists (not fobby Asians like for the inner Richmond location). 

Got the noodle dish. The sauce had great flavor but the noodles had much to be desired. 

The pork belly appetizer was also disappointing. Warm, not hot or cold. Ok flavor. Sauce doesn't really stick to it. Prefer the tendon dish.
author: J P.

description:
Such affordable, delicious, authentic Chinese food. Perfect to warm up on a cold SF day. 

Mostly soup noodle dishes as mains, but some delicious sides like tea eggs, dumplings, and green onion pancakes as well. Some soups had delicious daikon radish in them, which was new for me.

Easy to get seated on a weekday evening with some communal seating and some private tables. Would come again!
author: Shauna B.

description:
Wow, this IS the Chinese noodle spot!! I love noodles like a pig loves not being bacon. So when I heard about this place from a friend, I was so excited to try. 

Came here twice so far. Ordered Chong Qing Xiao Mian 重庆小面, tan tan noodles 担担面, chicken in wine sauce 秘制醉鸡, and tiger skin peppers 虎皮青椒. Everything was mouthwatering and authentic AF. Excuse my language, but yeah it's THAT good! Chong Qing Xiao Mian is like a spicy vegetarian noodle and tan tan noodle has minced pork in it. Both were super delish. The handmade noodles got me hooked. OMG. The chicken and pepper side dishes were both great. My favorite is the tiger skin peppers. It is actually one of my favorite dishes! You have to try it. 

I spoke mandarin to the waitress and learned that the owner was from Chong Qing so it's double legit! This might be the best kept secret. So please don't come here because I want to keep it all to myself!!!
author: Angela F. W.

description:
Ordered: Wonton w/ Chicken Broth, Steamed vegetable, Sweet & Sour Spare ribs, Spicy beef noodle soup, total $34.50

Everything was really good, except for the sweet & sour ribs. It was way overdone and became chewy/hard to eat. We didn't like it. The wontons were extremely small, but you have quite a bit in there (maybe over 15~20 pieces). The spicy beef noodle soup was done perfectly, not super spicy (I don't eat spicy...), so it was the perfect touch of spicy for me. 

I am hesitant on giving them full stars because of customer service. Service was slow and was not attentive. Had to ask for napkins, chopsticks and refills on water.

Yes, I would like to go back again despite the service (maybe long night?). Food presentation was on point and the food was good enough to go back a second time. I would suggest sticking to what they're known for: noodle dishes.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Realistically this place is more like a 3.5 quality wise but I have to give it a 5 because I eat here so much. So often that I don't even have any pictures of the food here.

One of the only places in dim-sum-dominated-Chinatown to get spicy noodles drenched in chili oil.

Get the spicy beef noodle soup!
author: Michelle R.

description: Large quantities with fast service but the flavor and quality is really lacking. I was not impressed with their tan tan noodles or their Chong Qing Xiao Mian. They were very spicy and oily but with no flavor.
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Tried one of their "SIGNATURE DISHES" the Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup, and it was good. The soup was lightly spiced with a chili bean paste and had some beef flavor.   There were a lot of wheat noodles, and what appeared to be chunks of plain cabbage/pickled vegetables.  Usually the pickled vegetables are supposed to be the hidden stars of this dish, but their salty/sourness just did not come through for us today.

Tried a Steamed Vegetable which consisted of a plate of small bok choy and was good.

We also tried their Braised Spare Ribs w/Rice one of their "SPECIAL RICE" dishes.  The Spare Ribs were mostly large pork neck bones (the two are totally different); they were served in a bowl of soup broth with napa cabbage and a side dish of steamed rice.  Finally, the pork just did not taste fresh.  I like spare ribs and I like pork neck bones, so this day's dish was kinda disappointing.

Overall, we'd give this a 3.
author: Frank L.

description:
Yummy noodle spot.

I liked how their noodles tasted freshly made and we're a nice soft texture.

Tried the Dan Dan Mien and the beef noodle soup.

The Dan Dan was pretty good but not the best I've had. I felt like the seasoned meat needed more seasoning as it was lacking some flavor.  I ended up spending more time eating the beef noodle soup.

The beef noodle soup was delicious. It was a little on the lighter side. I added some of the chilli peppercorn sauce on the table to it for the authentic 'Mala'  taste. :)

Overall a good choice for lunch.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I finally found a Szechuan place that I like in San Francisco!
it's in a great location on Kearny and Broadway st and it's close to work.
Authentic, Clean and Affordable.
they're mostly serving Appetizer dishes (really good portion) and Noodle dishes.
I ordered "Fei Xi Fei Pian (Cold Spicy Numbing Beef Tendon") appetizer and a noodle dish called " Chong Qing Xiao Mian"! (a namesake dish)
both were really good.
I will definitely coming back here every weeks to try different things on the menu.
I will be a regular on a weekly basis.
Recommended!
author: Rudy H.

description: Great noodles and some other small common szechuan dishes
author: Victor D.

description:
Going to keep this short, but I was convinced by some friends to give Chong Qing another try, given that it's been well over a year since they first opened, and one would *hope* that they'd have worked out some kinks since then.

And, well, they did! The restaurant is still on the crowded side, but the tastiness of their food has certainly improved: the noodles are now properly springy and not mushy, and have just the amount of flavor (and then some) that you'd expect. While still not anything spectacular, they now have a spot in my rotation of casual eats around the city.
author: Johnny W.

description:
In my recent trip to San Francisco I found a place that served probably the best small portion meal I've ever had. 

What's ordered:

 "Tiger Skin Jalapeño" ($4.95). I'm the type who loves spicy and to have these thick Jalapeños this way in black rice vinegar, sounds mighty delicious. Obviously, it's spicy right down to the jalapeño seeds. The pool of the smoky flavored savory sauce in it was really good. I actually wanted to consume all the sauces out of its small bowl, but I just took two sips of it. 

"Sweet & Sour Spare Ribs" ($4.95). Its in bite size pieces and by looking at them you could already see the coated dark soy sauce, and sweet & sour orange marinade. Even though some of the pieces were boney it was easy to eat around them. The meats has a crispy outside and tender inside. Along with that, its topped with green onions. With a small order of white rice with these, completes the experience. 

"Braised Beef Soup w/rice" ($10.95). First off, the broth was flavorful. I'm not sure what ingredients they put in to make the soup, but it tasted amazing. They found the right blend of vegetables and herbs with so much jazz. The tender beef and potatoes in the soup paired really well. It's comparable to the Oxtail Soup, but this version was a flavorful masterpiece. 

It was one of our least expensive meals in our trip and it totaled around $25 at four  small size portions. In the end, I thought I needed to order more due to the sizes, but I was satisfied and full. 

Its become a Schezwan favorite on my list.
author: Jon B.

description:
I've been on a small quest to find the best bowl of spicy beef noodle soup in the city. The beef and mustard greens are my favorite in the past year or so. The broth is rich but the acidity from the pickled mustard greens balance it out. Their noodles are chewy and don't seem like the generic texture-less ones you'll find at most places. I polished off my bowl completely. 

We also ordered the tendon/beef and scallion pancake. They were only $5 each so might as well. Worth getting if you have the stomach space. 

I don't make it out to the Chinatown-North Beach area often but I'll use this as a reason to.
author: Huey N.

description:
Not a bad little noodle joint!

The limited seating basically means any table is potentially a communal table. But the food is well-priced, exceptionally flavorful, and no-hold-barred spicy. That's my JAM!
author: Jimmy S.

description:
This place had so many high reviews in the Chinatown area that I just had to try it out. 

Limited seating and it seems like it's normal to wait for a table here. However, service is quick to serve out food and clean up tables so the wait isn't too bad at all. 

Really decent sichuan here. The flavors are what you'd expect -- strong, spicy and tons of chili. 

The soup broth here is extremely flavorful regardless of what you order. Super oily (which makes it a broth that you shouldn't really drink) and and immersed in tons of chili. Despite being so chili infused and red, it's not overwhelming at all! It really adds to the overall taste of your noodle dish or dumplings etc. 

We ordered the tan-tan noodles and spicy beef noodles. No regrets on both! 

We also ordered an appetizer which was tender beef in 5 flavors ($4.95). It was chewy and decently portioned for an appetizer but not as flavorful as what you'd expect from the name. 

Overall, a very easy spot for Sichuan cuisine! Fast and efficient service, but definitely not a place to slowly enjoy your food. Lines get long and the space itself isn't too big. Very fast moving and loud environment.
author: Kimberly G.

description: This is the most authentic Chongqing Cuisine I have found in San Francisco. The entire Chinatown serves either American style Chinese food or Cantonese food. This one definitely stands out. The flavor in every dish is there. If you're looking for spicy food that numbs your tongue, this is the place! I recommend getting the spicy chicken with bone 农家辣子鸡 vs the boneless (regular 辣子鸡）Also spicy beef noodle is a must try!
author: Sharon H.

description:
Hard to rate this place but I'll do my best. The service is a bit cold, you really have to Berle aggressive and just call the waitresses over if you want any help. The food was good, but only half of our party enjoyed it the other half couldn't even eat it. The broths are incredibly oily (see photos), it was hard to eat, good flavors though. 

I did like my soup but because of the things mentioned above I wouldn't go back.
author: Jessie A.

description:
Summary: If there was an option for 6 stars I would give it to this place. The taste of the food is so addicting and the price is unbeatable. 

-Went in for dinner on a Friday night and there was a short wait. The restaurant is pretty small and there's not really a waiting area, you end up just waiting by the door. 
-Service was pretty quick and the food came out fast as well. Some of the tables are shared with other customers, but I didn't mind that
-We got the guilin noodles and the classic numbing noodles. The guilin is a great non spicy option and the texture of the noodles is unlike anything I've had before, so soft and chewy. The broth of the numbing noodles is literally the best flavor ever, it's hard to describe. It is rich, spicy, nutty, and overall just addicting. The noodles were a little different than the guilin, not quite as good but still decent. 
-Would recommend getting one of their yogurt drinks if you can't handle spice very well
-For about $10 for a bowl of noodles this place is the best.
author: Jason C.

description:
EVENT: Got off work at 8pm... time to eat! Line is on a Fridayyy-yayyy night! We barely made the cut for their closing time! But lucky us... we were the last person on that waiting list!! *Phew*

SERVICE: Once seated - I'm surprised how fast they were to take our order and dude... food came flying out! (They really wanna kick us all out, lol)

FOOD:
(1) Sweet and sour pork - a unique twist from the spicy food! This is great for non-spicy eaters!
(2) Couple's delight - also, one of my favorites! 5 stars!
(3) Mouth watering chicken
(4) Cold noodle - I think this was my favorite! I love the cold noodles, 5 stars!
(5) Five spice beef with pickles 

**Spicy Alert** There's also a massive jar of spicy oil sauce... dude! DELISH! If it's not spicy enough for you... drench your food in that spicy sauce... I LOVE IT!

**OVERALL/MUST GET: Couples Delight! 5 stars.. overall!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
I had the Tan Tan Noodles here for Sunday lunch. I went slightly before 12 so there were plenty of open tables at the time, but as noon came the place got pretty crowded. They accept credit cards here which is a nice plus too.

For about $10, the Tan Tan noodles were a fair price, and like many other Szechuan dishes, this one also had that numbing spicy taste to it. The noodles themselves were quite excellent, they tasted pretty freshly made and I enjoy the texture and taste of them. Unfortunately the rest of the dish didn't come out as good as I would have hoped.

The dish itself needs a bit more salt, it is a bit plain despite all of the flavor from the spiciness. They do offer you some sauce at the table that contains black beans which can make it a little saltier, but that also comes with a bunch of other flavors as well. 

The minced meat pieces were okay, the flavoring is a bit more sour than I am used to, but they were still good enough. Overall though, for the price they charge I need more than just the noodles to be top notch.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Surprisingly enough, I'm not a huge fan of restaurants in Chinatown. There are only a few that I truly love, and Chong Qing Xiao Mian is one of them. In fact, this is probably one of my top 3 Chinese noodle spots in the city.

I would strongly recommend Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodles and Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup. They have weird English names, I know, but I swear they are absolutely delicious. Like other reviewers have mentioned, portion size is very generous at this place and price is really cheap compared to other restaurants. Most of the items on the menu are below $10. 

There is usually a short wait if you go for dinner on weekends, roughly 20-30 minutes. If you go during lunch, you should be able to get a seat right away!
author: Angel C.

description:
Had the spring rolls they were awesome 
Also had the Braised Pork and noodles they were very good I definitely would come back
author: Joe M.

description:
One of the worst experiences after I ate the noodle here! 

We came here because it looked authentic, and we just wanted something soupy. 

We ordered spicy beef noodle soup, and rib noodle soup. The flavors were not bad (I only found out why it was good in the hard way). We asked for less noodles in our soup, they said they couldn't do it- I knew it's because they probably used dry noodle balls which they couldn't break. My bf asked for extra hot for his soup (temperature wise) it came wasn't hot at all. I thought the soup was good, so I drank a lot of soup. 

About 15 minutes after I left the restaurant, I started to feel light headed, my heart was raising, and my hands were numb!!! Because they used so much MSG and my body was sensitive to MSG! 

Don't come here again, for the quality of food, it's just not worth it.
author: Jasmine J.

description:
Delicious food, huge portions, spicy but not too spicy.

The dan dan noodles were especially popular in our group, but overall we enjoyed all of the dishes we got. Be sure to try the black bean sauce that they provide at each table - it's a little sweet but spicy! 

Spacing is a little tight, the ceiling is taped, but the food is pretty good, so definitely stop by!
author: Hannah H.

description:
Nothing special. The beef stew I got was very bland, no seasoning. It's also very difficult to eat the meat using chop sticks, even my friend who is more of a chop sticks expert than myself didn't think it was manageable.

Combine that with the bad service even by Chinese restaurant standards, and higher prices than average for China Town.
author: Matthew P.

description: I got lured into this place by its name: Chong Qing Xiao Mian, which is a famous local street food. But I ended getting the individual hot pot which looks too good to be missed. The pot is only ~$17 per person and you get to choose among a few flavors and ingredients. I chose the spicy pot with fish and lamb. It was so yummy and has more than fish and lamb - I found shrimp, meet balls, corns and many vegetables. They had great pepper oil sauce in case you want extra spicy in your pot. As someone who spent many years in Chong Qing where the cuisine is originated, I'm very satisfied with the food here! Service is average, but not bad.
author: Nancy M.

description:
I had a great experience at Chong Qing Xiao Mian. The service was incredibly fast, and the food was all very tasty. We started with a lot of apps, including the green onion pancakes, veggie spring rolls, sweet and sour spare ribs, pot stickers, and steamed pork belly. All good. The standout was the sweet and sour pork ribs, as the sauce was sweet with a bit of tang. Great with rice. 

Braised spare ribs w/ rice: the beef was super tender the veggies and sauce went well with the rice. 

Would definitely recommend. (Note: they don't serve alcohol.)
author: Christopher D.

description: Highly recommend.  Yelp reviews on this place are spot on. Authentic spicy Szechuan noodle soups. Small restaurant in Chinatown. Not fancy. But it sure hits the spot if you are looking for this. Good appetizers as well - chicken feet, sesame pancakes, potstickers. . .  Clean, efficient, a local favorite.
author: Carlos D.

description:
Poppin' noodle restaurant in the heart of China town.
If you're looking for a Chinese noodle restaurant where the workers are not TOO aggressively yelling at you this is your place.
Our table opted for 3 noodles and 3 side dishes for the 4 of us (it was too much food. no surprises there)
Of the three noodles we tried. the regular Chong Qing, the dan dan, and the beef noodle soup the dan dan was by for our favorite. The minced meat was definitely the most flavorful topping for our noodz. Other than that the broth tasted pretty similar.
The cucumber was a good side dish, as it wasn't too flavorful and provided a good break from the burning noodles.
Our absolute FAVORITE was the pork knuckle though! Crispy skin on a ginormous bone to pick at. Delish!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Meh customer service, but delicious noodles and great price for the size.

I came here on a weekday around 1pm. Ever since they moved to this bigger location, the customer service is meh. There were only 3 servers; all of them are busting tables, taking orders, bringing food, and being cashier. We had to flag them down many times just to order and for our check.. Sadly they looked so overworked/overwhelmed. 

Besides the customer service, the noodles are probably the closest thing to Taiwanese noodles you can have in the city. For the price, you get more than enough noodles in your bowl. (Probably enough for two people) I ordered the Dan Dan noodles mild, there is more chili on side if you want it more spicy. The noodles are made to order there and are super tasty and flavorful. 


I recommend this place if you have time and want authentic Taiwanese noodles. But be prepared for their customer service.
author: Jenny S.

description: Lots of vegan options, like their namesake, chongqing hot numbing spicy noodle, wuhan hot dry noodle, and house cold noodle. The noodles get their yellowness from alkaline water, not egg.
author: W T.

description:
This smallish shop was pretty busy when we came here for lunch but there was still enough space for us to be seated without waiting. The menu looked amazing, with all sorts of different spicy and bold flavored dishes.

I decided on the lamb with pickled mustard green soup and had a bite of the dan dan noodles. While we settled into our seats and took in the decor, I noticed there was a big wooden container filled with chili oil. Yess! When the noodles came out the chili had some very rock hard bits but had good spicy flavor that went well with my soup. The soup itself was light, yet had bold flavor from the pickled veggies and slightly sour broth. It was a good complement with the lamb. The noodles were nicely cooked, and had a nice "bite" to them. While there was a good portion of thinly shaved lamb in the soup, it was a bit tough and chewy for my tastes. 

The dan dan noodles also had an al dente texture, but were a bit bland with the sauce so it really needed the strong, concentrated flavor of the ground meat mixed with it well. It was served with fresh cabbage rather than pickled vegetables.

Service was succinct. We got our meals quickly.

I'd definitely go back here to try more off their menu.
author: Karen W.

description:
I think this is one of the more solid places to get lunch if you work in the FiDi. I'm a huge noodle soup girl and am constantly trying to find good places to go during my lunch hour. Honestly, I'm over ramen; and TBH I'm not a fan of any of the places in the downtown area. But lately I've been on this Szechuan noodle kick: enter Chong Qing Xiao Mian. 

I got the Chong Qing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle. Go big or go home? As expected, it came loaded with lots of chile oil and dried chiles. The broth was spicy, but not overwhelmingly so, and there was good flavor. While the noodles weren't fresh hand-pulled noodles, they did have a nice bite and the portion of noodles was HUGE (not to say I didn't finish them). At $7.95 I thought it was a fantastic value - especially when comparing it to the $13 salads my coworkers get. 

Get there before noon. The restaurant isn't huge and fills up. They turn tables pretty quickly, but better to be safe. Be prepared to sweat.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
The food here is good and cheap but this is part of the SF Sichuan Restaurant Empire.  I don't understand why people don't go to Pot & Noodle which is just across the street and is owned by the same people and has the same but expanded menu and staff.

The space is small so you're often pretty packed in and there are lines at some of the busy times of the day.  This is in Chinatown and close to FiDi so I always see friends at college at this place.

I generally get the Guilin Rice Noodle Soup but the Chongqing Hot Numbing Noodles are great too if you're okay with no meat.
author: Mark C.

description: We searched for a local eatery and we found it. A small "hole in the wall" location with lots of patrons. The noodles were plentiful and the spice was just right, however, soup was oily. I assume because of the overly fatty meat. Overall not a bad spot and prices were reasonable.
author: Luisa J.

description:
I love Sichuan food, and the pictures of the noodles here looked pretty amazing, so I was excited to come here.

Unfortunately, I thought the food was super average. Originally from Asia, I'm used to the grease of Chinese food, and of course expected loads of spicy chili oil all over my noodles, but it was pretty excessive here. To the point I felt disgusted. 

I came with two others, and we ordered the tantan (dandan) mian, beef brisket noodles, wontons in chili oil, fried potstickers, and the pickled cucumber. 

The best dish by far was the pickled cucumber, which was actually well-marinated, delicious, and refreshing. 

The pot stickers' skin was too thick and slightly undercooked in places, and they were severely under-filled. Semi-cooked tough dough anyone?
Also, I usually love the wontons in chili oil (a dish I always get when I'm back in Asia), but these were pretty pathetic. They're also usually a side dish when served in Asia, not served swimming in broth in a massive noodle bowl. Again, severely under-filled wontons. All I ate was a ton of wonton skin--wasn't even sure if you could qualify these as wontons...?

Beef brisket was pretty tasty, but there were all of two pieces in the "beef brisket noodle". Again, massive bowl, but you'll find it's 90% noodle, 10% meat (no exaggeration). Finally, dan dan mian was huge bowl again, but just, noodle and oil and a bit of minced meat.

I was pretty disappointed. The flavors were somewhat there, and the cucumber was really good, but apart from that, expect huge bowls filled with noodles and barely any meat/ toppings. Most likely, you won't even want to finish it. I wish they cut their portions and instead invested in a little more quality. Also, expect some flies for company!! 

If you want good Chong Qing/ Sichuan food, I suggest you go somewhere else.
author: Su Lin Y.

description: The service was horrible and I was ordered to fold my stroller in a rude manner. I left the store immediately. Speechless. Shame on you!!
author: Meng C.

description:
Overall, the food was tasty and the portion was big. We ordered the steam vegetables and Bean jello with red chili sauce for appetizers. The steam vegetables were just the way it supposed to be, but the jello wasn't flavorful - I could only taste Chinese vinegar and that was all. I was expecting a richer flavor and spicier. 

We got a spicy beef soup noodle and a slingle cooked noodle soup. For both, there was very little meat in it, probably 2 - 3 piece max, so I wish they put more meat in it. Otherwise, the flavorful was good, and I like that they put vegetables in the noodle soup as well.
author: Yuan Z.

description: Amazing food.  We got there at the tail end of the midweek lunch rush and were seated quickly.  I can't recommend the tea eggs enough.  I got the spicy duck rice noodle soup  and it was awesome (careful with bones).
author: Ryan R.

description:
I've heard about this place for so long from various friends that I had built up some pretty high expectations, and I'm happy to say they were met and exceeded :)

Came here for lunch with some coworkers around noon on a weekday. We waited for about 20 min for a table of 3, which wasn't bad.

They're known for their spicy beef noodle soup ($10.95), so that's what I ordered. Since I have zero spice tolerance, I asked for them to swap out the spicy broth for a non-spicy broth. Our server did mention that since the beef is already cooked, there's no way to make it non-spicy, but I was okay with that.

Our orders came out within minutes! The star of the show was definitely the beef, which was braised to be super soft and tender and flavorful. The beef was spicy but not something I couldn't handle without the occasional pause to give my mouth a break from the heat. The noodles and the broth that came with it were both really good too and complemented the beef perfectly. I can't recommend this dish enough, especially if you're a fan of Asian style noodle soups!

Come here when you want a quick and delicious Chinese meal in a no frills environment.
author: Dianna H.

description:
I've passed by Chong Qing Xiao Mian many times and each time I've found it to be full with people waiting outside, so I finally decided to give it a try a couple of days ago. It is your typical Chinese Szechuan place so I decided to get the Tan Tan noodles ($9.95) to-go (+35c for container and +10c SF bag fee) as that is the best dish to benchmark Szechuan restaurants. After ordering it was a 10 minute wait and I was on my way.

Even though they had charged me extra for a container the noodles and broth was provided in a single container. This ensured that the noodles soaked up the broth and turned soft. The broth was straight up chili oil that left a nice numbing taste in the mouth. Overall this dish was let down by the noodles which should have been provided in a separate container.

Price wise it was 20% more expensive than let's say a Spicy King. I'm tempted to say that this is a tourist trap but that would be wrong as most of the patrons here are Asian.  So I guess they are just cashing in on their popularity. I'm not sure if I got the wrong dish but the Tan Tan noodles here are high priced and average. I may come back and try some stuff of their menu but I'm in no hurry to do that.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Quick and yummy!

Ordered the Tan Tan noodles -- deliciously portioned! Not as spicy as everyone says!! Unless I have a high tolerant of spice level now that is surprising and an improvement for my own personal goal haha. Noodles I believe were hand pulled(?) so I always love that chewiness! The flavor was so good. We also ordered the lamb skewers which I loved and believed was spicier than the Tan Tan BC of the cumin flavor.
author: Raviana R.

description:
Chong Qing Xiao Mian is adjacent to popular tourist book spot House of Nanking and whereas that establishment is almost entirely filled with non-Chinese, Chong Qing Xiao Mian is a good mixture of both.  

We stopped by craving for noodles and I wasn't disappointed.  It's been awhile since I've been to Chinatown and it's nice to see a newer and cleaner establishment with a Chinese regional (Szechuan) cuisine that you don't see often.  

The menu is foreigner friendly with nice pictures and simple descriptions and the prices are fair.  Service is a bit brisk, but it's fast and efficient.  The space is crowded with a lack of big group tables and fills up quickly.  You may also have to wave down someone to get your bill or take your order, but once it's in, food comes out fast.  Our food:

Spicy Beef Noodle Soup - $10.95.  In the picture, thick noodles are shown, but our version came with thin noodles.  I'm not sure if you have to ask, but luckily the thin noodles were tasty too.  The broth is good and the beef brisket pieces are very tender and flavorful.  Good portion size.

Tan Tan Noodles - $9.95.  I liked this dish as well.  Same great noodles above and the tan tan sauce is a nice mix of ground meat and vegetables with enough sauce to coat all the noodles.  Good portion size as well.

Tea Egg - $2.  A bit overcooked and probably left in the slow cooker all day, but it was 2 for $2 and nice marinade.

Green Onion Pancake - $4.95.  Popular with everyone this is a great non-spicy dish and good for soaking up sauce.

Mouth Watering Szechuan Style Chicken - $4.95.  Despite the interesting name, this dish is legit with free range chicken in a nice sauce with a slight numbing that is authentic and flavorful.  It's a bit on the cold side and has bean sprouts that soak up the spicy sauce.  Great with rice.

Fatty Pork Belly - $7.95.  The picture looks great but the portion size is smaller and a bit overcooked and salty as a result.  There is nice fat, but the lean portions are not juicy anymore and you need to drink water with this dish.

Overall, we had a great meal here.  Food is varied and tasty and it comes out fast in great portions at a nice price point.  While I've had better versions of the fatty pork and the tan tan noodles, I think everything here is very tasty and great for sharing.  A nice addition to Chinatown and much better than the tourist book place next door where you have to wait in line.

Chong Qing Xiao Mian accepts credit cards, but not American Express.
author: Randy F.

description: I love this place. Spicy food heaven. If spicy Chinese food is your thing then this is a perfect place. The wait may be a little long but it's worth the wait.
author: JoJo L.

description: I think this is the best soup I've had. Almost ever. Gf and I get something different every time and every single thing has been great! Tan tan noodles and Numbing Soup are some of the best.
author: Scott L.

description:
Want something 'numbingly' spicy? This is the spot. I had to find out how spicy the hard way when a drop of the broth made its way into my eye. I have to admit, I'm not the most elegant slurper out there. So my clumsy slurping made me appreciate the Chong Qing cuisine more.

The signature Chong Quing noodles are not good on their own. You need a side dish of meat to help it along as it comes with nothing but the noodles and the broth. The spare rib noodles soup on the other hand was mellow but the pork was nicely done.
