A 3.5/5 solid Go-if-you're-in-Chinatown restaurant.
author: Ganesh K.

description: Below average quality. Coming from someone who is from Szechuan, I have quite a high bar but it tasted very so-so. I had the dan dan noodles and the sour fish soup which were both mediocre at best. The ground pork was a bit overbooked and not seasoned at all. Overall, spicy but lacked flavor- if you know what I mean?
author: Claire H.

description: Small place kind of crowded. But the food is tasty. The chicken I ordered was awesome.
author: Nanshan L.

description:
Very small place which means you will be eating very close to other tables. The food was so good that once you start eating you forget everything around you. 

Lamb skewers were divine.
author: Judi H.

description:
CQXM has some seriously mouth-numbing, sinus-clearing, and hangover-curing spicy noodle soups!  We came here for lunch for the final day of our SF staycation.  My wife found this place on Yelp and I was pleased to see various positive reviews from fellow Elite friends. 

During our visit, they ran out of spicy wontons, so we just got noodle soups.  The spicy beef with pickles is excellent, especially with the tender, trimmed brisket meat.  The use of Daikon radish was also a nice touch, adding a wee bit of sweetness in a sea of hellbroth.  The Dan Dan noodles came in soup form, and also came with a whole lot of heat.  I think the Beef noodles are a tad bit better.  Tea eggs were way too salty.

Definitely worth coming here if you want to give your taste buds a workout!  Restaurant is next to House of Nanking and two doors from Xian Dumplings.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I had basically given up on dan dan noodles until I ordered them here and finally understood why the dish exists.  They probably tone it down a little for wimpy white people like me but it's still excellent.  Unfortunately the dan dan noodles are so good I can't bring myself to order anything else, but it all looks delicious.

I regularly travel all the way across town to come here.
author: Ian S.

description:
CLASSIC CHINESE RESTAURANT - really standoffish, but prompt service, and delicious and non-pretentious food with really large portion sizes for their prices.

Came here for an early dinner with Kristen (4:50pm). Only one other party of 6 was in the small restaurant. The menu is really straightfoward: has a section for nodle dishes, main entrees, and appetizers. Kristen and I shared a vegetable appetizer (bok choy, not spicy $5.95) and she got the tan tan noodles and I got the beef noodle soup with mustard greens. Our noodles came before the vegetables and were SOO HUGE - they gave us so many noodles and we both couldn't finish. Compared to other szechuan restaurants, I didn't think these were spicy or numbing at all. But the broth warmed our souls, and the table had a huge jar of black bean sauce from which I added generous scoops of sauce into my soup. The chunks of beef that came with my soup reminded me of home and were very tender and yummy. I was pretty happy.
author: Yenny Z.

description: Not sure why this place is ranked so high. I've been to chongchinq and this place does not even come close to quality or taste for that matter. Sorry owners.
author: Nathan P.

description:
I've only had lunch here and it was very satisfying. The menu offers an array of spicy noodles with side dishes. It's too far from my office, otherwise I'd come here a lot more often. 

Note: the place is not very big and gets packed during busy hours.
author: Amy Z.

description:
My coworker's and I came here around 1pm and there was a wait for about 5 minutes. The service is pretty horrible here as we put our name down and was standing by the door outside waiting and they didn't call our names but let another party in and seated them before us even though we clearly arrived first.

Once our table of 4 was cleared, no one came to tell us that our table was ready and didn't tell us to sit down and proceeded to take orders from other tables and just let us stand and wait by the door until we asked if this table was ours, even though one of workers there had previously asked how many people were in our party and knew we were waiting to be seated.

While we were looking At the menu and waiting for someone to take our order, the waitress said "hurry up" in mandarin. I'm not fluent in mandarin but I know what that means! Also, how do we "hurry up" when we weren't even able to flag you down so that we can put our order in? Our customer service experience was terrible, but it might be better for those who are older or who speak Chinese fluently.. 

Anyways, we all ordered the tan tan noodle and two appetizers to share - the green onion pancake and the sweet and sour spareribs. The green onion pancake was pretty good, similar to other places I've had them at. The spareribs were not even sweet and sour. They had this different flavor to it maybe like those Asian vinegar eggs? I had one and had to pass on it. We all didn't like it very much. The   Tan tan noodles itself was pretty good, however it was pretty spicy and some of my coworker's including myself, couldn't handle it. The spiciness is kind of like the numbing spice so it's different from the usual spicy taste, but still good if you can handle it. 

I really wanted to try the non spicy items on the menu like the pork bone noodle soup, but I'm not so sure after the horrible service we experienced..
author: Bailey L.

description:
Yum!!

Legit noodles: Check
Tons of spice: Check
Questionable Cleanliness: Check
Aggressive Asian Lady Yelling at You: Check!!!

Chong Qing Xiao Mian has all the parts to an authentic Chinese noodle experience! 

We ordered Spicy Beef Noodle Soup and the Tan Tan noodles. I generally can handle only a little bit of spice so we asked for both of them to be less spicy and they were definitely the perfect level for me. The noodle soup had great flavor and I was really into the tan tan noodles. Overall a great spot to satisfy that noodle hankering! Will definitely be back!
author: Christina L.

description:
Small space typical of sf Asian restaurants, but the wait for us was only 20 minutes for four people on a Saturday night, which was reasonable. 

We entered in with some trepidation, having had insanely spicy Szechuan food before. After ordering far too much food the wait was very short. 

We had the pork spare ribs, 3 noodle bowls, pot stickers, spring rolls, onion bread, and white rice. The server thought we had ordered an inordinate quantity 

Let's speak to the spiciness level first. It was adequate, not insane. I was honestly slightly disappointed that it wasn't just a little bit hotter. The temperature of the food was good and hot, it didn't sit at all. 

Overall a great meal. A little heavy on the oil but that's par for the course
author: Kian A.

description: Decent affordable noodles here, though I feel like some of the sides here are more worthwhile (really good kou shui ji).
author: Josh L.

description:
This place is pretty authentic as far as Sichuan noodles go, and it shows as far as the clientele. The wait is brutal, about 6 or 7 parties ahead of me on a weekday, though thankfully it moves fast. Pay attention to the sign in sheet! People are savage...writing their names on the extended first page instead of the second and cutting in line.

There isn't much seating space, so when you sign in, they'll ask whether you mind sharing a table. This can make for some interesting placements, as I ended up sitting across from a lady from a different group.

Ordered the dan dan mian and couple's delight. The noodles came in a good sized bowl and was more than enough. The couple's delight was authentic and spicy, though a bit more tendon than preferred. The dan dan mian came in a soup, which isn't typical, but was still tasty.

If I come back, I'll look to try the hot and sour rice noodle and beef noodle soup. Parking can be tough in this area.
author: Tim X.

description: I really enjoyed the tan tan noodles here. Prices are cheap and Szechuan food is great. Also, special points for the tea!
author: Yana Y.

description: Homey, small place with authentically tasty street food-style eats.  Cucumber salad was vibrantly vinegary.  The namesake noodles were fine, though they needed a little extra pepper boost from the huge can of Lao Gan Ma-type condiment.  Braised pork slices provided a rich contrast to the noodles.  I would return for the Dan Dan mian and other enticing selections.  Not quite a life changing meal but solid and worth repeat visits.  Unfortunately the washroom was also rather authentic, based on my years of living in China.
author: Rich H.

description:
A fast and fun spicy noodle experience!

Chong Qing Xiao Mian is a restaurant that specializes spicy noodles. This type of spicy noodles is the burning spice. How this restaurant works is that it starts off with Chong Qing Xiao Mian which is the base. The Chong Qing Xiao mian consists of noodles, the numbing spice broth (a spicy that is numbing, not burning), noodles, and green onions, napa cabbage, and some meat. Every other soup dish is usually the chong qing xiao mian with extra garnishes or slightly different broths.

My friend and I came to Chong Qing Xiao Mian on a Monday at around 5:45pm. It was fairly empty at this time so we were seated promptly. My friend and I ordered the cucumber salad, spicy numbing beef tendon (beef tendon served cold in spicy chili oil), szechaun style Pork Belly, the chong qing xiao mian, and the Ginger Duck Noodle soup. A really big plus here is that everything came out super fast.

The cucumber salad was a solid traditional chinese styled cucumber salad. With vinegar cucumber, soy sauce, it is a crisp and delicious appetizer. 
The spicy numbing beef tendon was a bit disappointing. The portion size was very good, but the taste was very generic. The chili oil itself was pretty standard, and the tendon was a bit boring.
The Szechuan style pork belly was very delicious. It was soft where it would melt in your mouth, and there was a surprisingly good amount! I thought when the menu said Szechuan styled it would be spicy, but it was not spicy at all and had a nice savory taste.
The Chong Qing Xiao Mian itself was good. Not great, but good. The broth it was in tasted exactly as it looked like, the szechuan numbing sauce but very watered down. The broth being watered down allowed the noodles for faster consumption. The portion size of this was also crazy, there was a ton of noodles, it's very deceiving!
The Ginger Duck Noodle Soup was simply the Chong Qing Xiao Mian with ginger duck on top. The ginger duck was gingery and tasty, but I personally got a bit too many boney pieces(so not much meat). Having a bit more meat definitely added a lot to the meal in my opinion.

Overall I could recommend Chong Qing Xiao Mian to people who are looking to try southern Chinese food. The Chong Qing Xiao Mian isn't spicy to the point where it's difficult to eat, so people with a small spice tolerance should be able to enjoy it as well!
author: Anthony Y.

description:
Not many non spicy options but the noodle soup was good! I'm not a fan of the numbing spice so got one of the more plain noodle soup (no meat) and it was really good. Noodles were cooked well, and the broth was just clean and simple.

The chicken app was dry, but we plan on coming back next time to try the won ton in chili oil!
author: Cal C.

description:
I was drawn inside by the clean windows and the 4 star yelp review (this must be driven by tourist reviews because we thought it was really poor food for San Francisco standards). After leaving, my stomach felt really bad, and the food was pretty awful, so we will not go back.

We had the:

Pork belly (ok but really greasy)
Lamb skewers (so fatty we could not eat them)
Tan tan noodles (again really oily and greasy, hard to eat. Flavor was good but the oil overwhelmed it all.

Service was poor. Our dishes were not cleared and we had to flag down folks for service.

I am wondering how this place has good reviews.
author: Jane C.

description:
If you're craving Szechuan food, this place is the place to go in Chinatown! It's very authentic and the food is good. This is their smaller shop, but if you walk a few blocks they have a big location now with tons of seating. 

PORK BELLY WITH GARLIC SAUCE 5/5
So good! Pork belly melts in your mouth and the sauce compliments it very well.

GREEN ONION PANCAKE 5/5
The pancake had the perfect texture! 

COUPLE'S DELIGHT 4/5
Exactly as you expect. Good appetizer for sharing 

BEEF NOODLE SOUP 3.5/5
DO NOT GET THIS TO GO. The noodle absorbs most of the soup and it's just sad lol. However, getting it for dine in is decent. The beef is tender and they give you a huge portion of noodles. I can't point my finger on it, but it just didn't quite live up to expectations. I felt like the appetizers might have been better than the main dish

This restaurant will hit the spot if you're looking for Szechuan food near downtown!
author: Poy W.

description:
My wife said this restaurant's House cold noodle is very authentic and reminds her of her childhood in China.

I also really like the Chingqing Xiaomian, highly recommended.
Unlike other restaurants hiring non-Chinese to cook Chinese food, the cooks in this restaurant  are real Chinese!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Chong Qing Xiao Mian is a pretty authentic chinese noodle shop located in Chinatown SF. They're quite popular so if you stop by during meal times on weekends, prepare for a wait! i also don't recommend coming with parties greater than 5 as space is pretty limited. 

Our group of four tried a number of their noodles and appetizers. We weren't disappointed by any of them. Price is also very reasonable given it's chinatown. 

For myself, I ordered the guilin noodles because I loved them when I had them in Guilin, China and never found them again. The ones i had in Guilin were dry but these are soup-based. the flavors were very similar. I'd recommend it, it's quite unique! :)
author: Annie Z.

description: They offer very local food in southwest China and the flavor is local too. Not too spicy. Noodles is offered in large bowel and quite enough for an average girl. The juice looks nice but not too much room for it.
author: Clare G.

description:
Sichuan spicy time! Their spiciness is much needed on a cold, foggy day in SF and whenever one is feeling like they need the numbness to the tongue that this spice cuisine brings. 

Dan Dan noodles is what I ordered up and they gave a generous portion of noodles.  The broth left more to be desired (a bit bland in flavor) and noodles as well.  The spiciness helped with slurping it down though. 

There are food pictures on the wall as well as on the menu for reference. It's quite helpful to see he items before ordering.  

Do order pickled cucumber cold appetizer.  It goes well with the spiciness by complimenting spicy hot and refreshingly cold to the palate. 

The lamb skewers are tasty and I like the kick of the peppercorn that is sprinkled on to it.  I think the peppercorn covered the gamey flavor that I usually prefer, but it was good nonetheless.  

I miss Sichuan cuisine and this one hits the spot.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Great sichuan noodle. I love their spicy sliced pork belly. The sauce is just enough. Not too spicy. After trying their tan tan mian, duck noodle and wuhan dried noodle, I think the last one is still the best.
author: Vy T.

description:
Great food, great taste, and fast service. Only complaint is the menu is a little difficult to understand. Also, portions are massive! I recommend sharing. 

P.s American Express is not allowed
author: Kelli H.

description:
I tried to pronounce the name of this restaurant and was accused of being racist. Such is life.

I think this place might have been my first encounter with Szechwan peppercorns, which tingled my mouth into numbness. Even my water started to taste weird. 

We ordered the pork belly with garlic sauce, tan tan noodles, some clear noodle soup (there's a picture of it on top) and some dumpling spicy soup. (I'm totally blanking on their names. It was in Chinese and too difficult to retain for this review.)

I think the tan tan noodles were my favorite. 

Small space with communal tables. It's a good place to try some authentic Szechwan food (according to my fob friends).
author: Juliana P.

description:
I was looking for a hot spicy Asian soup place in SF during my visit and I decided to try this place.
I started with some Gyoza and they were tasty but oily!
For my soup, i decided to take the same one that another client next to me has (he's Asian and he suggest that to me. It's bokchoy,meat,noodles and spicy broth. However, when I get my dish, it was broth with cabbage! I was very surprised that I asked the server and she said that the switch the vegetable between cabbage and bok choy!
I did not appreciate that!
A lot of slurping noise that drives me crazy too!


Service was good and fast!
author: Joe S.

description:
I know that some people are freaked out by numbing spice, or just hate it, but if you're someone that enjoys every second of the signature spicy tingles of Szechuan food, this is a great place to go in SF.

The Chong Qing noodles and the Tan Tan noodles are the way to go for the entrees, and the wontons in chili oil and the steamed vegetables (I think they're mustard greens) are great to share on the side.

Both noodle dishes are very wet and saucy without making the noodles soggy, and even though there's obviously a good amount of the signature chili oil, it doesn't feel like you're engorging yourself with oily noodles. I think the Tan Tan noodles were actually slightly more flavorful, but both are great.

Overall, I love this place. Will definitely be back when I have Szechuan cravings.
author: Sara L.

description:
Delicious noodle spot in downtown/Chinatown! I didn't realize that this was a chain, as I've actually been to their other location in the south bay many times. They also have a few other locations withun SF that I've not been to before. 

I always order the lamb noodle or beef noodle soup (spicy). I believe that this location mostly has noodle-based dishes while the other locations might have more variety (soups, vegetables, and meat dishes to pair with rice). 

It's also a pretty large bowl as I'm not able to finish an entire noodle dish all by myself.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
A mix of Chongqing, Sichuan and Wuhan dishes. Mostly authentic.

I recommend the hot dry noodles (热干面) from Wuhan and also Chongqing hot numbing spicy noodles （重庆小面) which is what this place is named after. The Chongqing noodles will numb your lips and are decently spicy (not overboard though).

Food portion size is great for the price. You won't be leaving hungry.
author: Tom P.

description: I came by with two other friends on a Saturday late afternoon. I ordered my usual, Chong Qing Xiao Mian and my friends ordered Tan Tan noodles, sweet & sour short rib dish, and tendon dish. I love how authentic my dish and the servers are. The dish comes with lot of fresh noodles and cabbages over the spicy chili oil broth. The tendon dish was very good as well. The tendon were sliced into thin pieces dipped in oil sauce garnished with bean sprouts. I highly recommend this place.
author: Lisa O.

description:
Came here on a Sunday evening and beat the rush. This place tends to have a line but I haven't ever had to wait too long. 

Dishes:
- Cucumbers
- Couple's Delight
- Spicy Numbing Noodles

Our total came out to be just under $20 and we were both pretty full. I love anything with chili oil, so the couple's delight (beef tripe and tendon) and spicy numbing noodles were delicious. I was so tempted to take the leftover chili oil home. The cold cucumbers complimented the spice from the other two dishes. Left feeling very fat and happy.
author: Annie L.

description:
Friend recommended this spot after a FiDi workout session. Definitely ask for extra knapkins when you get there- these noodz here are FIRE!!! They're nice and chewy (on the thin side how I like it) and their broth is flavorful without being too oily as is the case with most spots in the ChinaTown/NorthBeach area

Super good tho! I'd definitely come back!

Good spot to catchup with friends- but maybe not the best date spot given how closely you're seated with other people. The prices are great, the wait wasn't long, the service was fast, and their options are wide ranging (including many items you can't find anywhere else in SF)
author: James L.

description:
I'm so glad I live in Chinatown and this bomb of a noodle place is so close to me. SPICY-LOVERS this is your spot, and even for those wimps such as myself who can't handle the spice, you'll also be in love. 

I've been here a few times now and always order the same thing....I want to branch out to try other things but it's just so good. Maybe next time I'll try something else on the menu. 

My go-to item on the menu is the tan tan noodles (dan dan mien) and they're so yummy. Beware though if you can't handle spicy because I barley can and am constantly fighting the line between mouth on fire and taste buds having a field day. The noodles and pork go really well together with the soup broth. Overwhelmingly spicy but with some salty and meatiness to the soup. Although the soup is the spiciest part of the meal, it's perfect to have on a cold, rainy San Francisco day. 

I also recommend getting the green onion pancakes. They're flaky and not too salty so they are perfect to dip into your soup and eat along with your meal. If it's still not spicy enough for you, they have extra spice you can add in the container on the table. I would never dare touch since it's definitely spicy enough for me. Be prepared to drink lots of water to quench the spice as well.
author: Eric L.

description:
Such a solid place for noodles in Chinatown! Came in on a Saturday right before noon and luckily we got a table without having to wait (at all). 2 minutes after we were seated there was a wait so just got To try to beat the lunch rush. 

I ordered the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup($10.95)and my friend ordered the Chong Qing Xiao Mian ($7.95). The spicy beef noodle soup was delicious- and the beef was very tender. There was a generous heaping of noodles, and the white carrot was cooked well. My friends Chong Qing Xiao mian was also quite good, just had no meat so it's good for vegetarians! I found that the broth essentially tasted the same between the two of them, so if you're hungry and want meat, get the spicy beef noodle soup! It's not too overly spicy too -my mouth wasn't too numb after - so if you like diehard spice, you can prob ask for more. 

The service here as mentioned by other reviews is SLOW. It is hard to get the people's attention here so good luck and try to order as soon as you can. I don't think my other friend ever got his coke either haah but we weren't charged for it. 

Overall, good hearty portion of noodles but not if you're in a time crunch- service is kind of slow!
author: Kristie M.

description: Not very good.  Noodles taste like supermarket lo mein.  The cilantro in the bland cucumber salad was gritty, definitely had not been washed.  We had to lift our feet as we ate so they could get the hand trucks full of uncovered noodles past us.  So disappointed.
author: Alex L.

description:
Having eaten in quite a few szechuan restaurants I find the flavors here were quite unique. Like curries I expected szechuan restaurants to express their individuality and this restaurant does that nicely. Most Indian and Thai restaurants taste very much alike and so do very many copy cat szechuan eateries.

The mouth watering chicken was cooked perfectly and soaked in a spicy oil. Quite nicely done.

The Chong Ching hot spicy noodles and the lamb pickled mustard soup were both delicious with al dente noodles and a flavorful broth.

The bbq lamb skewers were nicely spiced, tender and delicious. Overall an unexpectedly good discovery for me. I would return and try other dishes.
author: Keo N.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco and was nearby for a work meeting. I decided to come here with a friend to try it out based on Yelp reviews. 

The restaurant sits on a busy street with numerous Asian eateries, many offering the same fare. We came in on a Friday afternoon at 1.30pm. The space is small and busy but we were seated within 5 minutes. We each received a menu which is uniquely printed on a both sides of a single wooden board. Many of their popular items had accompanying photos which was helpful. There are a lot of appetizers! We were brought water within minutes of sitting down and the very hardworking and busy server got to us for orders within 10 minutes of being seated. 

To start, we got the pickled cucumbers, tea eggs and bbq lamb ribs. The cucumber salad was delicious, it not overly sour with hints of fish sauce and sesame oil for umami. I've only had tea eggs a couple of times before but the ones we got were the best. The tea, soy sauce and (I believe) anise and cinnamon fragrances permeated deep through to the yolk. The hard-boiled egg was not overcooked and the yolk although fully cooked was still moist. 

Now, the BBQ Lamb ribs.....they were mouth wateringly amazing delicacies! Meat from lamb ribs ends were simply seasoned and roasted. Each piece had a crisp exterior, a thin layer of melting fat, and a thin sliver of gamey meat. 

On to the entree, I got the Ginger duck Noodle soup. First, it was a very large bowl of steaming hot noodles in a spicy broth with large pieces of duck and cabbage, topped with sesame seeds  (You can request mild, medium or hot). The noodles had the perfect chew, and importantly, maintained their texture in the hot broth throughout the next 20 minutes that it took us to devour our large meal! The duck offered in the soup was well seasoned were a great "side" to the noodles which was the star of the dish! 

A great find! Satisfyingly delicious food, fast service, gray prices! I'm a fan and I can't wait to go back again!

************************
Addendum: It was so good after our first visit that my friend and I went back the next day. This time, we got the lamb skewers for appetizers, along with the cucumber salad and scallion pancakes. 
The lamb skewers were styled like Singaporean satay (minus the peanut sauce), with small alternating pieces of meat and fat. It had great flavor, albeit requiring a little more chewing to break through it. 
I initially expected the scallion pancakes to be similar to ones I've had at korean restaurants. But I was wrong! Imagine a south indian roti prata but with scallions in it. That was exactly how it was for me, thin with flaky, crispy layers. 
For entrees, I got the pork Spare Rib noodle soup. The broth was clear and not spicy at all. The bowl was made up of the same amazing noodles as we had the day before, but the bowl was also filled with pork ribs and neck bones! (that's when you know the broth is gonna be good!). 
We're so glad we went back for a second meal. Alas, I don't live in SF, but I'll be back when I visit SF again!
author: Kel Vin W.

description: Closer to a 3.5.  Having come here several times now, the best thing we've had here is the beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup.  Other thing dishes we've tried that are decent but not outstanding include the dan dan noodles, couple's delight, and pork intestine noodle soup.  Pretty affordable and fast service.
author: Simon L.

description:
This is an amazing place for Sichuan-style spicy noodle! And yes, as the name suggests, get the "Chong Qing Xiao Mian" (It means "little noodle from Chong Qing", Chong Qing is the largest city in Sichuan Province.)

If you get this numbing sensation after eating the noodle, don't worry. You are not poisoned. 

The sauce comes with "Sichuan peppercorn". It's super fragrant and it also induces this numbing sensation. Perfectly normal. And you'll learn to love it soon.

Besides the noodle, their side dishes are also very authentic and reasonably priced.

The service is super slow though. I've been here 5 times, and it always takes forever to order and pay, even when the restaurant isn't busy. So make sure you know what you want and order everything in one go. Once your waiter/waitress leaves, good luck getting their attention again.

That said, the food is very good and this has become one of my go-to place when I'm near Chinatown.
author: Joseph L.

description:
This place is pretty good! The dan dan noodles were just spicy enough to be tasty, but not overbearing. The noodles were exactly the right firmness I like, and the meat was well-seasoned and paired nicely with the broth. The cabbage was sort of tasteless, but I'm not big on cabbage in the first place so take it with a grain of salt.

But the real star here was the pork belly on the back of the menu. It positively fell apart in my mouth and while I couldn't identify the sauce it was coated in, I can safely say it was phenomenal. It also came on a bed of chopped mushrooms which were conveniently coated in the same sauce -- great to help you sate your appetite for it after you're done!

The green onion pancakes were kinda disappointing though. They didn't have much flavor on their own and didn't come with any toppings or sauces. Texture was flaky enough, but I was overall left wanting with that dish.

The service was quick, too! My only complaint other than the pancakes was the place was hot as hell; a box fan circulating the air wouldn't have gone unappreciated. Overall, this place is pretty solid. Nothing incredible, but it's a reasonably-priced place to grab a tasty lunch in FiDi.
author: Shawn W.

description:
Pictures are very good, in-store decoration is attractive, menu is gorgeous. It feels like it should be a place that offers really great Authentic Chinese foods. So I tried their famous "Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle", "Slingle Cooked Noodle Soup". First of all, they use a looooot of cooking oil. Hey I know for sure authentic Chinese food sometimes aren't famous by its healthiness, but that is one of the reason that makes it delicious. But in this case, it does not. The flavor is mild. Sure I feel it somewhat spicy but it's not those kind of delicious-spicy. Besides, I found there are too much noodle in the bowl. I am kind of a meat-person, so I would like more meat in the bowl. Or even more vegetable in the bowl would make me happy. But there is just too much noodle in it and it takes over the entire bowl.
Overall, I didn't really enjoy what I ordered. But I will still give it a try next time and try to order something else. I have been to the other two branches of this store (one in SF, one in Fremont) and they all tasted good.
author: Yanzhong L.

description: Liked the decorations inside, really reminds me of the street restaurants in China. I ordered the fish noodles and my bf ordered the beef noodles. The beef noodle broth were a bit oily, but that's how they make this dish in China. The fish noodles were more on the lighter side but very flavorful. Very authentic.
author: Tracy F.

description:
Fast service! Everything came out fresh and hot in less than 5 mins!!! I ordered:

Cold jellybean - ate everything in 2 mins. Flavorful! Spicy, a little sour just my liking! 
Spicy beef with tripe (husband and wife dish) - legit spicy and tender at the same time.
Sweet and sour pork ribs - soft and flavors are great! Very well cooked through
Pickle beef noodle soup - beef is super tender, falls apart! Melts in your mouth. Lack pickle flavor, preggo lady needs her pickle cabbage! 
Pickle fish soup with rice to go - having it for dinner lol


I couldn't finish anything except the jellybean, took everything to go. Was charged 1.20 for to go containers and one bag  Total $41, with tips $46 not bad considering I got lunch and dinner.
author: Kris J.

description: Good for lunch, not expensive, very tasty, spicy! Good for one to two person. Try the CQXM noodles as it's the restaurant name, I like it.
author: Tony S.

description: Small place that seats just 45 . It's super busy on this Sunday night. Just what I want on a windy and cold summer night in SF. Hot, spicy noodles yum, yum, yum. We had tin tin noodles and hot and sour spicy noodle soups. Very good once your taste buds become acclimated.
author: Susangela M.

description:
Tooooo spicy but tooooo delicious! I strongly recommend people like spicy to try this! 

I like the 虎皮青椒 very much! 重庆小面is also higher than my expectation.
author: Gigi L.

description: Skip the lines of tourists at House of Nanking and go next door to CQXM instead! The giant bowls of spicy, fresh noodle soups are a godsend on chilly SF nights. The noodles are really fresh and chewy, and the soup is flavorful and fiery without numbing your mouth for hours. The food also looks WAY spicier than it actually is, so don't be daunted!
author: Denise L.

description:
This place is quite authentic. Favorite Chinese noodle place in SF! 

The noodles are quite spicy, but so flavorful. I definitely discovered this place too late. All the options we tried were quite decent. The location also allows you to walk off your food coma by walking through Chinatown afterwards!
author: Julia C.

description:
DELICIOUS!
Authentic Chinese food. I loved the tub of chili oil on the table. Authentic numbing Sichuan pepper corns. Beef tendon was delicious. I wish this place was in Seattle. 
Super casual. Accepts credit cards.
author: Opal D.

description:
Any time a Chinese restaurant has more than 3 stars on Yelp, I take notice.

And my fellow Yelpers did not disappoint!  The bowls of noodles here are pretty solid.  I've had the tan tan noodles and the lamb noodles, both are good hearty options.  I'd prefer to have my noodles a bit chewier, but these aren't too mushy.  The broths also run a little on the salty side, so make sure to drink a lot of tea/water with your meal.

As good as it is going down, my stomach isn't one for spicy foods (I must be getting older).  I love the noodles, but at home I face an almost inevitable stomach ache.  It's (usually) worth it from time to time though!

Tips and Tricks
-Lamb noodles are less spicy, if you're looking out for that
-Affordable side dishes (though the noodle servings are pretty substantial)
-Gets pretty crowded at dinner (post work FiDi crowd and the locals)
author: Jessica L.

description:
Place - It is end of china town, close to italian street. Pretty many tables. And there are one lone tables, so good to eat with big group. Very clean than other chiness restaurant. Menu is easy to read and there are pictures of foods, so you can get better choice. 

Taste - No flavor!!!!! No flavor!!! I ordered tan tan noddle and spicy beef noddle. Both looked spicy but it was fine. But the noddles was terrible. It tasted nothing!! It doesn't mean taste is bad. It mean no flavor. I felt like I am eatting a noodle with hot water and pepper oil. Do u want to eat noddle with just hot water?? Of course not! I counldn't eat. I wasted my money and time. 

Service and Price - Service was soso. Price was not expensive but it didn't worth to pay for food herez
author: Da Won L.

description: One of the better and more authentic Chinese restaurants I've been to SF. Great if you like spicy food. Had the beef noodle soup and really enjoyed it. Can't wait to go back.
author: Gary H.

description:
Every dish is basically the same so the service is pretty fast. The noodles have a good boing-ness to it and is nicely spiced. The broth is not as ma-la as I expected and it's more of a after-taste ma-la but tasty nonetheless. My beef noodles came with ~3 pieces of meat and they were very tender and well-cooked. 

LOL also if you come in alone at a busy time and sit at a table for 4... be expected to share and or be asked to move to another table.
author: Lydia Z.

description: It made me feel like I had the most authentic chinese food ever. Simply delicious!!! We got in a little late but had the food served and hit out in time for the place to close at the closing time. Fast and on point!
author: Ovidiu T.

description: This spot satisfies my spicy noodle cravings, I literally go here at least 2 times a month.  If you love spicy, this is the place for you.  My go to's are the Dan Dan Noodles and Spicy Beef Noodle Soup.  When I have to work on the weekends, this is my trusted noodle place, since they are open 7 days a week (my trusty old Chinatown delicacies).  The portion, price, and quality is what makes this place so good.  Other than the spicy broth/sauce and the chewy noodles, the portions are large enough for 2 people or for 2 meals.  I swear, they must put something in their Dan Dan Noodles, it keeps me coming back all the time.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Spicy Sichuan food in a cozy interior is just what the doctor ordered on (yet another) rainy SF night.

Glad to finally swing by after eyeing this place for awhile. At around $9-10 for main dishes and $5 for appetizers, prices were very reasonable. The spiciness level was just right for me but I also love spicy food. You can always ask for a lower level of spiciness when you order!

 Couple's delight (夫妻肺片): 4.5/5. The app was well balanced between the pieces of beef, tendon and tripe. The chili oil was a good balance of numb and spiciness! 

Dandan noodles (担担面): 4/5. I've had this in China before and I've never had in such a soupy broth before. Other than that, the noodles were just the right amount of chewiness and the meat and spiciness were really great!

Spicy wontons (红油抄手): 4.5/5. The wontons are plentiful but pretty small. What they lack in size they make up for in flavor though. The chili oil and soup base seems to be very similar to the dandan noodles, which, once again is yummy but not quite authentic since this dish should really only be served with some spicy oil and not a broth.

Service was a bit slow because it was busy but otherwise everyone was nice enough. I'll definitely come back if I'm craving some spicy food!
author: Jason W.

description: I had the house cold noodle with beef tendon. I wish I'd gotten pork belly slices instead, but the meal was still amazing. Extremely flavorful and way too much food.
author: Dominick L.

description: We stumbled across this place in Chinatown and the food is amazing. We had the Tan Tan Noodles, Wuban Hot Dry Noodles, and Braised Beef and Rice.
author: Trivell M.

description:
Another yelp guided adventure through San  Francisco for my favorite foods. 

Food: 
The spicy and sour noodles were not what I expected to be flavored like at all. Not spicy at all not really sour too, just had that layer of oil Potato noodles never disappoint though . Bleh 2/5 

Tan Tan Noodles: Different to the Shanghai style. I didn't mind it, had a very strong peanut sauce to it which was yummy. The noodles were a bit on the soft side. 3/5

GuiLan Noodles : So so good. It was exactly the taste that I wanted, kinda wanted that kinda flavor inside my sour and spicy noodles. this was good though, gave a lot of flavor and the noodles tasted fresh too 5/5

Drunken Chicken : No drunken taste to it all, more so sesame and oil. Bleh 2/5 

Pickled Cucumber: Nothing special, wish it was more garlicky 3/5

Dumplings in Chili Soup : Not good , the meat was kinda weird... maybe it had gone bad? The soup that it was in was bland too, giving the dumplings no flavor at all. 1/5

Atmosphere: Really small space, but gives the whole "I'm actually in China" atmosphere. 

Service: They came to us when we called them, your typical Asian restaurant service.
author: Carol T.

description:
I love this place and food here! Has all my favorite dishes! 

Chili oil wonton, beef noodle soup, dan dan mein, etc. This place is great! 

Price is reasonable and service is great! Food comes out super fast. Great place for a lunch or a quick bite!
author: Kevin W.

description:
This place is perpetually popular. Came here on a Tuesday at 7:45 pm and there was a line of 2-3 parties ahead of us. The place is not that big, so naturally the line went out the door.

We were seated within 10 min so the wait wasn't bad. We ordered the beef noodle soup and the numbingly spicy chongqing mian, as well as beef tendons to start.

The beef tendons were the right balance of crispy and jelly-like, with yummy spices.

Overall: the food was good. I liked the beef noodle soup, and it had a good amount of beef, white radish, and vegetables.

However: there is only a slight difference between numbingly spicy and regular. I wish they had a choice of even more numbingly spicy for people who don't want to feel their mouths after! 

The chongqing mian also literally has nothing else besides noodles... so don't expect any toppings!
author: Julianna K.

description:
My sister told me about this place and she recommended me to go on a cold rainy day. We went there late afternoon on a freezing cold day, and it was perfect for some Szechuan spicy food. 

My all time favorite when I go to Szechuan restaurant is to order the scallion pancake. At this place, they sell it for around $4, which is pretty cheap in the area. It was definitely worth the price on its portion and the crispy texture. 

I ordered the Tan Tan Noodle and you can really taste the spices, not too spicy that your taste bud cannot taste any flavors. The portion size is huge and I have to share it with my sister. 

I also recommend getting the House Cold Noodle for $7.95 which is extremely delicious. I love the flavors and the coldness of the noodle. The portion size is HUGE, great for sharing unless you do not like share :P 

The service was okay, there was only one server at the time and we waited pretty long to get her attention in order to pay for the bill.
author: Judy M.

description: Food is good but they put 18% service charge without asking you. We only have 4 people and we went for lunch. This is freaking stupid.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy
Hot and spicy slinge noodles in a very spicy broth. Mostly broth and noodles but some cabbage and chicken I think.
author: Cheryl G.

description:
Delicious and authentic noodles!! My bf and I got both the Guilin noodles and spicy beef noodle. Both were 5 stars. The meat is very tender and portions are huge. You could probably feed two people with one dish of you also get side dishes.

Prices were so cheap - only $10.95 per bowl. I'm looking forward to coming back already.
author: Sophia H.

description: The food came out really quick after we ordered. My friends and I shared lamb skewers and steamed pork belly. Lamb skewers were really good, but be aware that they are spicy. Steamed pork belly melted in you mouth, however not worth $8. I had Tan Tan noodles which was good, but I don't think I'll be craving it anytime in the future.
author: Michael C.

description: This is a fantastic place for eats! We had a variety of appetizers, none of which disappointed. The Noodle were the crown heels here though. The Tan Tan Noodles were amazing, with heat but a very flavourful spice level. Could be asked to tame the heat as well. All in all, if you are looking for an authentic noodle and dining experience, give his place a try!
author: Jason Y.

description:
Delicious food. 
My gf and I both had the green onion cakes and the Tom Tom soup. 
It was filling, savory, and spicy. 
My favorite addition was a bowl full of chili paste at each table.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I knew this place was gonna be good when I sat at one of the tables and I saw a very tall jar of chili oil, the ones that are exactly what you would see at a noodle stand in Chengdu. 

I'm glad that the Chinatown in SF is getting more regional Chinese food beyond standard Cantonese/Toisan.

I ordered the "Wan Za Mian" which was a bowl of noodles with ground meat and salted chickpeas in hot broth. This. Was. FANTASTIC. 

The Sichuan peppercorn aroma was fragrant but not overpowering. Spice level could be more, but understandably a lot of tourists/Cantonese people aren't accustomed to eating Sichuan-level spicy. Chili fiends can ladle on that delicious chili oil at every table.

The broth was piping hot and seasoned quite well. It had a strong chickeny/pork flavor and just the right amount of MSG so that it wasn't too salty. This really hit all of my pleasure points.

Service is a bit gruff, but you'll be enjoying your noodles too much to care.
author: Gabriel H.

description:
It's freaking delicious! I love spicy food especially the Szechuan way. Chong Qing prefect their chili oil. Everything is pretty much cooked in their chili oil. So good. 

I ordered the Tan Tan noodles aka "dan dan mein". Chinese saying hella good, "Feichang hao chi"!! One of the best tan tan noodles I ever had. Wasn't too spicy, tasty and the noodle was cooked perfectly. Also the beef tendon in chili was yummy too but next time I would prefer the couples delight. A mix of everything. 

Services is friendly but a bit slow when they are super busy. The food comes out a bit slow as well. Try to come after 1:10 or before 12pm. Can't wait to come back and try everything else.
author: Sandy B.

description:
This place is amazing! For a long time I think Chong Qing Xiaomian (little noodle) is so under valued as a type of cuisine. Well, all Chinese cuisine styles are sort of under valued in the U.S.  except the Szechuan spicy food. To me, the Little Noodle is the Chinese alternatives of the Japanese Ramen and there are much more adventurous flavors to explore. 

I tried the duck little noodle at this place and it was so tasty and spicy for sure. Don't go there alone because you want to share with your friends the BBQ lamb skewers. Although the lamb skewer is the typical food in Beijing, not Chong Qing, this place cooks it so authentically.
author: Cecille C.

description:
The foundation to any dish is the noodles, or the 'noodz' as I like to say. I'd be dreaming about this place right now if it weren't for the noodles themselves. The basic requirement is they need to be chewy. If you have that, then you can't go wrong. Crappy sauce? That sucks, but at least you can keep on chewing. 
I ordered the Tan Tan Noodles. The ground meat out-flavors everything else in the dish. But the limp noodz...so soggy. I picked out the meat and left almost the entire bowl of noodles. What a waste of noodz.

The onion pancake on the other hand, I'm dreaming about that right now.
author: Elaine T.

description: I was looking for a place for lunch while exploring Chinatown, and found this place. The food was great. I got the green onion pancakes and pickled mustard green noodle soup. Yummy! (Just a warning, it's really spicy!)
author: Justin P.

description:
Another place to add to my legit Asian restaurants to eat in SF (which is quite a short list).  

I've been eyeing Chong Qing for many, many months just by looking at the pictures.  Lots of spicy goodness and yes, pig parts!  So on a cold night about a month ago, my wife and I went to Chong Qing by Uber and fought for a seat.  A very popular place, so be forewarned.  

We've had three different noodle soups, but the best so far is the spicy pig intestine soup.  Wow, the flavors are amazing.  Gwai lo, be careful:  it is spicy.  But amazingly enough, there's plenty of non Asians (usually brought by their Asian friends, boyfriends, girlfriends, etc) who brave the spicy broth to expand their Asian food experience.

The spicy pig intestine soup is truly amazing.  When we first went there, my wife got a sour type noodle soup.  She tried mine and over the meal, she kept dipping into my soup bowl and less of hers (hence the 2nd trip!).  The soup is so nicely flavored that I actually ate more of the soup before I realized I was orphaning the noodles.  The pig intestines were delicious as well.  They were not anemic by any sense and were boiled quite nicely.  Succulent would be a good description.  

We noticed too that many other people around us were ordering this specific dish.  Also the beef or lamb cumin sticks were also very popular as well.  That'll be on the table the next time!

Totally recommend this place if you like spicy, authentic Chinese noodle soup.  The best so far and reminds me of many places in the San Gabriel Valley in LA.
author: Bob K.

description:
Very good Szechuan food. Got the tan tan noodles and wuhan hot dry noodles. The latter is a unique regional dish that is a rare find in Chinese places in America although it wasn't completely authentic. It has a strong taste of peanuts but it wasn't bad. We also ordered the spicy wontons in chili sauce but thought it was an appetizer. It's more of an actual meal so bear that in mind. It was good too. 

I'd give it 5 stars but I've had better tan tan noodles in the US. Also it was a hot day in SF and since they didn't have AC, I was sweating my butt off. Needless to say it made eating the meal uncomfortable. Lukewarm tap water didn't help either. I'd be back though on a less scorching day
author: Jd H.

description: Spicy!! 3.5 stars! I love Taiwanese beef noodle soup and here I ordered the beef noodle soup with mustard greens. The spices are different and the chili oil can be overpowering, but the way the beef was braised was tender and just right. And it comes with a nice piece of daikon, yum
author: Raya K.

description:
If you like noodles and like the mala spicy feeling which gives that numbing mouthfeel, this place is a must for you. The tan tan noodles are the most common thing to get here which is basically a noodle soup with a spicy oily mala broth. The noodles are chewy and plentiful and come with ground meat and cut up cabbage. My personal favorite is the noodles with peas and meat sauce which is very similar to the tan tan noodles but with peas added to the meat mixture. Both broths are identical and you get about the same amount of soup and cabbage. The flavor of the broth is pretty intense which is a treat if you're into that mala flavor. The mala flavor isn't as much spicy as it is a mild mouth feel of your tongue going slightly numb but not enough that Ye painful or you can't taste the food.

I highly suggest getting an appetizer or two especially if you're with others. The tendon is a popular appetizer that comes in thin slices of beef tendon drenched in chili oil. Despite the heavy oil, it's really not spicy and has a delicate flavor to it. The cumin lamb is also incredible and I highly suggest this if you can only order one appetizer. These lamb skewers have a nice toasted cumin flavor are are super tender. The flavor is intense and a must have for anyone that likes lamb or cumin.

There's also non spicy options for those looking for a less adventurous meal. I've tried almost every item here and pretty much every option makes for a great meal. Well priced, generous in portions and bustling with unique flavors, this place will be on my go to list for time to come.
author: James K.

description: We tried their spicy numbing beef tendon, noodles w/ peas meat sauce, and braised beef with rice - and unfortunately, the noodles were the disappointment of the meal.  The noodles were slightly overcooked, too salty, and overall lacking in flavor - for this particular dish, Spicy Queen on Geary has a highly superior version.  The spicy numbing beef tendon was on the good side, and is definitely worth ordering, although Little Sichuan in San Mateo serves a superior version.  The best dish of the 3 was definitely the braised beef with rice - beef was pretty tender and full of flavor.  Since it's a small place, there will be a wait - if you're in the area, it can be an ok place to go for a meal of convenience on the way to someplace else, but it's definitely not a "for the food" destination place.
author: Lyn Y.

description: Solid lunch spot the noodles for my taste it's spicy but not over the top,you can add my hot chili sauce/oil that they had table side..I would say for the price it definitely has good value,the noodles taste fresh and the portions are good..the beef noodle I had on my first visit was tender and tasted good,on my second visit I had a pork broth but all vegetable noodle with daikon radish very good..
author: jonathan h.

description:
This place is my favorite noodle place in all of San Francisco... maybe even in the entire world! It's so delicious here, I come here at least a few times a month! 

My go-to is the mustard green beef noodle soup. The noodles are a good consistency - I like that they're a balance of firm and chewy. The beef is oh so good, soft, slightly chewy, and spicy. The soup and flavors are very spicy, but thankfully the restaurant gives you a small jug of (much needed) water. All of this deliciousness for less than $10! 

We usually get a cucumber salad too on the side. We've noticed that the taste has differed each time we've gotten it, sometimes more/less spicy or salty or sour. Still good enough for us to get it again and again though.
author: Christine L.

description:
Updated to 4 stars after a great experience where they got our orders right and actually added toppings in! The Guilin rice noodles are to die for. And because they added enough toppings, it balances out the numbing spice and actually tastes great. No bean sauce sos was needed this time.

Despite the mediocre service and the crowd, we were very happy campers. Can't wait to come back to test consistency.
author: Robin Y.

description: Tan Tan, Ginger Beef soup, and the Duck Ginger dish were all amazing... according to my travel companions. I have to admit that I am not a fan of Chinese food, but I can usually find at least one thing that I will like not matter where we go. EVERYONE else at the table RAVED about their food.  Literally wouldn't stop talking about their food.   I will tell you that I really enjoyed the steamed rice  ;-)   But seriously they all LOVED their food, so I had to post and share their love of this place. Everyone that helped us there was very nice and helpful.
author: Natasha B.

description: Delicious!! Great atmosphere for lunch with friends! The food was brought out quickly and tasted amazing! Canned soft drinks are available to purchase. The location is small but the tables are set up to accommodate many people comfortably. The restaurant is very clean. They are unable to take Discover cards.
author: JoJo F.

description:
This place is so (numbingly) spicy and so delicious! A bowl of delicious noodles will cost you around $10 and leave you super satisfied and spiced out.

We got the tan tan noodles and the beef noodles and both were equal in spice level - level numb spicyness deliciousness! We also got the scallion pancakes and they were really crispy and thin.

Service isn't amazing but go for the food. Highly recommend this place for all those days you crave a big bowl of spicy noodles that will leave you sniffing of happiness.
author: Kelly Z.

description:
Price is reasonable for the noodle but a bit expensive for the small dishes.
Food is ok. Services is ok. place is small and crowed. Not very clean or comfortable sitting. 
Came here because of the 4 stars on yelp as well as other advertisement. it however is only a OK place for me.
author: Xbo Z.

description:
Chong Qing Xiao Mian (重慶小面)

Strolling on the streets of the oldest & largest Chinatown in the world, we waited at a crowded small restaurant with the locals for a spot to eat authentic Szechuan (四川) cuisine.  

The pictures don't do justice. Needless to say, I still dream of their Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup  (老壇酸菜牛肉麵).  

Ambience
No frills & not fancy. Most likely you will have to share a table with others because space in China Town is limited & lots of people want a bite of their dishes. 

Wait time
We came on a weekday, afternoon. There is a wait list, after signing in, we waited for about 15 minutes 

Taste 
You can ask them to adjust the spice level. Tan Tan noodle was mouth numbing, but flavor was plain. Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup was delicious. Beef is tender. BBQ Lamb skewer was juicy & slightly fatty & yummy. Chili Oil Wonton is standard, on the oily side. 


What we ordered 

BBQ Lamb Skewer (炭烤羊肉串) 
Tan Tan Noodle (擔擔麵) 
Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup (老壇酸菜牛肉麵) 
Chili Oil Wonton (紅油抄手)
author: C C.

description: This was my first time trying a Chinese noodle soup (not counting wonton soup or chow mein). It was actually really tasty. I got the Spicy Beef Bowl and my lady got the Tan Tan Bowl. The Tan Tan was a tab bit spicier than the one I got. Both bowls are actually really huge. The noodles in the Tan Tan soaked up ALL the broth. I've never seen that before. My broth was still there till I was done. The Beef in the Bowl I got was super soft. Really delicious. Both bowls were. We also got the sweet and sour pork. The meet was kinda rough. Not soft at all. I wish I got a bowl of rice to go with it. Service was ok. Not bad but not that great either. Either way, is definitely return to this place. Anything is better than Pho lol
author: Maikell B.

description: Had the tan tan noodles. Really great, 7.95 for that much food is AMAZING in this city. Would go again to try their whole menu.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Came in around 6pm with no reservation and were seated immediately. The service is prompt, polite and efficient, but in the same vein as traditional Asian restaurants, lacks warmth. The decor is clean, wooden and no frills. While we were there, a raving homeless man came in, and was shooed out by the waitstaff. 
We ordered the tan tan noodles and spicy numbing beef tendon and a cold noodle dish. The cold noodles were the least spicy of the 3 dishes, with a slightly sweet flavor, and acidic vinegar tang. The noodles were cooked to the right firmness, and retained a slightly firm texture, but were not really al dente. The beef tendon was drenched in chili oil and dried chilis. As such, it was very spicy, but delicious. The texture was gelatinous and chewy. 
The tan tan noodles were my favourite. The minced pork was peppery, while the soup was oily and spicy. The noodles were cooked perfectly. All in all, a delicious meal at very reasonable prices.
author: Su L.

description: If you like scallion pancakes you will love theirs. Best I've ever eaten! Had the won ton in chicken broth, excellent. Tons of won ton and very flavorful soup. Place is very small but had no problem getting a table for 4 on a Thursday evening. Service was very good, friendly staff.
author: Scott G.

description:
I've walked past this place a bunch of times and it's always been relatively crowded. Today, I found out why. I really wanted some spicy Asian food that was mildly healthy but comforting. This hit the spot in terms of authenticity, taste, portions, and service.

I went at around 8PM, so there wasn't a line, but most of the tables were filled. We were seated right away, and the server speaks both Chinese and English, so it's pretty authentic in that sense. 

Onto the food! I got the tan tan (or dan dan) noodles which is pretty popular noodles with some kind of minced meat with fermented bean flavor - which sounds strange but was pretty tasty. The spiciness level was perfect for me and really hit the spot in terms of nostalgia for that numbing spicy food. Noodles were cooked well, and portions were pretty big and filled up a hungry person. My friend got the spicy beef noodle soup and the beef was so delicious he didn't want to share any with me haha. It's very tender and everything is well seasoned if not a little bit more on the salty side. 

The service was very prompt and responsive but it is a small shop so that could be why. Will definitely be coming back here to try more noodles! :)
author: Michelle L.

description: Always authentic. Real Sichuan cooking.  Crowded, but that's a good thing. Service is fast though at time abrupt.
author: Matt B.

description: Not a bad spot in SF Chinatown to sit and grab a quick lunch. The noodles are very good, broth is rich and the portion is very large. But the dishes are quite oily and they put a lot of sauces on it to make it taste good. The floor is also very sticky and the lighting isn't great. This is a 3.5 for me but I would recommend the noodles.
author: Junda P.

description:
Perfect place to go when you're craving mouth numbing spicy noodles!

We got the tan tan noodles and the spicy beef noodle soup.

Both came out quick and steaming hot. The service was perfect for what I was expecting - you may have to be more assertive than usual!

Perfect level of spicy for me - where I can I feel the burn, yet I still want more. Pretty reasonable prices. I will definitely be coming back here to try the different dishes
author: Will Y.

description:
Good good.

I think its like all spicy soup noodles. Tasted really unhealthy. Just the way I like it :) Food wasn't that spicy, but they have this chili oil container. So you could dump in a bunch if your into that.

The tables are tiny. Pretty sure they're meant for like two people, but they sit four at them instead. You'll bump some elbows but if your lonely and need human contact, this is the place to go!

Not a tonna meat. So maybe not the best if your protein deficient.

Next to Quickly. If thats still popular.

But seriously, solid place. Would eat again. A lot. Pretty cheap. Good.
author: Adrian Y.

description: This place was unassuming, but really good!  I had the wohan dried noodle.  It was spicy, but not so much that I couldn't taste the other flavors.  I hope I have time to return!
author: William R.

description: Used to like this place for their noodles. As the other reviews said, their dishes are not as good as their noodles. Don't order their Chinese crepe, cause it has nothing to do with the traditional Chinese street food "Jian Bing"(crepes). The crepe they serve was just crepe rolled "Fuqi Feipian"(a Sichuan dish of beef offal). Felt being deceived.
author: Emily Y.

description:
I'm born and raised in Chongqing, China. This place is not authentic at all.  They have spicy oil mixed with soy oil sauce, excuse me????

The noodle broth tastes extremely salty...It's definitely misrepresentative to my hometown flavor.

I asked for extra spicy oil but they put pickled pepper water to "spice it up", which doesn't work and makes everything taste sour as pickles. That is not what I ordered! 

I'm very disappointed about this place. Not authentic, not truthful! Bringing bad names to hometown cuisine.
author: Myron L.

description:
I remember stopping by this place a while back, but was so tired. Stopped by again today when passed by a few friends who were about to have dinner.

It really hit the spot. Got the Wu Tan (?) Dry Noodle and the pork belly. The noodle dish doesn't come w/ any meat so this complemented it perfectly. The peppercorn had a nice numbing finish to it. It's a different kind of spicy. Pork belly in that chili oil was great and the cilantro added a nice refreshing taste to it.
author: James N.

description: A must try in San Francisco. Not your average beef noodle soup, herb is a bit strong for some but I personally love it. Service is fast, food's fresh..
author: Steven C.

description:
*Sigh* 

I had this place bookmarked for Tan Tan Noodles for so long, and I left so disappointed.

The wait on a Sunday at 7pm was pretty non-existent.  We were seated within 5 minutes of arriving.  Service is very fast here, so the tables turn over fairly rapidly.

For dinner, two of us split the Tan Tan Noodles, Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodles, cucumber salad, and "steamed vegetable."  Both noodle dishes tasted OK but certainly didn't live up to expectations.  They're both really more of noodle soups - albeit with a spicy oil broth - than they are coated noodle dishes - which means, you lose a lot of the flavor when the "sauce" is so liquidy that it slips right off the noodles.  In addition, both noodle dishes tasted almost exactly the same.  The Tan Tan Noodles were slightly more vinegar-y and included ground pork, but otherwise they were nearly identical dishes....and neither was very spicy.  

The steamed greens - i.e. steamed pea shoots in some kind of "sauce" - were pretty bland.

The cucumber salad, however, was amazing.  We ended up getting two orders of that.

Overall, the food was a let-down and the restaurant is pretty small/crowded and smells super strongly of the kitchen - which is very open to the restaurant - so I don't think I'll be back.
author: Tay H.

description: While we were strolling around Chinatown, we checked Yelp to look for a restaurant and this had some amazing reviews. There were lots of people waiting outside. After waiting for 30-40 minutes, we were seated. The seating are is small but t the service was pretty efficient. We ordered tan tan noodles and lamb skewered. Food arrived fast. Noodles were cooked perfect, broth was spicy and flavorful. Lamb skewers tasted great. Food was too hot for me but I was enjoying it despite sweating profusely :). We came again next day for lunch. It's a must try place in Chinatown. No frills, just awesome food.
author: Ruchi S.

description:
While it's probably good for many, it wasn't good for me.  I didn't know that so many of their dishes would have a peanut based sauce or soup.  So anyone with peanut allergies....BEWARE.

My first option was the tan tan noodles, but they make the soup base with peanuts.  My backup was the pork bone broth noodle soup which turned out to be delicious.  The soup was flavorful, comforting, and had the taste as if simmered for hours.  We also ordered the hot dry noodle.  The dish normally comes with a peanut sauce but the waitress told us that they could leave it off.  The dish was okay and I'm sure better with the peanut sauce.  The noodles tasted like it was topped with hot sauce, possibly sesame sauce, and chopped green onions.  It'll cost you if you want to take your leftovers with you - $0.30/container and $0.10/bag.

It was a clean restaurant but service was an issue but I guess expected at a Chinese restaurant.  There was one waitress who was seating people, but talking on her cell phone instead of taking orders.  Then you had the other waitress with the sour face and looked pissed anything you asked for something or she would just ignore you. Do note, if you have questions about the menu, there is a language gap. 

Expect a wait if you go during lunch.  We skipped coming here the first time because the line was out the door.  There were tables our second visit after 1pm.
author: Nicole S.

description: My partner was so excited to return to her old stomping ground in San Fran but our first meal in town was just okay. We ordered a few appetizers to start with; the spare ribs were tasty, the pot stickers tasted fresh and the green onion pancakes were both of our faves. Unfortunately, the Wuhan hot dry noodle was a big let down; it just tasted weird and we couldn't even finish a quarter of it. We ended up taking our left overs to go so we could give them away to a homeless person, and we later realized they charged us $0.60 for a container. I will say that the service was decent.
author: Lisa G.

description: First time being here, the line is quite long (about 35mins) but it is quite worth it. The noodles were yummy and the lamb skewers were tasty too. The lamb was very tender and juicy. However, I'd say the noodle could use a bit more flavor, to be more authentic. Overall, pretty good!
author: Sarah N.

description:
Its toxic that this place is located right down the street from my home. Every time i pass Chong Qing I find myself struggling to fight the urge of going in and ordering a bowl of noodles. Ive come here multiple times now and I've tasted 4 items on the menu and so far EVERYTHING that I've tasted has been delicious!

Numbing spicy noodles, Tan Tan Noodles, Spicy beef noodle soup, and fried dumplings. I can tolerate a lot of spiciness and everything that I've tasted here (minus the dumplings) seems to have just the right amount of spiciness. No.. im not refilling my cup of ice water 5 times to extinguish the flames on my tongue, instead I'm sitting there thoroughly enjoying every chopstick full of noodles i put into my mouth. I really enjoy the Tan Tan noodles the most because the ground pork on top adds the perfect amount of flavor into each bite.
I know im going to continue coming here especially because its almost always chilly in the city! With that said, I suggest that anyone who enjoys spice+noodles+authentic food pays a visit. :)
author: Samee M.

description:
Went back to try some new items!

Spicy Ginger Duck Noodles: Pretty good! Duck was tender and flavors were amazing as usual
Sweet & Sore Short Ribs: Decent, it goes well with all the spicy sauces you will be eating!
Spicy Garlic Pork Belly: MUST ORDER. Favorite appetizer! The flavors are very good, it has some wine, sweetness and spicy!

Will come back and try their dry noodles next time.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Hole in the wall? Little to no English? Authentic as f Chinese food? You can bet your sweet bippy that I'm there!

During our annual Community Manager's conference in San Francisco (where Yelp was born!), Mike B, Kimberly S, and I went venturing out to quench our thirst for some good Asian food (since we basically eat nothing but Vietnamese, Korean, and Chinese when we're back home in the DMV). We found Chong Qing Xiao Mian on Yelp, and it sounded right down our alley, so off we went!

We tried a myriad of things, including their Tan Tan Mien (awesome, spicy, and delicious), the spicy wontons (kind of listed as an appetizer, but a HUGE portion -- quite similar to the Tan Tan Mien). We got the cucumber salad as well, which honestly wasn't my favorite as the pieces are cut enormously which made them a little bit difficult to eat. They were SUPER garlicky too, which I actually loved. We also tried the sweet and sour spare ribs (delicious, super tender and sweet), as well as their steamed vegetable, which happened to be bok choy.

As Kimberly S notes in her review, the food was excellent, and the service was just about what you'd expect. The food came out quickly and it was all really good, but we had to ask for just about everything -- water refills, more napkins, tea, sauce, etc. Since we were seated so close to the server's station where they kept things, we eventually just started fetching things for ourselves.

But! That being said, the food was excellent and the price point can't be beat (especially in a city like SF!) We spent $50 on dinner for three of us, but ordered enough for 5, so you can't really beat that ratio, lol. I still had a great meal with great friends for a great price, and so for that, Chong Qing Xiao Mian gets four glowing stars.
author: Gretchen F.

description:
The food is so-so.  No way the noodles are hand-thrown.  They are way too thin and uniform, obviously pushed through a die.  

PLUS!  They double charged me. They spoke English fine when they thought I was calling to order, but once I asked for a refund... They proceeded to hang up on me 4 times when I called back.  I do not speak Mandarin, and I understand there could be a language barrier, but they did not grab a worker that could speak with me.  I was not belligerent, and nor was this an error with a split bill, I paid the whole tab.  I wonder how many people get hosed by them.  I had to call Wells Fargo to dispute the charge.
author: Frank R.

description:
My friend and I came here based on another friend's recommendation. We both ordered the Tan Tan noodles. This was my friend first time trying Szechuan style noodles. I had tried Szechuan hot pot before and I know about the numbing spice. 

Tan tan noodles: The noodles were perfectly cooked. It was a little chewy and al dente. It kind of reminds me of ramen noodles but different a little. The pork had some flavor to it but the highlight of the dish is the numbing spice. After a few spoonsful of noodles and meat, the spice hits you. It's spicy yet it numbs your mouth, tongue and some of your taste buds. If you are not used to it or familiar with it, it might an unpleasant surprise for you, like my friend. My friend did add some more spice to it that was on the table for more flavor. This noodle dish can be a personal preference if you are not into the numbing spice. I do think that the dish is authentic and taste great. The portion was a good amount for the price you pay for as well.

Green onion pancakes- we got some to share and it was really good! I'm so glad we saved it to eat with our noodles. It helps count down the spice with the saltiness of the pancakes. It was nice and buttery and a bit flaky. It was pretty damn good!

The restaurant is on the smaller scale. They have one long table in the middle of the room and you might just sit at that table with strangers next to you. It's a home type of feel restaurant.
author: Ellen V.

description:
Mostly good dishes with a few duds. Ordering food requires being strategic bc many of the dishes contain the same numbing spicy sauce so not only is my mouth numb, but my taste buds get bored from the lack of variety. 

Noms that I like:
Green onion pancake
Couples delight
Cold noodle
Beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup

Gets busy for weekday lunch and you might have to wait. Takeout automatically incurs a charge of .60 for container and 0.10 for the bag. Service is alright , but may be a bit slow during peak hours.
author: Judy C.

description:
I get cravings for the Tan Tan Noodles. I first tried it when my bf brought it home in a take-out container, and ate it again in the restaurant this week. The take-out version had more broth and it was more watered down, which I prefer. At the restaurant, the broth was heavier and there was less of it. The flavor was amazing nonetheless, but I couldn't drink any of the broth because it was too oily/strong. I'm guessing the consistency of the broth varies occasionally? We also ordered steamed veggies and couple's delight, which were just average to me.

I made one loop looking for parking on a Monday evening and settled with free street parking around 6:30 PM a 4 minute walk away. At the restaurant, there was no wait. I was seated immediately, even though I was still waiting for someone. The food came quickly, but it was difficult getting the bill because the servers were busy. Despite the slow service in getting the bill, I'll be back for those Tan Tan Noodles!
author: Stephanie C.

description: My short trip into San Francisco was definitely a great experience. I was spoiled with so many great options for Chinese food, and at such a wide range, it was so great to just be able to pick whatever I liked. I stumbled upon this small noodle house on my walk around China town and decided to give it a try. I was sat within ten minutes despite it being very busy. I tried their tea egg for the first time and although the color isn't necessarily appealing, it was dark brown, it was amazingly delicious. Nice and salty but not too salty! I had their spicy beef noodle soup with pickled mustard greens and it was a delight. It had enough spice to kick and caused a little bit of a numbing effect but it wasn't terribly spicy. The noodles were cooked well, the beef was tender, soft and juicy. Loved this place and definitely recommend for anyone going to San Francisco.
author: Blu M.

description: i am a noodle whore.  I dont discriminate, I like them all, some more than others.  This chinese noodle house located in SF chinatown area has a plethora of noodle dishes.  I ordered the name sake dish and it did not disappoint.  Tons of chili oil, which is exactly what I would order myself.  Portions were decent, prices were decent.  Can get busy, but turn over is somewhat quick.  Would come back again.
author: Michael L.

description: My cousin and I ordered the Tan Tan Noodles, Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, and the spicy wontons. The portions here are big, which is nice. I think the food is made properly - Szechuan style, but it was a little too greasy for my taste. The beef in the Spicy Beef Noodle soup was yummy and tender. However, I'm inclined to think of the "soup" more as a sauce because it was too greasy and condensed to drink as a soup. Service was generally friendly, but I had to wave the waitress down (who passed our table twice with the teapot open - indicating a need to refill) for someone to re-fill our tea. Note to the unwary, Szechuan food is spicy!
author: Annie L.

description:
It was a cold, gloomy day in SF, and my friend recommended this place to warm us up! He asked if I liked spicy food, and said if I do, I will love this place!

We came a little before 12 and luckily, there were a couple tables still open before the lunch rush! I looked over the yelp reviews and ordered the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup. The red soup is a bit intimidating, but I actually really enjoyed it! It was not the spicy hot I'm used to, it was more of a... tingly hot.. if that makes sense lol

The soup was tasty & the noodles were delicious! On a spice level, for myself, I'd rate it a 6/10, will definitely be back to try the rest of their dishes!
author: Carrie L.

description:
We recently came here with a big group, as part of a family trip in San Francisco.

The foods were very authentic, with a focus on noodles. In particular, I had cross-bridge noodles (过桥米线), which was full of yummy varieties (e.g. pickled veggies and tea egg) and only priced at around $14.

Last but not least, I got freshly made fruit juice, which was a delightful supplement to my meal.
author: Lancy L.

description:
I'm all for Szechuan food, no matter how spicy it is, I'm all for it.

Except... Chong Qing Xiao Mian didn't quite cut it for me. Maybe I came on an off day but it just did not punch me in the face like most Szechuan cuisine does. Generally, everything here is spicy and you want to get the noodles for obvious reasons. I got the spicy beef noodle soup and it was good, but not great. They might have overdosed on the chili oil because my stomach was coated in 3 layers of chili oil and writhing afterward. 

I really wanted to enjoy the food here, but the sheer amount of chili oil and other oils made my food a little difficult to eat, and this is coming from someone who eats Szechuan food with very little problem. 

Like I said, maybe I came on an off day, because spicy beef noodle soup is one of my favorite foods so it's hard for me to not enjoy it.
author: Derek T.

description:
YAY! Finally an authentic place that serves Ma-La dishes. As a spicy lover, I expected their food to be spicy, but it wasn't spicy for me at all. The food not being too spicy is not a bad thing.  In fact, it allows for those who can't handle spicy enjoy the numbing goodness with just a hint of spice!

I ordered the Chong Qing Xiao Mian and i'm so happy!  I'm going to come back here next time to try the Hot & Sour noodles.
author: Emi K.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon. This place is somewhat new, I believe it replaced a Vietnamese restaurant. Service here is fairly quick, there was no wait before I got seated and your bowl of noodles come out fairly quick after you order them.  If you don't like spicy food, then I would highly recommend you going elsewhere. About 90% of the menu items are spicy, where only some appetizer, and only one noodle/rice option as the main entree is non-spicy. Personally, I love spicy food so no complaint from me but I do wish there was more non-spicy option for your friends and family who can't handle spice. Some of the non-spicy options they had were actually crossed out on the menu and not offered anymore.
