I had the spicy beef noodle soup and I loved it. The beef was tender and had the texture of beef stew and I also personally love the noodles they use ! The noodles were somewhat similar to the skinny/thin ramen noodles that you get at certain ramen shops. Additionally, wowowowowww... I usually order medium spicy everywhere I go but this broth had me dying slowly haha. 

All in all, I really enjoyed the food here, would definitely come back.
author: Jenny N.

description:
I can't remember when this place opened, but I distinctly remember what lured me to this restaurant was the outside design of the store. It stood in stark contrast with the rest of the stores on Kearny, even know, I think it has a unique look that I'm afraid puts the other stores to shame. I came here numerous times since it opened, and have tried most of the items on the menu that enticed me. There's almost always a line outside whenever I walk by, which is probably a testament to the quality of the food here in comparison to other places in Chinatown. 

On a recent Sunday evening, I came here with a friend because we're craving for Sichuan cuisine. When we walked in, there was a small line, which was not too bad at all considering it was a Sunday evening. Eventually, we got seated and deliberated over what to order, since we already had most of the dishes here. I wanted something spicy, so I got the Tan Tan Noodle. We also decided to get the Sichuan Style Steamed Pork Belly with Pickled Mustard as an appetizer, since we never had it before. It seems that since the last time I've been here, they've added the plum juice to the menu. Intrigued, I decided to order the plum juice as well. 

First, the waitress served us the pork belly and my plum juice. When I got a small taste of the pork belly, I was really surprised. It was really tender and the meat just seems to melt when in your mouth upon contact. Honestly, I think it was better than the other appetizers that I've had here. There were some small mushrooms or bamboo shoots on the bottom of the bowl, and they went nicely with the pork belly. The plum juice was good, I never had plum juice before so I can only say that it was sweet and it's in line with what I expected when I ordered the drink. At last, our respective main dishes came out, and I dived into the dish. To my slight dissapointment, they didn't give me as much broth for the Tan Tan noodle as I'd like since the broth only went halfway up the bowl. Nonetheless, I went for the noodles and the meat. The ground pork was finely minced and went great with the noodles and the cabbage. Since there wasn't much broth, I had to eat quickly before the noodles soaked up the broth. The dish started off as not really spicy, but as you dig deeper toward the bottom of the dish, it gets progressively spicier. 

All in all, I was very satisfied with my meal here, similar to my past visits. I'm certainly a fan of this place, and I keep coming back here because this is only of the few great places to get Sichuanese food in Chinatown, and I really enjoy the variety of dishes here, spicy and non-spicy. I think the only con I could think of is that this place is always somewhat crowded whenever I actually want to come in to eat, but it is what it is. I hope they keep adding more dishes to the menu, and I can say that I always look forward to coming back here. This place is a solid five in my opinion.
author: Nelson X.

description:
Swung by for a late lunch around 2.30p on a Saturday and the place was packed!  We love Sichuan food and this seemed very authentic so we were excited to try it out, especially given the HUGE canister of chili sauce on every table.

Cucumber appetizer:  Simply smashed with garlic and a bit of cilantro.   Good rendition and a nice refreshing contrast to the spicy dishes we tried.  Good garlic flavor but not as strong as other places.  4/5

Spicy garlic pork belly appetizer:  I get this at almost every Sichuan restaurant and this did not disappoint.  Slightly small portion for $10 but very nice flavor with good heat.  5/5

Tan tan noodles:  Not sure what the hype is about these noodles as they were fine but not as good as the beef noodle soup.  Served with thin noodles, as spicy as it looked.  3.5/5

Spicy beef noodle soup:  smooth flavor with a bit of spice and a hint of sweetness.   Tender braised beef chunks and daikon completed the dish.  Not the most amazing rendition but one I would happily eat any day.  5/5

Overall the dishes were not as spicy as we thought (we're big spice lovers) but we left feeling quite satisfied and are looking forward to coming again to try more dishes on the menu.
author: Alice C.

description:
Asian food is my jam. When I saw this new restaurant pop up, I knew I had to try it. 

If you like Asian, spicy, and yummy, this is the prefect joint for you. 

Scallion pancake: doesn't come with sauce but doesn't really need it. I always eat it with sugar like fried dough. Something I've been doing since I was a kid. 

Cucumber salad: the dishes we ordered were spicy so it was nice to have a side of something cool and refreshing. Pretty garlicky but I like that. 

Tan Tan Mien: lots of noodles combined with lots of tasty ground meat in a spicy sauce. Very authentic as most other reviewers have remarked. More meat than veggies though. 

Beef brisket on rice: not spicy and so good! Meat was tender. 

Price is reasonable. Portions are good. There was only 1 server and though she was trying her best - I felt she could use some help.
author: Emily Y.

description:
I had all but given up on authentic Chinese food in SF until I tried Chong Qing Xiao Mian. I didn't think there would be a wait but at 7:15pm on Friday, the line looked intimidating. We grabbed some drinks around the corner and when we came back at 8:00pm, they had already called my name and skipped over us. But by then, there was only one group ahead of us.

When we were finally seated, we were extremely hungry. We tried Dan Dan Mian, Chong Qing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle, Sweet & Sour Spare Ribs, and BBQ Lamb Skewers. The best dish, by far, was the Dan Dan Mian. You have no idea how sad I have been in the past two years because I have not had good Dan Dan Mian since I left LA. This discovery is a game changer. The Chong Qing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle is an excellent vegetarian choice but I would have preferred a bit more numbing sensation. My date wanted the Spare Ribs and they were pretty decent for $4.95, but I probably wouldn't get them again. Finally, the Lamb Skewers were meaty and delicious; I could have used just a tad more cumin.

Overall, the meal was a resounding 5 star experience when graded on the Bay Area curve. Thank you, Chong Qing Xiao Mian, for restoring my hope in good Chinese food in SF.
author: Yi Z.

description: So glad I found this place! I had a craving for beef noodle soup and decided to try out Chong Qing - not only are the prices more reasonable, they also have a larger and more unique selection of traditional Sichuan dishes. I ordered the Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup ($11), which came in a giant heaping portion! I will definitely be back - they also have a ton of traditional appetizers.
author: Meesh L.

description:
I struggle finding Chinese food in SF that meets my standards. That sounds totally weird considering the large population of Chinese in just the metropolitan city alone. 

- Spicy Wontons - came in a spicy "soup" rather than the picture they display. It was fine but felt like it had-  very little meat.
- Tan Tan Noodles - This tasted like a regular bowl of noodles with some spicy sauce and it's my understanding that there should be a peanut element with Tan Tan or Dan Dan noodle. There was barely any ground pork in the dish. 
- Spicy Beef Tendon - not bad although I like my tendon sliced just a tad thinner.
- Braised Pork Belly - this was good albeit a bit salty and a small portion.

Ambiance: We had to eat at a communal table and even though we were at the edge closest to the kitchen it was a little claustrophobic being in that small place packed with tables. 

Service: the service was quick and efficient.

I left the restaurant feeling rather unsatisfied and perhaps it was the lack of protein because it wasn't very much protein when you looked at all the dishes combined.
author: Viyada S.

description:
Quaint little joint on the border of Chinatown, North Beach and Jackson Square.  Everything on the menu looks spicy.  For those of us who love spicy food, it will definitely satisfy though it may not necessarily push you to the edge.

Tan Tan Noodle: Fresh tender noodles.  Load of spicy goodness.  Savory ground pork.  This dish is awesome.  It's got a little broth, but it's far from being a soup.  The spicy factor seemed mostly derived from the sichuan peppercorn instead of tons of chili powder, so it's got that pleasant peppery perfume aroma to it.

Beanjello in Red Chili Sauce: Just wasn't feeling this one.  The chili sauce was fine; it even had an umami tone to it.  But the beanjello was a little bit too jello-like for my tastes.  I guess I was expecting something more like soft tofu, but this was savory bean-flavored jello.  Just not my thing.
author: Adam B.

description: Amazing dim sum and super sweet waiter. This place was recommended and I will definitely go back for one of their bowls.
author: Liz S.

description: Really good noodle dishes. Great flavor. Perfect spice level. So good! Can't wait to come back.
author: Tom D.

description: So freaking good. The service is a little under par, but the food more than compensates. My GF and I had bowls of soup, and an appetizer each and it came to $40 all in.
author: Mike G.

description:
After walking up and down (and all around) SF Chinatown a few times, searching Yelp reviews for a decent place to eat, we finally settled on this place due to the fact that there was a line of people out front, which is usually a good sign. Being only a party of 2, we didn't wait long (less than 10 min?) for a small table, skipping the bigger parties still waiting outside. 

We ordered the Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle, the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, and the BBQ Lamb Ribs. The noodles were on point: delicious, plentiful, chewy, and had just the right thickness. Did not care for the oversized, thick Napa cabbage leaves in both soup dishes (difficult to eat) nor the really thick layer of floating chili oil and countless Schezuan pepper flakes in the soup (one prev reviewer was right - you really can't drink the soup). Also, the picture on the menu for the Hot Numbing noodles showed thin greens (not the thick bottom ends we got), and for the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup showed much thicker, flat noodles. We asked if they got the type of noodles wrong for the 2nd dish. The answer was, "there is only one [type of] noodle [served]." The beef cuts in this soup dish was very tender but had a very plain stew flavor. Overall, the spiciness level was rather moderate (nowhere near hot numbing) for either dishes, although my tolerance level is rather high. The BBQ lamb rib dish was a disappointment for the $15.95 price. It was visually a very small portion; the ribs were also quite small with a lot of fat on them; and they were seasoned (rather saltily) on only one side.

Overall, the only reason we would return is for the tasty noodles and possibly to try the other dishes. This place is a pleasant surprise for the area, since most of what you'll get around there are dumplings, dim sum or just plain boring noodle dishes.
author: DN S.

description: Amazing soup. We had a corner booth and enjoyed watching the people outside. Walking distance from our hotel, but the homeless made it a scary walk.
author: Heather O.

description: For Chongqing noodles they really weren't very spicy. We ordered Chongqing small noodles (重庆小面) and the spicy beef rice noodle (麻辣红烧牛肉粉). The numbing spice didn't seem very fresh and really didn't cause the numbing feeling at all. Ok for Chinese food, buy certainly not the best I've ever had :(
author: Nadia S.

description:
Tan Tan Noodles?  Don't think I've ever had Tan Tan Noodles before.  It kind of looks like the Chinese version of Spaghetti.  We both agreed that my ordering skills is horrible and that I should be stripped of that right effective asap.  Somehow I managed to get him to order the Braised Spare Ribs...

Tan Tan Noodles- Uber delicious and lots of flavor. Huge portion
Braised Spare Ribs w/ Rice- a few big thick slabs of tough bland meat.  Sigh, I've failed at orderng again. Pass on this
Pork belly with garlic sauce- Decent, a little tough though
Cucumber Salad- refreshing

The Tan Tan Noodles are a must.  Will definitely come back to try the other noodle dishes.
author: Linda N.

description: Such a great find! Very small place with limited seating but the food was excellent! Great flavor. We will definitely be back again.
author: Aimee G.

description:
Spicy King is one of my favorite restaurants in chinatown.  So I went there with a high expectation.  I got there for lunch around 11:45.  The wait wasn't bad.  However, it took them forever to give us the check.  

Guiling Rice Noodles - I am not sure if that's what supposed to be, but i only had three pieces of meat.  Honestly, I think it's kind of pricey for what i got.  The soup was good.  I probably will not go back for a really really really long time.  This is one of those places I will go only if my friends want to go.
author: Rachael C.

description:
What a nice hidden gem in the outskirts of San Francisco Chinatown! My friend and I were looking to carb load before our race early in the morning and our criteria included: carbs, carbs, cheap, and more carbs. What better than to get Chinese food?

This place actually wasn't our first option but we came across it when looking for a place that takes card. That took us here. 

Their place is pretty small and not the cleanest, but don't let that discourage you from coming. Get here around 6 pm to avoid the crowd at 7. We got seated right away. Menu is pretty small and some things are crossed out but what they lack in quantity it's about that quality. I got the single cooked noodle and my friend got Dan Dan noodle. 

Late disclaimer: this place is your typically Sichuan style restaurant with spicy food. Not spicy like it'll burn the tip of your tongue but the kind of place that tingles your tongue. 

Food came out pretty quickly and I think they mixed up my order. I'm pretty sure I got the Dan Dan noodle, and first impressions was that it tasted great! The spice was there, tongue was tingling, and noodles were not bad. 

What I could mention as a caveat is that you don't get much in your bowl/plate. For $10, don't expect vegetables, hella meat, etc. That was a tad bit disappointing.

Overall, decent Chinese restaurant. It's dirty but it works when you're starving.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
Wow! Why so good!

I ordered the xiao mian, and it was amazing! Spicy and numbing, and so flavorful! 

The noodle was al dente. 

One complaint I have is the portion was on the larger size.
author: Wing C.

description:
Got cold house noodle and beef tendon. Both are super yummy and they give you A LOT of noodles in a bowl.

Minus one star for the customer service because one lady seems to be irritated at her job.
author: Karen J.

description: We came here on a random Wednesday night and there was a bit of a wait - lots of people looking for spice and warmth on the cold, slightly rainy day.  We got the chili wontons, tantan/dandan noodles, cucumbers, and the beef tendons.  The dandan were by far the best of the bunch.  The cucumbers were solid.  But the chili wontons had no flavor and tasted not per the usual fare and the beef tendons seemed to be not cut as thin or not as tender as I'm used to; the sauce wasn't bad, but they were more chewy than the usual.  I'd come back again for the spice while we're in the area, but for this kind of food I prefer Tasty Place down in Millbrae.
author: starrynight c.

description:
I'm long due to write this review! Chong Qing Xiao Mian already became my go to noodle shop, I had eaten there 3 times just during the first week I discovered it.
All the noodles are flavorful, in general portion. They make their own chili sauce with chili and 5 spices flakes, so aromatic and tasty! 
Their price is very reasonable considering how expensive food is in San Francisco.
Keep in mind t's a hole in a wall place, very small and always busy, in prime time you have to wait for a table. They opened another sister shop at the side street, which is much bigger and better decorated.
It's getting cold, go warm yourself up with a bowl of hot noodle soup!
author: sherry g.

description: So good that it's the only place I went almost everyday while I'm SF. Decent price, authentic flavor
author: Cathy Z.

description: Tried the pickled mustard fish noodles and the Guilin vermicelli noodles. The Guilin noodles had good flavor, although it's not exactly authentic. You don't get the toppings on the side to put into the noodles (not that big of a deal but it's fun to do it), the meat is the same as their beef noodle soup (which I actually appreciate, not a big fan of the meat that usually go into the Guilin style noodles), and the veggie toppings are all different. Probably healthier though because it's not as greasy. I liked the pickled mustard fish, had just the right amount of Sichuan peppercorn for me. The noodles were very plain though. The green onion pancakes was super crispy and thin, but pretty small in terms of portion. In general a good choice for noodles without going out to Richmond or South Bay.
author: Julie Z.

description:
This place is fairly authentic restaurant located in Chinatown SFO. I ordered the Tan Tan noodles which were very flavorful 3.5/5 only gripe was that the noodles were not very spicy, nor was the chili oil at the table.

The restaurant is always busy and pretty much everyone dining in there was Chinese. Which is always a good sign.

Huge shoutout to the staff for literally chasing me down the street because I forgot my iPhone at the restaurant. I found that really sweet of them,and very genuine. The 5 stars are for service!
author: Sagar K.

description:
For $20, my friend and I split a big bowl of noodles, a cold spicy ginger pork belly appetizer, and the couple's delight (why do they name these things as such... I will never know). The standouts were definitely the two cold appetizers. 
So authentic, flavorful, and so cheap ($5 per appetizer!)

I can't stress the quality enough. Growing up with this kind of food, I was very pleased that the Chong Qing ma la (numb/spicy) flavors were all there. The food here is so reasonably priced, filling (without feeling carbo-loaded), and at such a decent price point. 

It's also pretty good service for Chinatown! She was attentive without hovering and our waitress was the only person working the whole room. There was also only one chef in the kitchen and she was working very speedily. With a whole dining room full of people, we got our food pretty quickly! Also, it's not intimidating for non-Asians since there are pictures with the menu, which helps make ordering easy. 

I really hope this business succeeds! Come now if you can because I'm sure once the word gets out about this new business, lines will come through the door.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Spicy? Check
Numbness? Check
Noodles? Check

Overall, it was good and authentic but lacked flavor in some areas. But I would have to put my hands down to pork belly w/ garlic sauce. That sauce is money! I would bring that sauce home and make fried rice. Nom nom nom
author: Kevin Y.

description: It wasn't close to the real thing.  My friends from Chengdu and Xizhou and Shanghai who joined me agreed the food was not spicy.  But we were generally satisfied with the quality and they enjoined seeing the hipsters discuss how authentic the food was before they went back to SalesForce.
author: Timothy H.

description:
This is a hidden gem for authentic Szechuan noodle soups.  So delicious and affordable!  Although they sometimes have a line at the door, it moves rather quickly and they are pretty efficient about getting people in and out.  Orders do not take too long to come out and there's a pretty good turnaround of tables.

The menu is primarily made up of noodle soups, all of which are delicious.  I love the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup which has a nice ma la flavor.  Ma La is the Szechuan peppercorn which has a numbing sensation.  It can be a little bit strange for someone to taste for the first time, but I think they do a pretty good job of balancing this flavor so that it is not overwhelming.  The spice is perfect on a cold and windy SF day!  My other fave is the Braised Spare Ribs Noodle Soup (Pai Gu Mian).  The broth is SO delicious--clearly a slow boiled bone broth with rich and deep flavor and they are super generous on the portion of meat.  This is like the soup I crave for when I am sick in bed.  Amazing, and it's not spicy for those of you that can't handle the heat!  Portions for the noodle soups are large and the noodles are nice and fresh and chewy.  

For sides, I would recommend the:
- Cucumber Salad - good portion and a nice way to balance out the heat from the soups
- Green Onion Pancake - nice and crispy
- BBQ Lamb Skewer - nice cumin flavor and very tender lamb meat

My problem whenever I visit is that we over order.  You could easily share 1 noodle soup with some appetizers for 2 people.  Unfortunately, we always want to try different noodle soups and appetizers so we end up ordering a feast that we can't finish.  Consequences of having greedy eyes.
author: Jess Y.

description:
So good! I got the pickled green mustard beef noodle soup and my friend got the tan tan noodles. I heard the tan tan noodles were pretty spicy, so if that's what you're looking for then that's the go to. My beef noodle soup was delicious and more of my type. We also got some vegetables and lamb skewers - the lamb skewers were really good so definitely would recommend them.

The only thing missing here is beer.
author: Victor O.

description:
Here is the thing about this place. We used yelp to find our dining spot and this was recommended. I'm glad we did because the noodles are worth the wait. 
We got Tan Tan (mine was ordered mild). My daughters also ordered Tan Tan and a vegetarian noodle dish. This was the best I have ever had and we will return for every trip.
author: RJ F.

description:
Ordered the tan tan noodles. I was expecting it to be really spicy from ally the other reviews, but I was surprised to find it pleasantly mild. There is a large jar of chili oil on the table so you can adjust to your heat level. I honestly prepared myself for some serious spice. The broth was pretty flavorful and there were a ton of noodles. Very tasty dish. 

The only reason I took away a star is because of how loud the staff are. There were middle aged Asian ladies in the kitchen that were just talking so so loud the entire time me and my friend were eating lunch. Though this is a sit down place, it was impossible to have a conversation with my friend over the noise of the staff. And this one guy was transporting all sorts of ingredients/supplies on a dolly THROUGH THE MIDDLE OF THE RESTAURANT - during lunch time. Don't deliveries usually happen before the restaurant opens for business? I've seen the back door as well (the staff keep it open during business times), so not sure why he was using the dining area to deliver. The staff kept telling the customers to scoot their chairs in so that the delivery man could get through. Kind of strange...
author: S. S.

description:
I'm so glad I found this place. I came here because I was craving something Asian but not as rich as ramen but heavier than dim sum and Chong Qing was the closest and highest rated.

The Tan Tan Noodles is the staple of the menu and it delivers so much for a great price: firm noodles soaking in a broth of chili oil and grease, topped with minced meat and a heavy-set spice profile.

The service is fast and prompt with great attention and definitely clean all around from what I could observe. I'd definitely recommend coming here and enjoy the food and the show of running a small eatery.
author: Zahir A.

description: Great noodles with beef.  Just the right amount of spice without having to ask to tone it down a bit.  The beef even though being in a broth had it's own flavor.  Good stuff.
author: Dan C.

description: The soup is really good. We got the pickle mustard beef noodle. It's sour and spicy numbing. The restaurant is a bit cramped, but it gives a Chinese vibe. It's a bit hard to communicate with the waitresses because they mostly speak Chinese. They give a good portion. I was able to share with my girlfriend and both of us were full.
author: Chris B.

description: The noodles are made fresh here. The fatty pork has excellent flavor. This is a middle of China kind of food, not the typical, eggrolls and fried rice, Americanized Chinese food. This is authentic stuff.
author: Janice L.

description: The place has awesome delicious food. Oily and tasty. Full of flavor. I had the Tan Tan Noodles and steamed veggies. The right amount of spicy. The sweet and sour short ribs were tasty.  Service was nice and friendly. I can't see that much oil being good for you but as long as you don't eat it every day... I think I souls eat here very often if I lived close. Good job!
author: Mario M.

description: I loved the ramen here! This place has really amazing tasting Chinese food. The place is small which made it easy to observe people coming and going from the restaurant. When I took a moment to look around, I noticed there was one person per table enjoying a bowl of ramen. It is that delicious! It seems to be a place where people just go on their own or with a friend to enjoy ramen. I certainly can understand why. The service is great too. Don't forget to try the egg rolls and pot stickers! They are perfectly crisp and delicious.
author: Ang M.

description: After trying most of their appetizers, my family thought that it was really salty and bland. Their guiling noodle soup was pretty good and the noodle texture was just right! We also ordered the spicy beef ramen and pickled mustard ramen which was okay. We would go back for the noodles but maybe not the appetizers.
author: Pam Ela Y.

description: Came back a second time with my friend. The service was better and the menu looked a lot better. Also thought the food tasted better this time. I would recommend a try!
author: Victor L.

description: Cheap authentic spicy noodles with large servings-- we got 1 to share between 2 people, along with tea eggs & dumplings. The noodles could have been spicier (we LOVE spicy food!) but it was flavourful enough that we could do without.
author: Charmaine L.

description:
Chong Qing Xiao Mian instantly became my favorite Beef Noodle Soup shop in the entire city and I highly, highly recommend trying this place. In terms of price, each entree comes in at around ~$10 and is a very generous portion that probably can serve as two meals for lunch (if you don't want to pass out at work). I probably come here at LEAST once a week. It is conveniently located down Kearny within walking distance of FIDI. This place isn't established on SF's food delivery network yet, but has take-out available for pick-up. 

[Food]: I always say that my last meal on earth would be beef noodle soup. The beef noodle soup with pickled mustard greens here comes close to what I envision my last meal on earth could be (or if I had to eat one meal for the rest of my life). The noodles here are on the thinner side and is more traditional Chinese (like the name of the restaurant) than the Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup that is a bit more famous. This is my go to dish. I would also highly recommend the wontons in spicy chili oil. In terms of appetizers, I've tried the green onion pancakes, but they weren't the standout here. 

[Decor]: It's your hole in the wall Chinese restaurant. 

[Service]: The only reason I gave this place 4/5 stars was the service. I mean this is not a Michelin-Star restaurant so you shouldn't be expecting someone to pull your chair out for you, but sometimes the line can get congested and they don't seem to have the most efficient seating system. The place is also a bit small and cramped with people. 

Overall, a standout new gem in the heart of Chinatown. Definitely give this place a try and get the Beef Noodle Soup with Mustard Greens!
author: Alice Z.

description:
This place was super tasty! We ordered the Chongqing numbing noodles, wonton soup, and tan tan noodles. Surprisingly, the food was barely spicy at all, despite its bright red appareance. Every dish we ordered was more or less the same -- same broth, same noodles, etc. 

The portions are large, so you should only order two dishes per three people.

Service is fast.
author: Katelyn B.

description:
The Spicy Beef Noodle Soup was excellent, the price was reasonable (about $11), the service was efficient and the line to get in was out the door.

All considered, I'm not sure you'll find any better.

As Arnold said, I'll be back.
author: Some Bozo ..

description: We were in the city for the day and tried this place for dinner. It was good although a bit too authentic for everyone in the group. Soups were good, service was ok.
author: Kara H.

description:
Tan Tan noodles!!
First time here, my order was ready in under 10 minutes & best of all.. numbingly delicious.
author: douglas h.

description: Not authentic. Taste is OK. Does not compare to better options like Z&Y but usually there is no line. Most sketchy part is forcing an 18% tip on the bill. Unacceptable.
author: William W.

description:
We're from Miami and it's tough to find authentic Chinese food there! I mean, we really don't have a 'China Town'. Here's what my wife and I took from our experience at Chong Qing Xiao Mian.

Pros:
The food was fresh and the restaurant was also pretty clean! 

Food and experience:
We ordered the Green onion pancakes, 
Tan tan noodles, Dumplings and spare rib ends. Dumplings were awesome and so were the green onion pancakes. The noodles were OK, but not very flavorful. Ribs were way too tough. 

The only other comment I'd make is that our waitress couldn't guide us in the right direction. For someone inexperienced in the authentic Chinese food game it's difficult to gauge what you should order. This isn't a place you order fried rice in ppl (they actually don't have, I checked). There's definitely a language barrier.. So all in all, if I was a Chinese food connoisseur, I might have enjoyed this place more. If you're a beginner, you might spend some money experimenting with food you don't end up liking.
author: Maria R.

description: I love here one of the best Chinese restaurant in Sanfranciso, the noodle is good the appetizers is ok .
author: Clancy Y.

description: First time here. I actually really enjoyed it. It's not to spicy but you can add more spicy oil to it on the table. We got the tan tan noodle and beef with pickled greens. Appetizer, we got lamb skewer and braise pork belly. The pork belly is a no. It is tender but salty. Maybe better with rice. The skewer is good season with cumin and fennel seed. It's flavor does kick a punch but I like it. The two noodle bowl is most popular but I like the beef with picked greens better. Maybe because it has a sour flavor to it which I like. The best part is the noodles. Hand made nice and firm plus they give you a large amount of noodles. I really liked it. Thanks to Roy, he helped me with half of my noodles or else for sure I wouldn't be able to finish it. Even than I'm so stuffed. Should have given him 3/4 of my noodles lol. 4 star from me. Oh yeah the drink is really good and refreshing but not worth $3. I'm going to an Asian store to grab a case at a cheaper price .
author: Christy V.

description: This place was great. Super busy during lunch, but the noodle soups are all delicious. There's no online menu and no delivery options. That's a bummer because I'd order from here much more often if they did.
author: Mark C.

description:
i really wanted to like this too! four star on yelp and deliver with uber. i decided to give it a try.

the one star is for the green onion pancake, the rest deserve ZERO star. in short, found two long black hair in two different dishes, and none of the food is spicy or numbing by any standard, not even a bit. putting chong qing in this name is a joke. 

your local american chinese food restaurant is going to taste better and have bigger portion for the same price than here.
author: Haoyu W.

description: Better taste then other locations for the noodles, better phone signal. Only one noodle is great which is Guilin noodle. Other sour noodle and xiaoguo noodle was alright. The spareribs was too sweet and hard. Not sour at all.
author: Qing L.

description: Love this little gem in Chinatown. Place is clean but pretty small and it get crowded real fast especially during the lunch time. But I think pretty much most place will get crowded around this area around lunch time. The broth is super yummy. It can look intimidating and spicy but it does not taste as spicy as I would it will be since the broth is super red and with all the chilly. We ordered the original noodle and the chicken in the appetizer.
author: L D.

description: This place has very authentic sichuanese noodles. My friends and I came here together and ordered two appetizers and then each got our own noodles. Our wishes same out extremely fast and so did our bill later. Portion sizes were fair, and flavors were really well seasoned (definitely spicier than most places which is a plus imo). Only complaint for me was that I ordered the duck dish but there was not as much duck as I would have liked.
author: Diana Y.

description: Short of a trip to Chengdu this is a nice replacement. It's less spicy, oily and garlicky then the real McCoy but it's still the flavors of the Sichuan province. Prepare to be packed in tight, rushed and treated with little to no hospitality. All this only adds to the authenticity. Spicy beef noodles were filling and left me tingling.
author: Rob B.

description: This place is pretty good if you like to get quick meal. The place is very small but cheap. Food quality is pretty good but taste-wise, it's not as impressive as I expected. Maybe I just had unrealistic expectation. It will be a place I will frequent if it's close to where I live but not something unforgettable.
author: Yuesheng L.

description:
This place reminds me of Chongqing. 

Each of the dishes is very similar to what you get back in China. The spice level is definitely toned down compared to what the locals eat. 

Some must try items:

Wontons
Tiger skin Jalapeño
House dry noodles

Can't go wrong with any of the noodle dishes.
author: Lyman C.

description: Tan tan noodle was good and just enough spicy level. Overal food was good and happy to have this comfort food
author: Stacey W.

description:
Chong Qing is delicious! Prompt service and spicy, flavorful noodles. I was visiting SF and had to come here twice - the Tan Tan Noodles were that good! 

Go now if you love spicy noodles where the heat is layered with flavor.
author: Becky M.

description: Food was great! Soup has a lot of good flavor but is just too oily. Still good though. Pop stickers and mini spare ribs for appetizers. & beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup!
author: Pamela C.

description: Decent prices for huge portions and insanely fast service. Like literally we ordered, the waitress turned around and 30 seconds later we had our appetizers hahaha. We got the bean jelly and pork belly appetizers and then the tan tan men and the pickled mustard greens noodle soup. Overall impressions are that this place isn't that spicy compared to a lot of other Sichuan places I've been, and their food is veeery oily, which is kind of to be expected. Bean jelly was delicious, a little sweeter than what I get at a lot of places, very vinegar-y and yummy. Pork belly was pretty good, it's really delicious with the bean sauce in the giant jar on the table. Tan tan men was decent, the noodles were great and the meat was salty and yummy, but the soup tasted just like hot oil hahaha. The pickled mustard greens soup had a lot more flavor and the stewed meat in that dish was delicious. Overall a nice place to go
author: Michelle Z.

description: Walked in famished on a Saturday in the midst of city touring and took fellow Yelpers' advice and ordered the hot spicy noodles (subbed rice noodles). Unbelievably delicious and under $9 with tax! So good, in fact, that I went back for dinner and ordered the same thing!
author: Angela R.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I've had in a while.  Really enjoyed the Duck Ginger Soup.  Staff was a little cold but overall I really good bargain for the flavor and quantity.
author: Sean T.

description: Holy frick, this was hands down the best bowl of noodles I've ever tasted. The prices were relatively low, and the portions were decent, too; ~10$ for a good sized bowl of noodles.
author: John W.

description: Fantastic noodles! It brings me back to my days in the former war time capitol, Chong Qing. Lots of choices, great appetizers and wonderful noodles that will make your mouth water
author: Zach A.

description: Excellent authentic food, everything we had was amazing! We were skeptical, just pulled this up on Yelp and it was close by. I was very surprised it was only 4 stars! It was so delicious that we came back and ordered the exact same items a few days later on Saturday and found a line, not surprising! Asked some locals next to us in line, they said this was the best in the area. We wholeheartedly agreed. Highly recommend.
author: Sue H.

description: Passed by this place on a Tuesday afternoon at around 2pm only to find that there's still a huge lunch crowd and line. Fortunately the turnover is pretty fast here and I was seated in about 20 minutes (there were at least 10 parties of varying sizes before mine). I decided to try the spicy beef noodles and I could definitely see why it's a customer favorite. The meat was extremely tender, the noodles with a perfect springy texture and the soup in absolute perfection. My only regret is not trying the soup in a spicier level (I had opted for medium spice) and not being able to try some of their appetizers.
author: Judy H.

description:
I had 4pm lunch take out on a weekday and this place was open with a handful of seated customers.  Got their supposedly "spicy" beef brisket with rice to go.  I wasn't looking forward to my head sweating at work eating spicy stuff, but I also don't want them to alter the dish so I just went ahead with what they have.
They charge an extra $.30 for the plastic container and $.10 for the bag.  Total was $12 and change.

Food was ready in 3 min so that was fast.  
The brisket was not piping hot this late in the day and didn't melt the plastic container lid, which I thought was a good thing.  I skipped microwaving it as it was still hot enough with the rice.

Luckily the beef brisket was very tender but not spicy at all.  Portion size is adequate and I was satisfied.  The sauce/soup was chili oily but overall it was light to the taste.  

Will come back to try other things in the menu.
author: Drew B.

description: First time here, this place has some really solid noodles. You can tell just by smell, that the broth is amazing. While some folks come here for the numbing spice taste, I got the the pork broth noodles which was still as flavorful without the spice. I love that the broth includes vegetables, daikon, some sort of asian sweet nuts, and a mirage of balanced spices.  The noodles for definitely get a 5 stars in my book, but I'm unsure of other dishes (the wine chicken was nothing special). The free tea served has only a hint of taste and serves as more of a palate cleanser.
author: Dion L.

description: Order the beef in pickled mustard green. The beef is so tender and fatty. It's to die for.
author: Na Eun O.

description: Love the Tan Tan. I will get it more than once this week. Highly recommended!!  Have it with the tea. It strikes a good balance
author: Athena P.

description: Tasty Dan Dan mian and spicy beef noodle soup! Their spicy beef noodle soup blows House of Xian Dumplings(two doors down) out of the park, Xian's beef noodle soup is way too sweet and not spicy at all for me. Blegh.  It's the closest Szechuan flavors that I've had in SF that is comparable to the BOMB noodles I had in Szechuan, China but 5 times the portion sizes (go go obese USA). It's a good numbing burn but not bad enough where it's uncomfortable. I love spicy noodles so this place totally hits the spot.
author: Linda H.

description: Overall: good, flavorful and authentic Szechuan food--which also means that you have to stomach the oiliness of it! Got the dandanmian and the stir fry lotus root. Both were solid. The only downside to this place is that their utensils aren't really clean--everything was oily, from the empty cup that was given to me to pour my tea into, to the bowls, ladles.... you name it. Nevertheless, I don't expect top notch cleanliness and service from an authentic Chinese place TBH--the grit of it somehow contributes to its vibe. (??? Unsure). Bottom line would still return for its solid food!
author: Astrid G.

description: The food was tasty. It was refreshing to see something described as spicy and it actually tasted spicy. Service was fast. They don't take American Express or Discover, so, that might be something for travelers to keep in mind. Nothing extraordinary. Just a decent meal, accurately described and quickly served.
author: P O.

description:
Really delightful, I tasted the cucumber salad, scallion pancake, Tan Tan Noodles, and Beef with Pickled Mustard Greens. I thought the scallion pancake was a bit doughy and not as crispy as it could have been, but the cucumber salad tasted very fresh and helped cut through the richness of the noodle dishes very effectively. The noodle dishes were both awesome, definitely the right end of the spice spectrum so that I could add spice to my level of comfort.

The restaurant itself is cramped, but feels exactly like Chinatown NYC restaurants in that way. No harm, no foul.
author: Justin B.

description:
Chong Qing Xaio Mein is Szechuan noodle shop is a predominantly Cantonese San Francisco Chinatown. The restaurant is small and the table and chairs are packed in. The menu is simple with most of the menu noodle dishes. Each table has a huge vat of hot sauce. When we arrived we got the last open table and there was a constant wait list. Almost all the noodle soups were $9.95 and we ordered the pickled mustard green beef noodle soup. Great flavor but the noodles were slightly over cooked and there were only 3 tiny pieces of beef. The Szechuan dry noodles were also good with thin noodles that were al dente. I don't recommend the cumin lamb skewers because much of the lamb was fat. The most interesting item was the spicy red oil wontons. Usually, spicy wontons are served dry with a spicy sauce on top but the dish served here comes in a spicy soup that was outstanding. The wontons skins were a bit thick and tough but the soup it came in was excellent. 

Service was ok and the food us slow in coming out when they are busy. Parking in the Portsmouth's parking lot.
author: George F.

description:
Tongue numbing slow burn. 

I've had the Tan Tan Noodles, Spicy Beef (picture on menu is deceiving - no wide noodles, they are all thin), and Spicy Beef with Pickled Veg and the Tan Tan has the most flavorful broth by far. 

You can ask the server for less spicy and adjust accordingly with the pot of hot chili oil at your table if you're into controlling the heat level in your soup base! 

Another thing to order is the cucumber salad - my friend and I say there dissecting the addicting vinegary juice that the cucumbers are pickled in. 10/10 would order (or make) again! Would be a great accompaniment to the spicy noodles! 

The places gets pretty packed as it's right next to tourist trap House of Nanking, but this place is pretty authentic in terms of Szechuan spice!
author: Connie N.

description: One of the biggest surprises I got in SF! The price is decent and the quality of the food is amazing! I have been a big fan for spicy food; the chilli oil smells super good and the noodle is handmade and fresh. If you're also a spicy food fan, Chong Qing Xiao Mian will not disappoint you.
author: Tiffany T.

description: My boyfriend loved it, but I wasn't a fan. I got the braised short rib noodle. The broth (which I Believe was just a pork bone broth) was just flavorless, salty water. But the meat was very good, and I would definitely recommend their pot stickers.
author: Jay T.

description:
Loooove the spicy noodles here! We got the tan tan noodles (mild spice) and beef noodles (normal spice). And also the green onion pancake. 

Everything was decently priced. My friend said the tan tan noodles was a tad spicy but perfect level for her. The beef noodles came with chunks of soft beef brisket and A LOT OF NOODLES. the broth was numbing spicy. Your tongue will turn numb! There was a lot of noodles so you can prob share this. The portions are huge here! 

Service was decent. I love that it's a couple of Chinese ladies here and there was a lady cooking by herself in the back. Get the beef noodles!
author: Sarah I.

description: To be honest, it doesn't taste as good as we expected. The 口水鸡 has no flavor, Y & Z made it much better.  chongqing xiao Mina doesn't taste good either, it is too spicy and it has a lot of MSG in it! When we headed back, we all felt tired and big headache, it can be the MSG in every dish. So just be careful.
author: Haiyan H.

description:
Pro Tip:
Great Hot Noods!


I also loved the cold, wet and garlicky cucumbers.
Perfect pairing with the hot noods.
author: George C.

description: Super duper restaurant! Everything was very delicious! Get the Barbeque squid for appetizer. It was awesome! Tan tan noodle was also delicious and the braised beef soup broth was good too. If you are a Korean, you can expect some sort of  gal-bee-tang flavor from the braised beef soup. Highly recommmend the place!
author: 90sujeong ..

description: We wanted to find a good noodle place to eat in San Francisco that was really good but casual. This place was mentioned on a few food blogger articles and so we thought we would give it a go. It ended up being one of the best noodle places we've ever been too. Didn't have a problem with service, they were nice and straight to the point. We both ordered the beef green onion pickled mustard noodle bowl and it was perfectly spicy, beef was super tender and soft. The broth was really good, you could tell there were a lot of different spices in it. Just try it.
author: Shira H.

description: My cousin and I were fortunate to come here mid-afternoon on a Saturday and there was no line!  Still busy and we got the last empty table, but way better than the last time I came for dinner on a Saturday night and the line was down the block!  Fairly abbreviated menu, a lot of spice (there's even a dish named "numbing" from the side effect of the chilies they use - awesome!).  I focused mainly on noodles, since that's what I was in the mood for and so did my cousin!  We both enjoyed our dishes and she liked hers so much, she ordered one for to-go for her boyfriend (I think she got the tan-tan noodles).  We also tried their onion pancake and that was good.  It's a lot of food, but so good, we both finished our bowls!  Service is fast, straight forward (no frills).  The bathroom has one of the tiniest sinks I've ever seen!  Will definitely come again with hubby if we can time it right to avoid the lines!
author: Lily W.

description: Noodles were always overcooked but the soup/sauces are on point. Don't think the owner cares about feedback but putting it here just in case. Stop over cooking your noodles, it feels like I'm eating a block of flour.
author: Koalie W.

description:
TL;DR: Numbing spicy noodle lovers, come here. This place is the real deal.

After a long night of drinking, I woke up hungover and hungry. Looking for a solution that could kill two birds with one stone, me and my friends ended up at this restaurant after a recommendation from one of my boy's bae.

This restaurant is small, with that vibe you get from restaurants in China, and had a wait even though it was almost 2PM on a Saturday. Put your name on the list, and wait till they call you. They have a large communal table in the center of the room, with other tables on the sides for groups of 2-4.

When I went, the three of us got the spicy beef noodle soup with pickled vegetables, some cucumber salad, and the green onion pancake. The noodles will literally beat the hangover out of you. The spiciness is the numbing-spicy type, and it was great. Properly cooked noodles, flavorful soup, fluffy pancakes, and a nice cooling cucumber salad results in a perfect lunch. You want that Chinese ma-la flavor? Come here.
author: Albert C.

description: The only thing we got here that was good was the cucumber salad. Not spicy at all, lackluster noodles, and a wildly off flavor profile. My father, who is Chinese, says that they were very much unlike any noodles he had in Chong Qing
author: Dana C.

description:
Extremely delicious and pretty darned affordable.

The place was pretty busy when I went there after work. I didn't get the signature soup, but I ordered a bunch of sides:

-- green onion pancake / scallion pancake: super tasty and crisp with good layering. Doesn't come with sauce, which I like.
-- beef tendon: excellent flavor and texture. It wasn't too thin nor too tough. Just right! Pretty good sized portion for the price, too!
-- sweet & sour ribs: much too sweet for my tastes, but a good sized portion.

There's not a lot of seating, so you should probably call ahead if there are more than 4 in your party.
author: B C.

description: Tasty noodles but the side dishes we got (mouth watering chicken and lamb kabobs) were not that great.  A bit of a wait and simply just not enough space inside.
author: Hanyu Q.

description: Even though their specialty is noodles, I find them too oily to eat overtime and always ended-up not being able to finished it. Instead, I recommend to have the braised beef soup. It includes rice and the portion is very filling. The taste is refreshing and savory. Almost like Ba kut teh. It is not spicy and its very light.
author: Elitè T.

description: Peanuts surprise make them take up the whole dish added and slurps of broth filled the mouth-watering bowl.
author: Angela T.

description: Was wandering around trying to find a good place to eat. This is a very small place that's easy to miss but looking through the front window I could see that at least to me, someone who's never been to China, this looked very authentic. 80% asian crowd and many signs in Chinese and even the menus are in Chinese (and English). I don't know if that is actually a good indication though because there is a very large asian population in SF and also this is Chinatown... but it was also pretty full (but not too full) so I decided to go in.  Good decision! The food was really tasty, I had a Wonton in chilly oil soup and a cucumber salad. The soup needs to 'sit' for a few minutes for the flavors to blend in (and also so it doesn't burn your tongue), and when it's ready to eat it's just delicious with plenty of wonton in it. Careful though, it's spicy! The salad was just perfect, made with room temperature cucumbers and yummy dressing. service was fast and prices are typical to SF (i.e. too high). Overall, I will definitely come back when I'm in the area again!
author: Gil S.

description: Absolutely delicious. Came here for the authentic szechuan taste, was not disappointed. Wait was a bit long-- about a little bit over half an hour on a work day evening. Got four side dishes and one noodle to split between the two of us, and it was just the right amount!
author: Cheechee L.

description:
I had Mr. Ping's Noodle Dream and it was right on the streets of Chinatown in San Francisco. Chong Qing Xiao Mian is an authentic noodle house nestled right next to the legendary House of Nanking right of Kearney Street. 

Like most hole-in-the-walls, the food is four stars and the service is about a two. Let's start with the good:
+ Your dollar has Fab Five flexibility here. We spent about $50 total on dinner for three people and we definitely over ordered with us ordering sweet and sour pork ribs, braised bok choy, bowls of tan tan mian, spicy beef noodle soup, fish and rice, dumplings in chili oil, and probably more that I can't remember since we were such in a food coma.
+ The dumplings in chili oil came in a penseive like bowl where you could clearly see that dumplings were in your past and future. Seriously every time we dipped our ladle in we were surprised to find more dumplings floating to the top!
+ My spicy beef noodle soup had tender beef, a good mix of greens, perfect chewy noodles, and as promised lots and lots of spice!
+ I ended up leaning towards the sweet and our pork ribs and greens that day which accompanied the resulting fire in my mouth from the noodles.

The Service:
+ Besides bussing our tables, we basically had to grab all of our utensils, bowls and remind the waiters to refill our water and tea, and bring out dishes we ordered because...they just did not care.
+A group of 12 came in and the servers had the audacity to kick out a table who was in the middle of their meal and move them to another table which I found quite rude. 
+ The words vegetarian or gluten free do not exist here so you better know your Chinese food before ordering here if you have any food allergies.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Best beef noodle soup (beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup) I've ever had! They give a generous amount of beef, which basically melts in your mouth. Best sf has to offer.
author: Irene P.

description: Nope. The pictures look great but the food was not. Not authentic at all. If you like noodles covered in straight oil then you'll get that here. I'm more of a broth girl and there was none unless you like drinking grease. Sorry wanted to like it but even my Chinese Grandma got mad at me for bringing her here.
author: J C.

description:
This place is legit. Very authentic Chongqing food, a rare find in Chinatown. Probably the closest I've found since returning to the US from, yes you guessed it, Chongqing.
  Sadly, the wait staff consisted of only two very polite, but overworked, girls. To get to a five star rating, they need to hire at least one more person. Otherwise, be prepared to wait for your order. The good news: it's worth the wait!
author: Clayton R.

description: Excellent! Note that any dish can be made with rice noodles if you're sensitive to gluten/wheat.
author: Eric S.

description:
Looking cleaner than most chinatown restaurants, and being new, I gave this place a shot and I left with a smile on my face. 

We tried the spicy beef noodle soup (tender beef & sour greens) and the ginger and duck noodle soup.

- ginger and duck noodle soup.
light flavor broth, delicious duck, not spicy.

- spicy beef noodle soup 
full flavor broth with that numbing pepper and spicy pepper.  I love the sour greens that cuts through the spicy, refreshing your taste buds.  the beef is sooo tender and good.

the noodles (both)- great bite and a good amount of it

Service-a bit slow on everything.
author: Bobby L.

description:
I've had a lot of noodles in my day. I even soent two years living abroad in Taiwan. I can say, without a doubt, that Ching Wing Xiao Mian is some of the best noodles I've ever had. I had the paigu mian, and it was phenomenal. 

The only downside was that the potstickers weren't that amazing. But they're a noodle restaurant, so it's not a huge surprise. 

Next time I'm in SF, I will definitely go out of my way to eat here. 

It does get crowded, but when we showed up around 5:30 we got seated right away. However, by the time we left there was a decent line of people waiting to eat. 

One of the ways to know if Chinese food is good is by the number of Chinese people eating it. There were plenty at this restaurant.
author: Dallin S.

description:
I have been fiending for noodles recently but had reservations about this place b/c they use the thin wheat noodles that are basically spaghetti.  Normally, I like ramen noodles, thick egg noodles, or thick hand pulled noodles...basically the ones that are more likely to yield al dente results.  But given the good reviews, I just had to visit and try for myself.

I told the waitress that we were comfortable with spicy and wanted her recommendation.  She pointed to the house noodles (the spicy one without meat).  Since I generally like some meat with my noodles, I also got an order of the chicken appetizer (kou shui ji).  The chicken appetizer was solid, and I'd recommend it.  I thought the broth for the noodle dish was pretty good, too.  I was unsure what to expect...perhaps some animal broth with a lot of chili oil.  But I think I detected the flavor of pickled mustard, too.  However, it contained all the flavor of the dish.  If you ate the noodle by itself without taking in a mouthful of broth, it was pretty lackluster.  The fact that the noodles were slightly overcooked did not help matters.

If I return, I would order the dry noodles...First they would more likely be al dente and secondly, maybe the noodles would be flavored better.
author: Lan N.

description: Highly recommend! Very authentic! The thing is too spicy for me and would only come here once a while. But it isn't probability the best noodles place in San Francisco, if you like spicy noodles, this place is perfect for you!
author: Kelvin Y.

description: Wow, the Chong Qing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle is so delicious! Being a vegetarian, I often struggle to find Asian restaurants that have options for me to eat. And if I find a place that does serve a vegetarian dish, it is usually either tasteless or a plate of steamed vegetables. However, the spicy noodle soup was far beyond anything I expected. It was full of flavor and the portion was huge! My meal was also pretty inexpensive and perfect for an affordable lunch out. For the price, the quantity and quality of the food are amazing. I would definitely recommend if you are looking for something warm and flavorful!
author: Mallika J.

description: After these days  ,I think I should change the star.I visit this restaurant since it opened. Every time I visit this restaurant,the food quality is worse than before.When it is open,I really like their noodles,and at least their chill oil in the noodles were red and normal. But now ,the oil they use is so dark black and weird .I 've never seen any chili oil is black and tasteless.it is Neither spicy or smell good.their food is  really greasy and awful .Their grill squid didn't grill, I sAw they just fry the squid with seasoning! They should stop using that bad quality oil and focus on their foods quality .At last,I don't recommend this restaurant,and I never visit this restaurant any more.
author: Botasha B.

description: . . THE FOOD IS HORRIBLE! THEY SERVE OLD FOOD WITH  DIRTY CANS OF SODA! WHEN I WIPED THE SODA WITH MY NAPKIN,  IT WAS literally black!  The worst food with the worst service! Super dirty cooks, who whipe their sweaty face with their hands and never washing them! GROSS! No thanks, will never return! Fool me once!
author: Gina F.

description:
Southwest Chinese cuisine seems to be the trend these days.  
And it sure doesn't look like it's slowing anytime soon.  
Walking by one morning, I noticed two new restaurants on Kearny Street and asked for takeout menus from each place.  About a week later, I studied the menu and decided to try their Spicy Beef noodle soup (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=G5KR7WJhsJrM4X7WvO0zHg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) for $9.95.  The picture on the menu (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zVMogYg1hg9b9iePEoDpQA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) was a bit different as the ingredients were a bit different and actually for the better.  The menu photo shows a thicker udon like noodle with tender bok choy.  What I actually ate had water spinach (ong choy) and large cubes of daikon (radishes) which added to the flavor and textures in the bowl.  I appreciated that it wasn't fully "authentic" as described in its Chinese name of numbing spicy.  My mouth tasted the different flavor in the bowl which made it that much more interesting.  The beef chunks were melt-in-mouth soft and flavored from its braising process.  The noodles were thinner, more in line with saimin noodles found in Hawaii, more of a Cantonese style noodle type.
The menu doesn't have a large variety of items if you're coming for a family style diner, but, for just a one plate meal, there is a good selection both spicy and non-spicy.  For those who seek authentic numbing spice far, this probably doesn't fit your bill.  For me, being able to taste the food is more important especially if they leave me smiling.
Will be back to have this again on a cool San Francisco day.  Also, hope to try some of the other available noodles.  Given the prices of ramen these days, this is definitely a good change of pace or warming bowl of noodles when in the area.
author: Mike C.

description: Came here randomly for dinner, and I enjoyed it! We ordered the wonton in spicy chili oil, tan tan noodles, bbq lamb skewers, and steamed vegetables. Everything was tasty, with just the right level of heat. I especially liked the lamb skewers. Perfectly cooked and not too gamy.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
1- Came here on a Monday at 11:55 and beat the lunch rush. 
2-Got seated fairly quickly and food came out fast. 
3-Big noodle portions and everything was really spicy and drenched in oil (first few bites were tolerable then everything got spicy numbing) 
4-If you want it spicier there is a big bamboo pot with chili flakes on your table.
5-I'll come back, but the boyfriend dislikes how it's drenched in oil 
6-The foodranger on YouTube made me want to try this place. Not that he endorsed it, but he's very into this type of cuisine.
author: Helen C.

description: Very popular Chinese restaurant. Our group people ordered about 10 kinds of dishes. They are all delicious! Comparing the price with other restaurants in San Francisco , Chongqing Xiaomian is really decent. Fast service + original flavors!
author: Yen C.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite places to go to when I'm craving something spicy! I always order the tan tan noodles and the garlic pork belly appetizer. I took my parents there while they were visiting and they wanted to go back again before their flight out.

There isn't much pork in the appetizer sadly. I feel like I take a few pieces and its all gone but the sauce is super delicious. I like to take it home and put it over rice to eat. 

As for the spiciness level, I feel like it varies every time I got there. It's not the most consistent but you can always add more spice as they leave it on the table. Regardless its pretty good every time.
author: Ann L.

description: The Babe™ and I were in San Francisco for a conference and we ventured out to find some 'real' Chinese food.  We had heard good things about this place so we thought we would check it out.  When we first arrived we were questioning our decision but after smelling the wafting aromatic breeze we decided to try it.  Absolutely fantastic!  I haven't had this kind of food/flavor/intensity since I was last in Shenzhen.  We ordered a variety of dishes and ate past feeling full.  It was awesome.  Only missed 5 stars due to lack of diet soda choices.  Don't be put off thinking you have to know Chinese to order/eat.  They treated us very well & the food was awesome!
author: Robert M.

description: This little hole in the wall place is amazing! Super on point to what food in China is like. The price is not expensive and it's a great place for a fast meal. The food is mostly spicy and numbing so make sure to ask before you order if you don't like things too spicy. I highly recommend the Chong Qing Xiao Mian!
author: Amy W.

description: Nice place and good for a quick drop by lunch. But it feels like the food wasn't very clean or fresh. Yeah, I'm talking from my soon-after experience.
author: CJ Z.

description:
Chongqing Xiao Mian is the sixth effort by the ex-Z&Y pair that began by transforming The Pot Sticker into (now defunct) "Ma La Yi Pin" and later took over the venerable Uncle's Cafe (now Spicy King) down the street on Waverly Place. They also operate Spicy Queen in the Richmond, as well as outposts in San Mateo and Newark.  Unlike the other venues, Ma La Yi Pin #6, as its menu dubs it, is from the mian guan (noodle house) mold, focused on noodles and accompanying appetizers and side dishes As such, it is a more inviting place for people like me who fly solo and are just looking for noodles and a nosh without the guilt of occupying a space at a full-service restaurant promoting more elaborate and profitable dishes. In this respect, the Chinese mian guan is really the prototype of the ramen-ya.
 
Chongqing Xiao Mian was empty when I arrived at 2:00 PM on its opening day, though another couple of tables were filled while I was there. I pretended to study the brief menu, though I almost knew it by heart already, and wouldn't let myself order anything but the house's namesake dish, Chongqing xiao mian, to which I added an order of potstickers for protein. Based on a previous experience at another of the Wu-Du group's properties, I was poised to insist my spicy noodles come to me spicy, but the server had it covered: "It's very spicy," she said, and I assured her that was the way I liked it.

My bowl of Chongqing Xiao Mian did not disappoint. A veritable mountain of extruded fine noodles sat in a pond of chili oil augmented with a number of ground condiments and spices including Sichuan peppercorns, and what appeared to be garlic shoots. It was honestly spicy, eye-watering, nose-running spicy but not so much as to mask a complex flavor profile. The noodles themselves were fresh and al dente, and there was such a quantity of them packed into the bowl that I felt like I had consumed a whole Mission burrito, so sated was I after my meal. This is a bowl I will return for (after vetting some of CQXM's other offering).

As for the potstickers, they were pretty generic in shape, size and flavor, but well cooked with nicely browned facets, and tasty. I'm not sure if they were made in house; I began by asking the server that question, and she initially replied she didn't think they had them today, then checked herself and consulted the chef, who assured her they did. In any event, they filled the bill, providing some needed protein (and unneeded carbohydrate!).

Like some of the group's other branches, Chongqing Xiao Mian offers a whole range of regional noodle styles, including Guilin mi fen, Wuhan Hot Dry Noodles, liang fen, etc. along with other Sichuan classics. With such a range, one tends to be skeptical,  but since this branch is a noodle-focused enterprise I'm hopeful the chef knows what he's doing.
author: Gary S.

description: On arrival to San Francisco, we headed directly to Chinatown in search of a memorable place for dinner. Glad we went here. Food was very favorable and well seasoned. Noodles had a unique taste and spicy. The Couple's Delight is a mish mash of different meats in a spicy sauce; very tasty.
author: Van T.

description:
Sadly, not as amazing as I thought it'd be based off of the raving reviews. 

My friend and I came for an early dinner, hungry and ready to eat. We started with the cucumber and spicy beef tendon appetizers, and then ordered a bowl of tan tan noodles and a bowl of the beef with mustard green noodles to share. 

The cucumbers were tasty but tasted a little watered down and not as flavorful as I would have liked. The beef tendons were great, and probably the best part of the meal for us. Both bowls of noodles were sadly lacking in broth, by the end of the meal, the noodles had almost entirely absorbed any liquid in the bowls and the dishes resembled dry noodles instead of soup noodles. It was hard to distinguish any real difference in flavor between the noodles, with the tan tan noodles probably being a tad more flavorful. The beef noodles came with only 2 sad pieces of beef which was disappointing. 

Good for a cheap and quick meal, but don't expect it to blow your mind.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Get the pickled mustard green fish filet noodle soup. Die a happy person. This place is too underrated. Will sorely miss this place when I move to New York! 

3mo later: Am in New York. Still dream of this place
author: Thomas C.

description: A bit cramped and most but noodles and soup were on point. Especially for the price. Cucumber appetizer was tasty, and I'd recommend the spicy beef mustard noodles soup. We were seated quickly. My only reservation is that the waitress was busy, but once we ordered food was out in less than 5 minutes.
author: John Y.

description:
My gf introduced me to this place. Others very crowded here and the space is really small so expect to have to wait during peak dining hours. Also my gf spoke Chinese so we got better service than the other guests...it's a typical divey Chinese restaurant so definitely don't expect decent service. 

The noodle soups here are awesome. They make their own noodles. We also had many of the side dishes like the cold chicken, pickles cucumbers, and roasted jalapenos. The duck noodle soup was on the salty side but I wonder if that's how that particular soup is supposed to be prepared. I'm definitely coming here again!
author: Mai C.

description: I like this place. It has flavorful food. The wonton soup I got was delicious. As in the wontons tasted like it was freshly made. Some places have wontons that taste like they've been frozen and then dunked in boiling water prior to being served to me. But not here. I'll most definitely going to come back for more.
author: LeTran B.

description:
Nice clerks and good food.
But I think it tastes awkward to foreigners like me.
Anyway, generally good.
author: Ki Young S.

description: Amazing. Best value noodles in Chinatown. You get stuffed for 10 bucks and it tastes amazing. Get the Lamb or the traditional beef pickled green noodle soup. Also the squid is good and the numbing beef tendon is good!
author: Harry L.

description: Food was really good, service was a bit iffy but that's okay. Prices were reasonable too. Would recommend.
author: Nghi T.

description:
There is a sign in sheet so remember to put your name down at the front. We got seated pretty quickly because three tables of two left a few minutes after we got there, even though it is a very small place.

The food came out in around 15 minutes and daaaammn they look JUST as good as they taste. And let me tell you, it made my mouth water just by glancing at it. However, people who don't like spicy food should stay away because most of the menu here is spicy. And by spicy, I mean the numbing of your lips and the fresh minty feeling in your tongue kind of spicy. Exactly the way I like my food, so I was in love. I also took advantage of the black bean paste on the table because it added a nice touch to the noodles. 

The only complaint I do have is that the soup was very very oily. It also did not have much of it so it felt more like a sauce than a soup. 

Contrary to other reviews, I actually think they give very big portions here. I even had half the bowl leftover. The bowl was big and full of densely packed noodles, and I got 3 decently sized pieces of beef. And according to my Taiwanese companion, the beef was very authentic and similar to the traditional spicy beef noodles he gets in Taiwan. 

Overall, I will DEFINITELY come here again. Especially because some other options on the menu sounds really good! The table behind us left their hot and sour noodle soup untouched and unpacked to-go, though, so I'll probably skip that one.
author: Christine C.

description:
Saw the photo and review decided to give it a try. Ordered the spicy beef noodle and the soup was blend. Not spicy or flavorful. It was needing either more soy sauce or salt. 
Sad.. Looks better than it tasted.
author: Angela C.

description:
This place does the job for spicy noodles. I had my pick up order for spicy beef noodle. I just wish they separated the soup from the noodles. By the time I found parking to run in and grabbed the food and back home, the soup was soaked up. 

Friendly staff !
author: Cynthia N.

description:
The soup noodles were really bland.  There was no flavor and it was disappointing.

We asked for hot tea and our server advised us that they were still boiling the water.  They never brought it to us.

There's much better places in SF.
author: Adrian R.

description:
No taste. Seriously. 
Just noodle and meats in hot water with pepper oil.
 I'm a very easy eating person. I just eat almost of food whether it's suck. But noodles of here have 'NO FLAVOR'. I mean it's just hot water and pepper oil. That's all.
Even I didn't eat for 7 hours so I was starved a lot, I couldn't finish neither my bowl and my friend's one. Worse point is here is expensive than that shit taste. Here is shit.
author: Changmin L.

description: Phenomenal green onion pancakes. I would travel a great distance for those again so this is on my list of places to visit again.  The Tan tan noodles here are really unlike the ones we used to find at Hokkien and Cantonese places so I was a little surprised at the lack of peanut flavor and dryness of the dish but I'm sure the interpretation of this dish varies a lot. It was tasty and very numbing. The toddlers had a dish the owner suggested which was a beef broth with boiled peanuts and very plain noodles and they loved it as a non-spicy option.
author: Stacey C.

description: This is a traditional Chinese spicy noodle place, the taste is original and presentation is original too.  Another good place to visit in SF.
author: Craig Z.

description:
Brought 4 coworkers for a basic introduction to Sichuan food. Although my meat n' potatoes dining mates didn't seem to enjoy their meals, I was satisfied, but not overwhelmed. 

Having reasonable experience with Sichuan food, I wouldn't necessarily consider CQXM a dining destination. I expected my Tan Tan noodles to be more numbing, although the spice was nice. Oddly enough, I felt that the noodles and the cold chicken appetizer lacked sodium and that a touch more would have made the meal more enjoyable. 

This is not a place for a leisurely meal.  The service is extremely quick and efficient. Plates are cleared when there is a hint that its diner has cried "uncle" and checks delivered immediately after.  Waiting customers formed a line just inside the door, expectantly eyeing the diners.
author: David H.

description:
Get the tan tan noodles. They'll change your life.

I come here once a week and take all my friends and family who come here to visit. Quick, easy, and super cheap. Everyone so far has loved it. Can I give this place more than five stars??
author: Allegra G.

description: tan tan noodles.... so delicious. not overwhelmingly spicy but an awesome chili broth that makes your lips tingle. the broth is incredibly flavorful and the noodles are plentiful. the meat is perfectly salty and delicious. it's the perfect balance and incredibly perfect AND it's under $10 for a giant bowl. I'm ready to go back!
author: Baby J.

description:
This place charges you 18% tips if you are a group of 5. Yes, you read it correct, FIVE. Is the service good? Not at all. The waitress didn't serve anything,  including refilling tea, and barely wore smiles on face.
All in all, don't go here if you are a group of 5.
author: Bryce L.

description: Ughh... The food was horrible i was stupid for thinking the food was good but it went so so wrong and the tan tan noodle was oil and yes very VERY fat OIL and when i was drinking water while eating the noodle the water taste BAD and i knew it was the oil making me sick of it. I would rather have a diffrent kind of restraunt then this oily greasy noodle. But tbh the wonton was good atleast.... But the rest went were just bad.
author: Bright Boom L.

description: I really wanted to try this restaurant which claims that the Chongqing Xiaomian is authentic. But after I tried today, it disappointed me. I tried so many Chongqing xiaomian in Chongqing and Chengdu, and it's definitely not the one I though it will be. Secondly, the service is not good. Third, the cup I got had leftover, I asked for the change but they forgot. And fruit flies were flying happily on the table and shared the food with us. Forth, the green onion pancake is not crispy when it was served. However, the B.B.Q squid is okay.
author: Lanlin H.

description: Came in for lunch on a Saturday afternoon. The food quality was pretty good and did not take too long to come out. These noodles are more on the spicy side but there are non spicy options for the weaker folks out there. The place is on the smaller side so a big party would not work too well.
author: Dan C.

description:
The one star is so I can leave this review.
Service: -10 stars... waitress got annoyed when asked questions. Cut us off and said she is simply too busy to explain every single items in details for us. (We didnt ask her to)
Food: 2 stars. Noodles tasted ok but broth is too salty and super MSG based. Was sick from MSG OD for 2 days after.
Will not be back... too many of these restaurants around.
author: Mel T.

description: We came in for an early dinner, they have several different kinds of hot pot and also some good noodle soups. The noddle soup comes a huge portion and the soup is so delicious! Try some of their cold appetizers too, it'll surprise you!
author: Yan H.

description:
Authentic noodle dishes served up with a regional Chinese flare at very reasonable prices in a casual setting. 

The Chinese delight (4/5) was done well (it's slices of meat in a spicy oil)

The lamb skewers (3.5/5) were tasty but average (but I'm factoring the best that you might get in China so it's actually pretty good for SF). 

The Chong Qing Xiao Mian (4.5/5) was numbingly spicy and mostly just noodles and a few veggies but very tasty. 

The beef with sour/pickled veggies (5/5) was very tasty and less spicy than the chong qing xiao mian. It was a huge serving.

As a single person, you can be filled by just one bowl here. It's a great value and I'd definitely come back.
author: Victor W.

description: The noodle was fascinating! Got the tan tan noodle and the noodle with meat sauce. The flavor is very unique! Highly recommend for something warm and tasty to get in winter :)
author: Aracely V.

description: We got the vegetable dumplings, no meat noodles, and beef noodle soup. Very tasty, large portions, fast service, fresh ingredients. Definitely would recommend!
author: Christine E.

description: Went here on a whim while staying at a friend's place in Chinatown. The spicy beef noodle soup was awesome. The appetizers were nothing to write home about. I'd eat here again.
author: Michael B.
