description: Very high quality noodle and tasty soup! My friend recommended it to me and willl come again
author: Yinjia Z.

description: One bowl is enough for 2 people so this place is dirt cheap! Pretty good flavor and there's so many noodles you think you'll get tired of it but somehow you finish the bowl. The meat isn't the most flavorful but it is pretty tender so I can't complain too much either. The noodles are chewy and perfect and I would definitely come back!
author: Y W.

description: My family & I ate here over the weekend during our San Francisco trip. Everything tasted sour, rancid & greasy. The meat did not taste clean at all. Not going back ever again! We didn't eat at least half of the food. Giving two stars only because the the staff was friendly.
author: Allan T.

description: Mediocre at best. Would recommend passing on this if at all possible. Conveniently located though if you're near fidi
author: Phillip T.

description: Best noodle place ever in San Fran, can't wait to come back! Loved the pork and spicy beef , and the hot tea warmed my soul
author: Danna T.

description: Was very different from what we are used to in small town upstate NY but was pleasantly surprised. The stuffed pork mushrooms in brown sauce were delicious. The wonton soup was tasty with lemon and herbs and my husband loved peppered shrimp mushroom. The atmosphere was trendy with shared tables and the service was fast but very friendly.
author: Beth C.

description: We were looking for a quick bite before heading to the airport and found this place.  Not like any Chinese food I have had but I loved it!  I had the Tan Tan Noodles and it was awesome!
author: Roy O.

description:
I thought I could handle the spicy but I wave my surrender flag because I definitely cannot handle Sichaun spicy.

If you're looking for legit numbing spicy noodles- this is the place to go. I've never personally tried numbing spice so I wasn't sure what to expect. I typically like spicy foods like hot cheetos, boiling crab, etc. but this spice is a whole other category. It makes your tongue feel numb and tingly- feels similar to if you get analgesic gel from the dentist. I, on the other hand prefer a more chili type of spice? Like spicy where I can still taste the flavors, and feel pain, but not numbness. 

I ordered the Dan Dan noodles and my boyfriend ordered the pickled mustard green noodle soup. We both asked for light/mild spicy. Unfortunately, the light spicy was still too unpleasant for us because we don't like the numbing spice feeling at all.  The soup also didn't have much richness or savoryness to balance the spice. 

Overall, I wouldn't say this is a bad place, I think it's great if you really are looking for Sichaun spice. It's just not my preference/taste.
author: Kathleen Y.

description:
Four days old, and Chong Qing Xiao Mian is already bustling. I popped in during high noon and was seated immediately in the shared middle row of tables.

Big heaping bowls of spicy broth, lots of noodles, and there are urns of more chili oil to ladle on if you just can't get enough capsicum. 

I opted for the sour veggie fish noodles, and I was not disappointed. Big chunks of tilapia, plenty of pickled veg, and the noodles do a good job of soaking up all the broth. This is also one of the noodle soups here that aren't drenched in chili oil already, so you can ratchet up the heat yourself.

The staff is mainly Mandarin speaking, but Cantonese and English-speakers will fare well.

Everything is around $10.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Seriously, this place rocks! Real authentic Szechuan style food. Delicious! And if I'm not mistaken it's an all women run restaurant. 
I had the ginger duck noodle soup - the broth was so silky, delicious and smooth with the perfect amount of heat. I know I'm going to be dreaming of this tonight. 
The lamb skewers were so tender and perfectly seasoned with Szechuan peppers and cumin. They had a great kick. 
The vegetable noodle soup was so flavorful - I could drink the broth any time of day. 
The jelly bean appetizer was melt in the mouth good and the black beans accented the dish with the just the thought right amount of saltiness. 
The cold chicken Szechuan dish - the chicken silky soft and doused in this Szechuan chili oil with pickled bean sprouts. Amazing!
We had someone in our group that could not tolerate any chili spice, she had the dry noodle dish. Even that was very tasty. 
I must say I am super impressed with this cute little place and glad I avoided the other tourist traps in Chinatown. 
I will be back to try the many dishes that look and sound fabulous, especially the soups with the mustard greens.
Thank you!!!
author: Shamim R.

description:
Ate here for first time last night & based on observation this place is very popular (with a line outside by the time we finished dinner). You put your name on a paper list when you get there. 

Ordered the tan tan noodles...flavor was very good but by halfway through the dish found it too salty/possibly too much MSG. Took leftovers home for lunch...portion size was generous. In the future will order that, split it w/my party & share another main entree of something else for variety.

Also ordered scallion pancakes which served as a good palate cleanser from the spicy noodles, steamed veggies/spinach which was fine, and lamb skewers as appetizers. None of them were memorable but were fine additions to my meal. 

Smallish place, quick service.
author: D L.

description: Tan tan noodles were not too spicy and the flavor was, um, muddy. Not bright and distinctive as I would expect. I'd prefer them with less broth, I think. Service was quick but inattentive. We had to wait quite a while both to order and to get the bill - and this was during peak lunch when you'd think they'd be wanting to maximize turnover in the relatively small space. Once we ordered, food came promptly.
author: Matt J.

description:
There is no doubt that they got the Sichuan flavors on key. The Ma La (spicy numbing) taste is spot on and tastes delicious. However, it seems like everything has the same taste, which is the downfall for me. We ordered two bowls of noodles, egg rolls, and beef tendons. Of all things, why would I get egg rolls you would ask? Because they did not have the sweet tangy spare ribs (tang su pai gu) anymore and I wanted something as an appetizer. 

When the noodles came out, they smelled fresh and delicious. But after a couple of bites, I just got bored of the taste. The tendons were in a similar soup but a bit more refreshing ("leung" in Cantonese).

If you don't get tired of this taste, then this place is perfect because they do it well, no argument in that! Dono loved this place and is willing to come back for take-out (since I'm not too willing, haha!) I just personally prefer a variety of flavors.
author: Henry P.

description: 酸菜牛肉粉 Best spicy beef noodle soup that I ever had! Very authentic! Very spicy~ if you cannot eat spicy food, the 小锅米线 is really good too.
author: Mary W.

description:
Must admit that I accidentally told my friend to meet me at "Ching Chong Xiao Mian" ...smh, autocorrect.

Easily the best Spicy Beef Noodle Soup in all of SF. The beef is incredibly tender -- though the amounts vary based on how busy they are....

The spicy wontons are really soft, porky, and delicious.

The lamb skewers taste really good and do not smell or taste game-y.

Cucumber salad is pretty sweet, and I really enjoy it though I rather spend it on the green onion pancake. 

This place has always made me suspicious that it's the same owners as Spicy Queen and Spicy King. All the menus are the same and they have the same pens....interesante much?
author: Vi T.

description: This place has really good food!! It did take a while to get the check after requesting it. That being said, it was amazing food with a good atmosphere.
author: Nyx B.

description:
I'm overwhelming sad to write this review. My family is from Sichuan and I grew up with the strong salty, spicy flavors my province is known for. When I first visited this shop, I was elated. The flavors of the spicy noodles were so close to the street flavors I missed in China and I didn't think I'd find noodles made to such authenticity in San Francisco. I forced my boyfriend to come here nearly every week since then and he became a convert. 

So why the 3 stars? This establishment has changed so much. The past 3 times I've been here have left me disappointed. The once vibrant, numbing flavors of the noodles has turn into a generic salty slop of too many old chilies. I am a horrible Chinese cook. I know the taste of when I can't get the spiciness right and overcompensate by just lopping on more old chilies. I just didn't think I would have to experience that sort of neglect here. The flavors are not authentic anymore and this place has quickly become just another Sichuan(including Chong Qing) imitation restaurant. Probably why it's gotten such high reviews from people who have "eaten noodles in Beijing". 

If you are like me and miss you family and the painfully wonderful 川菜 back home, I would suggest you try Z&Y instead. They're not the best but better than here now at least. Chong Qing Xiao Mian - I know there are always problems with adjusting flavors or quality to meet the demands of the crowd you've started to draw. I just wish you knew how much your food meant before to people like me who saw it as the first nostalgic glimpse of my culture.
author: Katherine F.

description:
Finally, I found a place that serves authentic Hot and Sour Noodle! If they can add other toppings like minced meat and peanuts, it will be exactly as how I get it in Hong Kong. I also recommend ordering Tan Tan Noodles (Peanut soup based with minced pork), Spicy Beef Noodles (very flavorful and beef is tender), Sliced Pork Belly with Spicy Garlic Sauce (great appetizer), and Wonton in Spicy Chili Oil (very big portion). 

Service is good, but food takes a while because there's only two people in the kitchen.

Parking is also a hassle to find because it's Chinatown. The parking lot nearby costs $4 for the first hour, $6 for two hours.

There's also Spicy Queen on Geary Blvd, where parking is easier to find.
author: Melody L.

description: Best noodle joint in town. Never a bad meal here. And good service. Portions are large, prices reasonable. The noodle soups are pretty spicy!
author: J K.

description: Great service and selection. Ordered potstickers, green onion pancake, sweet/sour pork and mouth watering chicken. All delicious but could skip potstickers next time and will definitely come back for the noodles.
author: Sara L.

description:
At the edge of chinatown, you will get some very savory noodles from this newly opened restaurant. For people who are not familiar with chinese geography, chongqing is one of the area where the local LOVE spicy food. And the noodle from this restaurant is very spicy! [STAY AWAY IF YOU ARE NOT A SPICY PERSON!]

Anyway, for the two times that I was here, the noodles were good. The cooking time is short.[less than 10 mins for me]. And the price is reasonable!
author: Tianyi L.

description:
Portions are HUGE and there was a wait both times I've been. Restaurant is a little small and if you sit at the table in the middle of the room, you'll have to share the space. 

Noodles are just the right amount of spicy and I've tried the beef noodle and dan dan noodles. I got tired of the dan dan noodles after a few bites and the sauce was a little too salty for my liking. The beef noodle is my favorite but I wished they gave you more beef :( 

Also tried the spicy wontons but they're basically in the same sauce/spicy oil as the noodles so you're not missing out on much if you don't get them. 

Overall, noodles are thin and chewy with great spicy flavor. I love noodles so I'll probably be back here pretty often. I would most likely share a bowl of noodles and get a few appetizers next time.
author: Maryann S.

description: Let's talk about this Tan Tan noodle: hands down, the best I've tasted. Full of flavors. Then the famous Szechuan peppercorn numbing effect build and cleanse the palate. Every bite is like the first bite. The scallion pancake is also a plus. Very crispy. However, this must be an acquired taste. My boyfriend didn't like the after taste of the Szechuan peppercorn. He though the squid was awesome.We also tried the chicken. Delicious. The jelly was good too. More on the mild side. My least favorite dish would be the tendon. It's cut so thin that I didn't really enjoy the taste of it. Overall, I would return to try out he rest of the menu.
author: Ngan T.

description: The flavor that I have been missing so much!! Ordered noodle with peas & meat sauce and words failed to explain how thrilled I was!! I'm originally from a small town in Sichuan. And this is THE kind of noodle I used to eat for breakfast everyday.
author: Bilbo L.

description:
I would like to give this place 2 stars but I don't think that would be fair considering the fact that I dont have anything to compare this type of noodles with.  I went here with my boyfriend and we got the tan tan noodles and the single cooked noodles.  The place was packed and I thought that was a good sign. Everyone's food looked good so I didn't mind waiting a bit to try it.  When we're seated, we get seated very tightly close to other people which was a little annoying at first but I understood that there was limited space.  It's just a pain when you don't have elbow space.  When we got our food, it looked great but it was pretty disappointing. Both noodles were pretty bland and tasted like it was just a mixture of oil and spices which it probably was. I liked it at the first bite since I thought it had a nice kick to it but the more I ate it the more overwhelming it became.  Also, I thought they were serving us tea but it turned out to be just hot water.

Now, like I said before, I don't have another type of Chinese noodles to compare this to so maybe the noodles were made well and maybe just not my cup tea. As for the hot water, I'm not sure if it's a common thing to serve hot water that isn't tea so please feel free to correct me about anything if I come off as ignorant.  

Overall, I wouldn't come here again. My stomach started hurting after eating here and still hurts hours later.
author: Gwendolyn C.

description: I totally love this place! Thee Killer  authentic Szechuan style food! I lived in Hong Kong and Thailand and I'm sure it's similar in portions,noodle and soup selection as well as spice tolerance and fried as well as broiled or steamed selections.It's just the best! The beef bowl I had was very tasty as were the wontons I couldn't resist after seeing them go by twice! It's crowded,compacted and has some decor that's unusual.The service is good and would have to be to get people in and out in some reasonable time as there are people waiting to come in! I suggest if You want to try and get there if it's not spontaneous just when it opens.And try more than one soup! They have several that are truly authentic to mainland China!.
author: Brian D.

description:
Grand opening! 
I didn't expect the food portion is so huge. Price is pretty reasonable too.
author: Kevi O.

description: Probably the most authentic Chong Qing noodles I've had in the US. They also had some very traditional Chong Qing dishes that I've never seen anywhere else here in the states. Loved it!
author: Jane F.

description: Great new Chinese restaurant! Genuine hot and numbness flavor in Szechuan or Chongqing cuisine! I had Tan Tan noodles and the noodles were super elastic indicating hand made.
author: Xiang S.

description: The food was very good and the place was very clean. The service was quick, if somewhat snippy at times. Definitely would go again
author: Zachary H.

description: Great noodles. Walked out very satisfied and perhaps just a little too full! I ordered the noodles with the quale eggs and found it to have just the right amount of spice. First restaurant I tried here in Chinatown. Giving it 5 stars because all was good especially for the price.
author: Raul A.

description: Old school Szechuan noodles.  I liked the wontons in chili oil.  So it could be a spicier, and could use some numbing ma la in here, but this does seem like a stand out place in SF Chinatown.  Portions are plentiful, I think one order of tan tan noodles and one order of wonton in chili oil would be enough for three.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Delicious, numbingly spicy, authentic Szechuan food! Went here on a Wednesday night after work with a friend. Was pretty busy, and the place isn't too big, so expect a wait. 

Service and ambience were conversational and casual. I got the Tan Tan Noodles- a noodle soup with the uniquely numbing Szechuan peppercorn aroma and taste, a completely different experience from ramen, udon soup, and pho. The noodles and broth, combined with the tender pork, resulted in a delicious flavor with not too much spice or oiliness. A great dish to clear your sinuses if you're congested, or on a cold, foggy SF day. Some of the tastiest and most authentic Chinese food I've had!
author: Sharath R.

description: Love it! The Tan Tan noodles and the potsticker are the best. I have to hit this place every time I come to San Francisco.
author: Jamie M.

description: It's cheap, authentic, delicious, and fast. The beef tenderloin and BBQ lamb are bomb.
author: Stef G.

description: This is easily the best Sichuan food in the Bay Area that is according to my taste the must order for me is the guo qiao noodle and the pork belly. Cleaness and service is good. Will definitely come back.
author: James K.

description:
Oh man this place was yummy!

So... first things first. I wanted beef noodle soup. 

But the lady gave me pork spareribs instead. 

That being said, it wasn't bad at all. 

The noodles were SOOOOOO good and I loved the soup base. 

If you walk too fast you'd miss the spot; but I'd feel sorry for you if you did, because it's some great stuff!
author: Patricia A.

description: One of the best noodle soups I have eaten. We ordered ginger duck soup, spare rib braised noodle soup, and single noodle soup. The first two soups had the right amount of firmness that my son and I like. The amount of noodles and meat in each soup was good enough according to the price. Very authentic and flavorful.
author: Archna S.

description:
The restaurant is small, old. But GRET noodles! 
I also had kinda dumplings, those were good!
author: Yukie S.

description:
I'm so sad Yelp directed me here. 

My wonton soup tasted entirely like oil. Not spicy chili oil. Cooking oil.  

Nothing to write home about and would not recommend.
author: Lauren B.

description: I love this please so much, I go there almost three times per month. Because I am the top fan of spicy food and Chinese noodles which with peppercorn and chili oil. Highly recommend you to try the Chong Qing Xiao Mian there!!!!!! You will fall in love with it !!!
author: Kelly Z.

description:
This place makes me cry. Great Saigon, I will miss you. My favorite family-owned, family-run pho place used to be here. I was here a week before they got bought out. I'm upset that they no longer exist, and probably harbored some grudges towards this place for taking over... But I have to admit that they have good food. 

I came here on a super rainy Saturday night. Everyone here speaks Mandarin. We got a table for two and ordered the spicy beef tendon. Large amount of beef tendon, and very much worth the price. It was tender and spicy, but not too spicy. As we kept eating, we noticed that it got increasingly spicy but not to the point where it was unbearable. The tendons are marinated in a dark red spicy sauce with cloves. When you reach the end, be careful -- lots of cloves floating around and they're kind of bitter.

I ordered the Dan Dan Mian. I've had dan dan mian in Beijing, the capital of spicy food (besides Sichuan). Dan dan mian in Beijing is 2USD, so seeing the price tag for this was exorbitant in comparison. The noodles are chewy and cooked really well. I can't tell if these are handmade, but I have a feeling that they're not. There wasn't enough pork, and they included three pieces of cabbage? lettuce? The dan dan mian I had in China had a LOT of soup. This had some soup, but not enough. It wasn't a bad dish; I just wish there was more meat and soup. It does get increasingly spicy as you eat, and tastes good the entire time you eat it. It's not numbing spice, but just enough that you get a kick. It was okay. 

I'm still sorely missing Great Saigon. (Does anybody know where they went? If they opened a restaurant at another location? Please let me know!) While I miss that place, I think that this place is still good. The beef tendon really made me give it four stars. The dan dan mian is just average, but I've also had the real thing. If you've never had dan dan mian, I would recommend coming here to try it. Their other noodle dishes also look fantastic. I'll probably come back if I'm in the mood for spice, but there are other local businesses in Chinatown that I would love to support more than this place.
author: Nancy C.

description: This was a great noodle place. I had a spicy noodle dish, unfortunately I can't remember exactly what it was. The consistency of the noodles was very satisfying/tender. The atmosphere was lively and the service was good. I thought that, overall, this was a great restaurant to go to as part of our visit to SF's Chinatown; it definitely gave us an authentic feel for the place.
author: James K.

description: I always get the Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup as it is one of the few dishes in SF that manages to transport me back to Zhuhai 2009 when I worked in China for half a year as a contractor, post-Olympic glow.  The soup is numbing but never salty.  Great for hang-overs (which means I should really be coming here every day).
author: Paul M.

description: I came here on Wednesday for lunch. I ordered  sliced pork belly with spicy garlic sauce and pickle mustard green noodle soup with lamb. Both of them were just ok. Nothing special. The utensils, the table, and  teapot were not very clean. The price of the dishes is reasonable. Therefore, it worths 3 stars.
author: Viola C.

description:
2.5 stars. I was really excited to try this place, but it was a bit disappointing. Came at 11:15 to beat the crowds. Service is rude and they don't have a bunch of items on the menu anymore. It's not even properly crossed out. Just with a black pen with a line through it that you can barley notice. 

The tantan noodles-not enough broth, not that spicy, and noodles were too thin for my liking

Green onion pancake-needs to be more crispy

Spicy wonton-this was in a huge bowl of red sauce-looked super spicy and it seemed more like a soup since there was so much sauce-it actually wasn't even that spicy and the meat is super skimped. I mainly taste the wonton skin. 

The grilled squid-that wasn't bad and it was a huge portion. 

I won't be back. Not sure why everyone likes this place. I'd rather pay way more for better food. (I heard Spicy King is way better, so that will be next on my list)
author: Karen H.

description:
Spicy beef noodle soup is quite good - soup is flavorful, beef is tender. MUST ORDER. 
Tan Tan Mien - never had it before, it was pretty good but I like the beef noodle soup better due to the portion of beef (only has a small amount of ground beef). 
Single cooked noodle - the noodle consistency is more slippery, pieces of pork. Again I still say spicy beef over this. 

Service isn't that great. But I will go for taste of food over service.
author: sharon s.

description: A nice dining location on the edge of old Chinatown.  It's going to be moving soon into a larger venue on Jackson in the coming months.  Hopefully, it keeps the same updated look!  The food is not bad.  Not as spicy as I thought it was going to be so some northern Chinese people may feel its not spicy enough.  But it's fine for "Cantonese" spicy.  The lamb skewers were kinda of small.  I'm used to large chunks of meat / kabobs like Xinjiang style.  But overall a good place for some fast noodles.
author: Cary L.

description: Had me some delicious spicy Szechuan noodles twice in 4 days recently and I have no regrets. My favorite so far is the dan dan mien and green onion pancake. Came here after a happy hour on a Friday night and was super happy they were still open for dinner. Service is pretty quick and the noodles themselves taste super fresh. Will be back again when I'm looking for some numbing action.
author: Clinton L.

description:
Let me start by saying that this place probably has the most authentic and best tasting noodles I've ever had in the States. I came here at 1:30 PM on a Saturday with a friend. The place was pretty packed, but the waitress asked if we'd mind sharing a table and we happily obliged. Everything looked amazing on the menu, and all the pictures on Yelp do not do this place justice.

I got the pork rib noodles, whereas my friend got the beef noodles (a more traditional noodle dish). The noodle itself was firm even after sitting in the broth for a while, this is how I knew it was quality stuff. They ran out of the lamb skewers, which I was really looking forward to having, but the BBQ squid was an excellent side dish nonetheless. 

The broth was just right - not too rich, but packed with flavors. The bowl was still a bit hot when I finished. I might have burned myself a couple of times but it was literally that good. 

Can't recommend this place enough! There were people waiting outside by the time we finished, which we were surprised by, since it was well past lunch time. But that's how you know this place is legit! Can't wait to go back
author: Zhen L.

description: First time try this place, they have so many different kinds of noddle. Since I'm the noddle lover, me & my friend we order 3 different noodle. The best one is the Guilin rice noodle.
author: Yueming G.

description: Having tried Chongqin xiaomian in Chongqin, I can endorse this place for its authentic and delicious noodles.
author: Breeze G.

description:
Dear Chong Qing Xiao Mian,
Please put back the couple's delight wrapped with green onion appetizer!!! :)

My husband and I tried the spicy beef noodle soup and the pork bone noodle soup. Both soup broths were very tasty and the noodles were cooked very well. But just a heads up, the pork bone noodle soup does NOT come with any meat and there was only maybe 3 pieces of beef in the spicy beef noodle soup. We ended up ordering a side order of spicy tendon to accompany our noodle soups. But aside from the lack/skimp of meat, they were both still delicious bowls of noodle soup and I would still come back to try out their other items.
author: Katherine C.

description: Two stars. The sour and spicy noodle was only sour. The meat was cold and not tender.
author: Han F.

description:
The spicy beef noodle with pickled mustard greens deserves 4 stars, but overall I'd give it a 3.5

Lamb skewers smelled deliciously spiced, but tasted bland. It was juicy and fatty though.

The wonton in chili oil was strange. It's not really a chili oil version of HK wonton soup (also, it doesn't come with noodles and the wontons are puny), but nor was it the traditional 紅油抄手. Broth was tasty though.

It's the numbing kind of spicy, which may not be everyone's cup of tea. Dishes come out fast.
author: Julia C.

description: Dunno if it's authentic since I'm Cantonese, but definitely tasty. Highly recommended.
author: Kaylie C.

description:
I don't think I've been this disappointed in a restaurant in a long time. The service was SO slow. They took everyone else's order before our table even though others came in after us.

In terms of food: the noodles in the dan dan mian tasted like packaged ramen noodles and the sauce was nothing special. The short ribs so so beyond dry despite being advertised as braised. The spicy wontons were lackluster at best but the most satisfying dish of what we ordered.
author: Anna T.

description:
This restaurant has a cute small dining area with festive decorations.  The service was alright but it took a little while for the waitress to take our order.  After that, our two bowls of noodles arrived very very quickly.  We ordered Tan Tan Noodles and Spicy Beef Noodles; each bowl was $9.95 and packed with a dense amount of fresh noodles.
The Tan Tan Noodle is more of a saucy dish--topped with, I think, minced pork--rather than a soup since the peanuts add a rich thickness.  The Spicy Beef noodles had about six thick chunks of beef that fell apart in your mouth and two chunks of turnip.  The broth has a "Taiwanese-esque" taste to it and had a good amount of heat to make you sweat a little bit.  Both dishes are very authentic, hearty, and in bowls of noodles to get in Chinatown!
author: Ashley Y.

description: Surprise surprise, the food exceeds my expectation and is pretty authentic, gui lin mi fen is very food. The service is good too. The z&y across street is fucked up with its service and food, and I am glad that I found this better place. Will come back again next time I am in the area.
author: Charles Z.

description: San Francisco lacks decent Chinese food, this place is an exception. I was going to Z & Y but parked in front of Chong Qin Xiao Mian, lured in by its menu and decided to give it a try. It did not disappoint. All I craved I found them here. Dandan noodles- taste from my childhood and my hometown. Guilin noodles- the pickled long bean is perfectly sour and opens up appetite. Sweet and sour pork - 5 dollar goodness! Spent 38 dollar for 2, way too full and content
author: Ge Y.

description:
It gets busy. I like the limited menu. You must like spicy food! 

We got:

The BBQ Lamb Skewers were exceptional with the exception for a bone in one of the pieces.

The Spicy Beef Noodle Soup was good except they skimp out on the toppings (3 pieces of beef).

The Guiling Rice Noodle Soup was good as well.

4 stars minus 1 for the bone.
author: Peter L.

description: Lines at my usual favorites were long, so I ended up here. What a pleasant surprise. Best noodle bowls I've encountered in the Bay Area. Also a great spot for a quick meal. My food was ready in a few minutes. Had the beef noodle bowl with the quail egg. It was very flavorful. Texture of the noodles was very nice. The texture of the meat was delicate like an exquisite pot roast. Will be back.
author: John M.

description: I ordered the duck noodle soup and my girlfriend ordered the beef noodle soup with pickled mustard and we both loved it! It's pretty spicy, so make sure you have enough tolerance. But I would definitely come back here for some reasonable eats.
author: David G.

description: The noodles look spicy but it was not as spicy as what I've imagined!!!!!!!!! I ordered Guilin rice noodles and a 酸辣牛肉面 for my boyfriend and they BOTH TASTED SO GOOD!!!!!! Believe me, you should try that 酸辣牛肉面 for sure.
author: Annabelle L.

description:
I've been pleasantly surprised by the food at the Sichuan/Southwestern Chinese restaurants in the city. It's even more impressive that this joint has Wuhan's Re Gan Mian (Hot Dry Noodle) on the menu. The noodle soups were not too spicy, which I guess, is tailored to the local SF palate, but if you ask them to spice it up, it'll come close to the authentic flavors of Sichuan and Chongqing. The side dishes are delicious as well, and perfect to share with a small group. But the portions make it easy for one person to finish a bowl of noodle soup and a side dish all by themselves!

Only complaint is they seem to be understaffed when it comes to seating people, but the food comes out fairly quickly. If the waitstaff don't seem to notice, it's best to be more assertive and call them to your table.
author: Jessica L.

description: Great food. It's funny that this place is full of Chinese all the time whereas the next door house of nan jing is full of non-Asian all the time.
author: Yaqi S.

description: If I could give 3 1/2 stars I would, I am rounding up. Great food! This place was recommended to us by our Uber driver. He indicated that I should stay away from Chinatown for food and to try this place for authentic Chinese. The prices were very reasonable for the city (bonus) . I did not recognize the menu items here from other Chinese restaurants I've been to- there was nothing to compare. I like that concept. The things I did recognize were : pork, noodles and spicy. Unfortunately, the servers were very short tempered and rude and that's why we didn't give five stars. We were the only Caucasian people in the restaurant and totally touristy, maybe that was the reason? Overall, it didn't really matter I was able to overlook her poor attitude. The pork noodle dish that I ordered was incredibly flavored, something I've never tasted before and very hard to describe. It was definitely very salty and very spicy, which I liked very much. My son had a duck noodle dish which had lots of bones that he had to navigate through. That was a little difficult for him. He tasted my dish and said mine was better. When I asked the server what vegetables were in the dish she said "Chinese vegetables". I gave up in asking questions and took the leap. We wanted to try the short ribs because another table had those as an appetizer, they look so delicious. I was afraid we would have too much food. I would definitely recommend this place for an adventurous palate. If you are a traditional American food/American Chinese food type person and you're not adventurous I recommend staying away. The food experience we had outweighed the negativity given to us by the servers.
author: Amber S.

description: Reasonably priced, quick service, amazing food! My boyfriend got the "beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup" which was spicy but really flavorful. I got the wonton soup in chicken broth. Spring rolls were great as an appetizer! Would highly recommend this place
author: Hannah K.

description: My second visit 4 months later: the noodles were a lot springier, and less mushy and gross. The meat portions are also slightly more generous. Still, though, a film of MSG powder settles in your mouth after a meal here, as if you'd binged on Flaming Hot Cheetos instead of food made from natural ingredients. The environs are just as stressful as greasy and awkwardly trafficked as ever.
author: Ken H.

description:
Picked this one straight from Yelp recommendations and turned out great! Food was great, portions are small - so double up if you're sharing. 

Standard stuff like pot stickers and spring rolls were very good, but Wuhan Hot Dry Noodle and Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle were excellent. Lamb skewers we're decent too!
author: C F.

description: The Chong qing Xiao mian is very plain, just spicy sauce and noodles, but that's the way it is. Maybe dan Dan noodle and re gan mian would be better. Didn't impress me. Taste ok.
author: Xin G.

description: Their tan tan noodle and beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup is packed with flavor. I highly recommend coming in to try this place if you are a a fan of noodle and spicy!
author: Ally C.

description: Literally so good. I went during lunch time and while there was a wait, it'll literally take them two minutes to bring you a bowl of hot steaming soup noodles. These are by far the best noodles I have had in the Bay Area~~~~ but, my friend did say she got food poisoning from this place...so eat at your own risk
author: Jessica J.

description: I love this noodle restaurant! It's small but very friendly! I had Guilin Noodles, I was a bit disappointed since the noodles were not homemade. However, the sauce in there was very tasty. My husband's noodle dish was very good! Will go back there again!
author: Wen T.

description:
The food might be good but service leaves a lot to be desired. 
The server basically ignored me and took orders from everyone else because my husband was not at his seat waiting in bathroom line. When confronted, she said something in Chinese. Hey lady, maybe spend less time on putting make up that doesn't look right and more time training yourself on customer service.
author: Shayla L.

description: Yesterday, I ordered the chicken feet, eat like eating salt, oh, no, even salty than salt，Disappointed
author: Yanci K.

description:
I tried an odd ball menu item so maybe this faults on me. I had the Fish Mustard Greens and the Scallion Pancakes to go. The fish was bland (at least it was soft and nice texture). The noodles were boring, had no bite, a bit too watery (and yes, I ate the noodles as soon as I picked up the package. The soup base was lacking substance, it was lame. And to top it off, the scallion pancakes were a bit charred and chewy. 

Yeah, for $16 bucks, I expect much better. Sorry.
author: Ashraf A.

description: Five stars for the fish rice noodle I ordered. It's spicy and very tasty. It's very hot and I was in a hurry so I had to take to go. Container is charged at 30 cents each. I needed two. Service is non existent even though the young girl who took my order and brought my food was pleasant. Some other people came at 8:40 and were turned away saying they are closed even though they close at 9pm. Not even to go orders are allowed 20 mins before closing so I recommend going at least 45 mins before closing to be safe on getting your spicy noodle craving satisfied!  Generous on the toppings. The food is definitely worth waiting in line for!
author: Corinne Z.

description:
I really doubt that the two chefs in the cover of the menu are just false advertisements! 
粉蒸肉(new dish, not on the menu) is totally not Sichuan style & taste, but Northern style with unfresh pork. 老妈蹄花(new dish, on the board)  just uses the name & reputation of Chengdu authentic one, which will never use kelp in trotters soup and the soup looks like milk. Even homemade trotters soup will be better than that. 夫妻肺片 is no better than others. I don't believe that these dished are made by Sichuan or Chongqing cooks.

Besides, the waitress misled us to order more dishes than we need. She said 粉蒸肉 was so small that we need to order one more dish, but she never told us there were SIX pancakes in it!

Both of us are from Sichuan. Very disappointed! No next time & no recommend！
author: Tina Z.

description: For the lines and the hype, I was disappointed by the food here. I got the dry noodles, which did not taste like Szechuan food that I'm used to. Their couples dish (fu ji fei plan) was good but also not very spicy. In general, for a Szechuan place, their dishes were not very spicy and most noodles lacked meat.
author: Horatia F.

description: Great bowls of noodles. There was a wait to get a table but not too long. The BBQ spare ribs were good too, although different than I'm used to.
author: Bob C.

description: This place is always amazing! You have to try the pork belly appetizer, it is a little spicy and super tasty. I've been making my way through the menu of delicious noodle soups and so far my favorite has to be the duck. Lots of flavor! Food comes out really fast and prices are very affordable. I will keep coming back to this place for warm comfort food!
author: Nicole D.

description: Chong Qing style noodles galore. We ravaged a bowl of the Tan Tan and the Ginger Duck Noodles. The portions are generous and the flavors are on point. Delicious stuff, it's downright addicting.
author: Yoni Z.

description: Slow day at work? Time for a long lunch. We arrived around 11:15am to no wait (but it was very crowded around noon). I ordered the Tan Tan Noodle ($9.95) which including chewy al-dente noodle, spicy sauce, and finely ground pork. Szechuan food has this great numbing spice. It doesn't burn and you don't feel it right away but it certainly builds. I wouldn't be intimidated though; just take your time eating it. My co-workers ordered the Beef Noodle Soup which had very similar noodles but a soupier base.
author: Tammy T.

description:
Pretty authentic spicy Chinese food that's large in portion and not overpriced. I went with two friends and we ordered just enough food for the three of us with only a little leftover. It's a small restaurant and when we went on Monday night, it was packed, but the turnover was fast-- it's definitely more of a get in, get out establishment. The sole waitress that night handed us menus as soon as we sat down, but we ended up going up to the counter to order because we saw other people doing the same. Not sure if this was because the waitress was swamped though...
 
Dine-In:

- Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle (重庆小面) 
This came to the table first and we devoured it in minutes. The spice builds and it was so good I dreamed about it and ordered it for lunch pickup today. 

- Beef in Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup (there are two, but we ordered the 老壇酸菜牛肉面) 
Make sure to eat this as soon as it's served because the noodles will get soggy if they sit in the broth for too long.  The soup base was tasty, but you didn't really taste or see the pickled mustard, save for the tiny little fragments here and there.  They gave around 4 pieces of beef and a couple of bok choy slices.

- Appetizers: Couple's Delight (夫妻肺片), Slice Pork Belly w/ Spicy Garlic Sauce (蒜泥白肉), Chicken Feet w/ Pickled Pepper (泡椒凤爪) 
These weren't too spicy, probably 1.5/5 (except for the chicken feet, which is just sour/tart and not spicy at all).  The Couple's Delight was great; standard and good texture.  The pork belly was a bit too sweet for my liking but delicious nonetheless. The chicken feet was a hit with my friends (I'm not as big a fan of sour dishes) and the texture was perfect.

Drinks:
The Ice Soy Milk actually comes by the glass and not by cans as the menu states. I think the waitress said the soy milk and plum juice actually come in big bottles and they just pour out glasses for you. They're not housemade sadly. The tap water comes with a lemon slice though!

Takeout:
I called in an order of 2 noodles on a Wednesday and they said to come by in 15 minutes. When I got there at around 11:30, only 2 tables were occupied (so if you're craving Chinese for lunch, it's a good time to go!) I timed it so there was minimal wait time, but my Chong Qing Noodles got a little soggy anyway. These came in a no-ventilation hole plastic container with sauce on the bottom and noodles on top. It still hit the spot, but I have to note that it was less spicy than our dine-in experience.

My friend ordered the Pork Bone Broth Noodle Soup (骨汤小面), which was very flavorful and wasn't spicy at all.  This came with the noodle and soup separate. They don't give much soup for takeout, so it might be better to eat in if you plan on drinking the soup as soup.
author: Lily D.

description: The food here is amazing and affordable. I just got really grossed out one time because there was a big cockroach roaming the floor. After I saw it, I couldn't enjoy my meal anymore. They should clean the place.
author: Yna D.

description:
Authentic tasting and much better than most of the Chinese food I've had in the bay area. Good flavors. Large portions, especially for the price (25ish dollars fed us both with some leftover). Clean and friendly staff. 

Unexpectedly good! If you are feeling some warm hearty noodle dishes definitely give this place a try.
author: Emily H.

description: Amongst an assortment of Chinese restaurants that are a little less then authentic this one stands out as a genuine noodle house with the feel and taste of a real Asian street food establishment. Won ton chk soup was our favorite.
author: Dave S.

description:
This place is on the main drag just on the outskirts of Chinatown.  Small place but service is quick. The noodles are awesome!!  Had the hot and sour noodle and cold noodles.  Everything spicy but soooooo flavorful.  TWo women cook and you feel like you're in the kitchen.  The broth is chili based, not the typical chicken broth I'm used to....

Will come back!
author: Frank S.

description:
With Chongqing style noodle soups and side dishes that are this perfectly numbing and spicy, I guess I can overlook the bad mannered service that is characteristic of many Chinatown restaurants. ;p

The friends who work near here who have tried this place have all raved about it. I can now see why. My mouth is watering again even as I am typing this review. It really is that good and you really have to try it for yourself to see.

Here were the dishes that I tried and none disappointed:

The Chong Qing Xiao Mian - Absolutely delicious. My only vice is that it has too much noodles but it was so good that I finished it all anyway.

Couples Delight (side dish) - I only wish the size was bigger. Definitely did not get enough of it.

Sweet and Sour Pork (side dish) - Acted as a perfect alleviator to all the numbing-ness and spiciness of the other two dishes.

Can't wait to go back and again. I heard the beef noodle soup with pickled veggies is to die for. ;)
author: Nancy Y.

description: Arrived at 5 minutes before closing n they seat  us but tell us to hurry n order cuz theyr closing in 5 minutes with a restaurant full of people.... so we gladly left n went to 925 Kearney at house of Xian dumpling and gladly racked up a bill of $120+.....Best food n service Ever
author: Macie Q.

description: The spicy noodles are very tasty.  Texture is very good too.  But the ground meat disappears when you mix the noddles.
author: Byron L.

description:
Based on the pictures, I came to try the Guiling Rice Noodle Soup for $9.95.  The soup comes with Beef, Bok Choy, Quail Eggs, and Peanuts.  The soup is not spicy at all.

Since I got it to go, it didn't have a lot of broth when I was able to eat it.  And, the beef was a bit dry.

While I would give the dish a 2.5, I believe it would taste better if I were able to eat it at the restaurant.  What little broth there was had a nice flavor.

I'll be back to try more dishes and adjust my review accordingly.
author: Roy C.

description: This place serves authentic Szechuan style food (judging as a native Chinese from Szechuan) with reasonable price and amount.
author: Tim L.

description: Their cold and hot noodles are all SO FREAKING DELICIOUS. The Tan Tan noodles are a little spicy (by my standards) but so satisfying. One of my friends thought the soup was a little oily but I loved it. Great quality and a good price.
author: Kelly T.

description: This restaurant was a disappointment.  The noodles were well cooked; however the broth wasnt great.  There was no delicacy...very overpowering and one-note.  The spicy chili oil is overcooked.  AVOID IF POSSIBLE.
author: Max S.

description: The duck noodle soup is the perfect choice if you want something delicious and filling that isn't too spicy. The Dan Dan noodle is also delicious but not for the faint of heart.
author: Chris M.

description: I'm not normally impressed by the food I get in China town but this is the only place that I'm dying to go back again. It's very authentic and so good.
author: Annie W.

description: Mom is from Chongqing; this place gets a thumbs up for authenticity. There's a wait during peak hours and the place isn't that big, but it's one of the nicer places in the area without being ridiculous in pricing. All but two of us got noodles - those came out way faster than the other dishes. There's a big communal table in the middle; gets to be fun if that's your thing.
author: Joy Y.

description:
Seriously some of the best noodles I've ever had. Ordered the Tan Tan Mian and the beef tendon appetizer.
The beef tendon was shaved thin and texture and taste was flavorful and delicious as a cold appetizer. The prices on the appetizers are outstanding. Looking forward in returning to devour more authentic noodles.
author: Chris M.

description: Wonderfully spicy Chinese food. Come here for good authentic Chinese food, and be ready to get spiced out! We came in on a weekday night and sat down instantly. Ordered 3 apps (cucumbers, wine chicken, and sweet & sour spare ribs), and then the Guilin rice noodle soup (not spicy at all!) and braised beef with rice (comes as a bowl of beef soup and a side of rice, not beef on rice). I'm definitely going back, and it's some of the more authentic Chinese food I've had in the area. Don't expect superior service or fortune cookies, but look forward to some great food.
author: Tony C.

description: i had the beef in pickled mustard green noodle soup.  super hearty, sufficiently spicy, great ingredient variety and proportions, succulent and delicious.  we also tried a spicy beef tendon dish with a very interesting texture and style, worth a try
author: Gonzalo S.

description: The duck soup had duck that was too salty. The Dan Dan noodles was good. What was nice is that this type of cuisine is usually completely dominated by spiciness/hotness. Here, you could still taste other flavors besides the hotness. Service could have been a lot more hospitable. It was curt and on the unfriendly side, but perhaps if the food is good enough no one cares.
author: Alex D.

description: I love this place so much! The taste of both appetizer and noodles are awesome! The taste is really good and I would say it's the place with best chili oil as far as I know. But it's really spicy. If you can not handle very spicy food, reconsider about it.
author: Katherine J.

description: I will definitely give 5 stars for the food here. But their service is not quite good, maybe I shouldn't choose peak hour to go to the restaurant.
author: He M.

description: If you are hungry and on a budget downtown SF, then show up to this place. It is a very small place, so don't be surprised if you have to share a table with strangers. Completely worth it, because I came out of that place feeling full and fantastic and it didn't cost me a bunch of money.
author: Luke C.

description: The food is very good, and quite authentic. I visited to Chengdu, China a couple years ago & I felt transported back via the food. But authenticity does have some drawbacks for me. Specifically, if you order any of the appetizer dishes then you need to expect there are going to be a lot bones in your chunks of meat. That is not why I gave four instead of five stars however. They missed five star rating because they are simply under-staffed. The place is was very busy & there were only two waitresses running their butts off. I know they were trying but the overall service experience suffered.
author: Tom K.

description: Tastey smokey spicy! Got the duck ginger and husband got beef and mustard green soup. Quick device and piping hot food. I just wanted to curl up and fall asleep after a filling warming meal.
author: Jenna K.

description: Beef noodle was the best! We just flew in from Chongqing, China and it tasted just like the Sichuan dishes we are familiar with. My wife from Chongqing loved it as well! A+ place if you need your Sichuan food fix. Highly recommend!
author: Kyle D.

description: Got the Tan Tan Noodles. Wished they served more meat in the dish, but still quite tasty.
author: Wayne S.

description: Food is flavorful and prices are good but pretty oily and greasy. Also they don't serve or permit any alcohol. Also very hot.
author: Eric W.

description: Loved it. Got pork intestines in hot and sour soup with noodles. I like that there were pork intestines cause it's hard to find. Really genuine szhechuan flavors but too much peppercorn for me.
author: Ke D.

description: Great noodle spot my family and I stumbled upon. Very small and simple place to get spicy noodle soups. While no room to wait for seating, our first time was not a good one. Had no idea there was a clipboard to sign our name for us to be seated, we were the 2nd party to be seated. Another party came after us and because they spoke the same language as the waitress, guess the waitress had asked her how many in her party and told them that they had a table ready. The lady politely said in English, "no that's okay they were here before us" (pointing at us; 2 babies 2 adults also a party of 4). Then the waitress said to the lady"are you sure??" Like as though she would seat them first anyway. Mind you, that same waitress watched us come in the door earlier. Not a fan of favoritism, luckily there are some good standing people that do the right thing. Besides the drama, this is a great spicy noodle spot, flavors are good.
author: Kris L.

description: Intense, efficient service.  We ordered a bunch of things that we thought might be delicious but unusual.  Everything was delicious and presented rather quickly, even though the place was jammed.  The soup-with-pork-ribs was a bit challenging to eat, but we figured it out eventually.  All in all, I'd definitely go back.  It was tasty and fun.
author: David B.

description: Way too much MSG! I got massive headaches after eating from this place and to boot, food was so so (compared to authentic cuisine).
author: Sam C.

description: Great tan tan noodle dish. My first time having it! I'll definitely be looking for it on other menus. Service was fast despite the crowded restaurant. I wish I could go back to try other dishes, but sadly I was only here for business. Next time!
author: Emma H.

description: This place is amazing! We got the chongqing xiao mian and the single pot rice noddle. Both delicious.
author: Ran L.

description:
This place is beyond good ! Even if you don't like
spicy food. This place is a most try. The guilin rice
noodles are out of this world good. The soup is
super tasty. The brisket cooked to perfection; and the 
noodles are at just the right thickness. I've gone
three days in a row and don't feel satisfied.
author: Chris L.

description: The place is good in general but I guess it's just not my taste. The Chongqing Xiaomian is just noodle with few cabbages in a broth full of chilly oils... It might be popular in part of China (which I have a hard time to imagine) but definitely not for me. We also ordered Fuqi Feipian and Koushuiji. All of them are greasy and full of chilly oil. It's not too spicy though I'm just not a big fan of such kind of cuisine. Not very good for my stomach. Besides the greasiness and spiciness, the dish is generally bland which I think is far from the true level of Chinese cuisine. Service is good though. Just not a big fan of the dish personally.
author: A B.

description: Food is very good spice numbing noodles, five spice beef, and dumplings were tasty. The heat hits you after wards and numbs your mouth which is why you go there.
author: N A.

description: Ordered Dan Dan Noodle. This is probably the best I have had in the San Francisco Bay Area. Simply delicious and strongly recommend to everyone who crave for spicy food.
author: Y C.

description: We went pretty standard here just to get an idea of how their cooking was: Dan dan mien and spicy beef noodle soup with cucumber salad to start. Let's just say that their flavorings were the closest I've had to what they use in Chengdu. They are not shy with the five-spice and sichuan peppercorns, but do not overdo it to the point that your tongue is simply numb. And the cucumber salad (always one of my favorites was fantastic). They used plenty of green onion and cilantro, the latter of which you don't see too often in chinese cooking, and tons of garlic (AWESOME!). Can't wait until my next trip into the city to hit this place up again and try some of their more interesting dishes like the Wuhan hot dry noodles or the house cold noodles.
author: Juan C.

description: My favorite authentic Chinese Sichuan restaurant. The noodles are not that spicy but super flavorful. I love the gan guo mi xian, spicy beef noodle, and mustard green noodle are the best. The lamb skewers are also super flavorful. Make sure on weekdays to get there before 7 or there is a line.
author: A B.

description: Food is decent but service is awful. If you want service here, be prepared to work for it. Wave those arms in the air to get your server's attention, but don't be surprised when they make eye contact and then continue to ignore you. As if to let you know "yes, I've seen you. I'm not responding not because I don't see you. I do see you." Eye contact does not mean they will come talk to you. Additionally don't think they are eager to take your money after you've eaten either. Ask at least 4-5 times for your bill, if you really want it. They will even respond and say "Bill, yes. Ok" but don't believe them. It's not coming.
author: Freedy H.

description: relatively new spot from the owners of spicy king, i believe, who also have a few other authentic spots in town.  on the edge of chinatown / north beach, the restaurant is about the size of a large san francisco studio, with a small kitchen in the back where all the magic happens. there are 2 waitresses, and 2 ladies gossiping and cooking noodles and everything else on the menu. when i stopped by on a saturday around 1 pm, the place was packed! and all the customers were chinese/asian - there was a lot of mandarin spoken, so this spot is clearly legit/authentic.  i perused the menu and ordered the sweet & sour spare ribs and the tan tan noodles. you get a jug of water with your glass - amazing.  the noodles came out piping hot - noodles are softer than ramen, which is expected, and the spare ribs were hot and portion was good for the price. my only complaint is that noodle to broth ratio is not great - too much carbs for the little bit of delicious spicy broth in the bowl, and there are only 2 pieces of bok choy in the whole bowl. next time i will be requesting more veggie.  will definitely be back though to try the other items on the menu - everyone's orders looked amazing!
author: Christina L.

description: Super great noodles and average service. Turnover rate is fast, too. We ordered Hot and sour noodle soup and Guilin (rice) noodle and both are awesome not just because of the toppings.
author: Luna Z.

description: Delicious!  We got the Lamb Skewer, BBQ Lamb Chops, and Chong Qing Xiao Mie.  All of them were great!
author: Sherwin G.

description: Pretty spicy menu.  Good for me.  Challenge for wife.  Both leaving happy.  Would be a challenge with kids.  Fast courteous and affordable.
author: Bobby J.

description: Oily noodles with no flavor . An unimpressive attempt to copy the trendy Xiao Mian fever but turned out to be worse than instant noodles. Not recommended.
author: Daisy W.

description: The flavor is great but the server... The lady with short brown yellow hair is rude to customers. 1. She didn't clean the table when last customers left and directly put the menu and tissue on the table for me. 2. I gave a sign to order but she didn't answer three times when she passed my table. 3. Then suddenly she was rude to ask what do you want in my back. 4. When she put the dish on the table, she just put on the right corner near my arm when I was eating. Very shame on her:(
author: Yiqian L.

description: One of my favorite noodle place in Mission, real authentic Chongqing flavors and reasonably priced. Great for family and friends get together.
author: Lulu W.

description: My family is from that area in China and I thought  this place had really delicious, authentic food! The chili oil was smoky and an appropriate amount of spicy. We got the tan tan noodles, couple's delight, and sweet and sour spare ribs. Could have done without the spare ribs but it was still ok.
author: Amy Y.

description: Food was good, however we had to wait 1 hour to eat, which was fine, everyone had to wait, we sat down then the ladies took order then brought food, restaurant was busy so there wasn't really any service, I typically tip based on the service received so I felt like not tipping much after I ate, I just paid whatever the food cost with a credit card, and was going to leave a couple dollars on the table, the lady ridiculously brought back my bill and educated me on how "this is America and you tip after you eat", that totally ruined my impression of the restaurant, I always tip, AND I live in America, then people in the kitchen start saying "tipping is mandatory in America". Not sure if it's a San Fransisco thing or what, not happy with this restaurant
author: Ying G.

description: This is probably the best noodle i've ever ate in US.. Especially the tantan noodle & the wonton.. The noodle is soo chewy ,while the broth is super tasty.. Highly recommended!! I give this noodle house 100 out of 10
author: Juanda P.

description: What a wonderful cheap, authentic Chinese restaurant! This was our first time to try. The service was very helpful and fast, and the atmosphere and big chairs were very comfortable. Nice place to sit with friends
author: Nevaeh R.

description: Good authentic food, super rude waitress. I think they really should get more focused on the work than chatting with each other. I left my file folder on the table while ordering take away, when I picked it up it's covered with gross spicy oil left by the previous customer :-(
author: Natalie L.

description: This is the place to be if you like spicy food that numbs your mouth. Go early to avoid lines.
author: William C.

description: I had the lamb noodle with pickle soup (hope that's what it called, couldn't remember exactly), it was very very delicious! I feel so lucky walking in this restaurant. The chili sauce on table was amazing, try that out. Btw the cook's haircut is cool!
author: Mao Y.

description: I really wanted to try this place but was not greeted or seated in the 15 minutes I waited at the front entrance.
author: Jason G.

description: I got the spicy ginger duck noodle soup.  It was very good with pieces of duck on the bone, cabbage, and noodles.  It was very spicy but not overbearing.  The chefs were very efficient in the kitchen and brought the food very quickly.  I will go back again.
author: Sean S.

description: The 小面 was surprisingly authentic. However, the peas they use for 豌杂面 was not the soft type.
author: Yuhuan J.

description: The noodles here are extremely good!! Their chili sauce is amazing!! I don't know why there are only over a hundred reviews for this restaurant, but I highly recommend it, especially for those who love spicy food.
author: Grace L.

description: I came here for a take out and I ordered sour spicy noodle (酸辣粉). I only gave one star because the food was okay but the service was really bad. The waitress was so impatient with me, and so RUDE! I was geting my card back and while looking carefully at the receipt, then this waitress was like , okay are you done? " with an attitude. Seriously, what kind of service was this? I paid and I think I have the chance to take a look at the bill right? Id never come here again and Id rather go to somewhere else that has better services.
author: Tina W.

description:
Ate here on 8/21. Had their spicy beef noodle soup. The flavor was great. The 'mian' (noodle) to meat ratio was off. They give you a lot of noodles with just a few pieces of meat. My friends and I also ordered the spicy beef tendon, which I do not regret ordering. The texture of the tendon was perfect (more on the firmer side) and the sauce paired well with it. 

I would definitely recommend getting the spicy beef tendon. I look forward to trying their tan tan noodles!
author: Forest T.

description: Three great lunches at Chong Qing Xiao Mian so far...always every table full, so try going early or late for lunch if you don't want to wait.  Food here is very spicy Szechuan style. Very tasty spicy mouth numbing Tan Tan Noodles...they taste like the ones I had in Chongqing. Loved them. BBQ Lamb skewers a favorite and the only fish dish on the menu, the fish filet with pickled mustard greens, is super flavorful. Shanghai style chicken in rice wine appetizer also very simple and flavorful and a good dish for someone who doesn't want spicy. Green onion pancake a little oily...I might not order this one again. Service is quick. No liquor license...so unfortunately no cold beer to go with your spicy food. Hopefully they will get one soon. Great value, plenty food for reasonable prices.
author: Shirley T.

description: We stumbled in to this place on Thanksgiving, after failing to find an open restaurant that would fulfill our ramen craving. Little did we know, the tan tan noodles from Chong Qing Xiao Mian were exactly what we needed! I love the numbing quality, comes from szechuan peppercorns. The broth was richly flavorful, and I'd highly recommend getting the green onion pancakes as well. They don't serve alcohol, but the hot tea was very nice on this cool evening. Will be back!
author: Meryl H.

description: Recommend this place if you like traditional Chinese spicy noodles. Their noodles are very authentic. Their small dishes are pretty good too.
author: Joey Y.

description: Okay so I found this restaurant based off of the GOOD Yelp reviews and let me tell you, it was a mistake. Walking in, we were not greeted (mind you, the place is tiny and they were not busy), we had to ask for a table. Anyway, we sit down and are going through the menu, the ramen did look pretty appetizing so I'll give them that. I was kinda upset that they didn't have a chicken ramen so I opened for their dry noodles. It took our waitress about 15-20 mins just to take our order yet she was servicing the other 2 tables. Whatever. Food finally comes and our chicken dish we ordered was cold and disgusting... I'm not sure it was even safe to eat. So I didn't. The noodles were tasty which is partially the reason for the 2 stars instead of one. My mom ordered the vegetables (it was literally just spinach) and was very tasteless. My mom asked the waitress if they had a chili sauce and she takes the same bowl of chili oil to the back, brings it back to our table and tells her it's different (it wasn't). Then, we had to ask for the check and overall just was NOT satisfied. Food was EH and the service was TRASH. Thankfully I'm not a local so I definitely won't be going back.
author: Starla M.

description: Small shop but packs big flavor. If you're into sichuan cuisine I would definitely recommend trying this place out. The Dan Dan noodles are floating in flavorful sauce and topped with pork. They also have a house special version without the pork. There is communal type seating down the middle which is great if you want to grab a bite by yourself and don't want to take up an entire table.
author: Kiran S.

description: Food is good, service is the WORST, at least for the two times I came on two Saturdays.
author: Veronica R.

description: Food was very authentic and impressed natives visiting for the weekend. :) The wait wasn't very long as table turn around and food delivery to the table time was pretty fast. Definitely recommend to anyone looking for good noodles
author: Denise S.

description: The most authentic 四川 szechuan noodle I can find in bay area. It could be very spicy for some people lol
author: Sim Y.

description: Consolation prize for not getting into quince = outstanding four-course meal at less than 10% the price. Especially loved the Guilin noodle soup, followed by spiced pork belly and cucumbers (in descending order). Spicy wonton in mala soup (i.e., not mostly dry, as we were expecting). Sweet service. Glad we stumbled upon this place.
author: anon r.

description: the yogurt they serve was expired two weeks ago, and i found out after one sip. Their solution is to cancel my drink. That's it. And the lady kept telling me that some guy had four of these, and he's fine. Fxxk U!
author: Tao T.

description: Really delicious. I had the noodle soup with Mustard Greens & Pickled Peppers (lamb version). Came quickly, and the noodles were very flavorful. I also ordered the Mouth-watering Chicken, which is usually served cold but this was warm (!?). Unusual but very good, and not too many bones.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Food was good. Prices reasonable. Service was so bad and the waitress, a young girl, so ill tempered I was even scared of her.
author: Clownaman A.

description:
I flew to SF for work and found Chong Qing Xiao Mian here on Yelp. I was meeting a friend for dinner, and he wanted some hot and sour soup. I saw that this restaurant had a hot and sour noodle soup and other noodle items so we gave it a try. I got the tan tan mian and loved it (my friend got the hot and sour noodle soup and really enjoyed it). The noodles had a perfect 'QQ' (chewy) texture but wasn't as spicy as we had anticipated.

As others have mentioned, make sure you sign in when you enter the restaurant. Service is pretty non-existent but the food was great. We both enjoyed our experience and would definitely come back again.
author: Eva B.

description: Finally a place that sells Guilin noodle soup in SF!!.. Having fell in love with this soup in Yangshuo a few years back I can confirm this soup really is Legit!!! The service was great too, the food was tasty, not too spicy at all.. it gets busy so be prepared to wait for a seat, buts it's worth the wait believe me!!
author: Marc G.

description: Finally a good place in Chinatown! Ordered tan tan noodle, spicy wonton, lamb skewers. Everything was good and tasted authentic but a bit on the oily side. Will def go back
author: Dana C.

description: Very good and friendly service. It's definitely something for people who like spicy food! I asked the waitress for something less spicy and was very satisfied, although I had to sweat a little :) The taste is unforgettable, I'm surely going to visit again!
author: Aleksandra Ć.

description: Tried this restaurant last week during lunch time. There was a long line an after 20mins finally get in by myself. Maybe it is becoz I had higher than normal expectation becoz of the long wait, the food tasted really awful. I ordered its star fish - chongqing xiao mian and green bean jelly. Both of them taste like instant noodles. The noodle they use are not instant noodles, it's the flavor which is very artificial. Maybe the other dishes are better and I just didn't hit the right one. By the way, they forgot to give me water until I asked for it and put another random guy opposite to me with whom I have to share a super small table with.
author: George T.

description: Authentic and brings me back to childhood. Just be aware that after you eat the noodles you will get serious food coma. I literally couldn't move afterwards but was worth it.
author: Blake Z.

description: I'm from Sichuan and I can tell you this place is legit. Super authentic! $9 for a big bowl of noodle. I'm going to try every single noodle on their menu!
author: Ella W.

description: There service is very fast but the food is very spicy. The numbing spice is strong and you don't taste any flavors cause of that.
author: Nadendla P.

description:
I ordered a bowl of braised intestine noodle soup, instead I got a bowl of lava that took my tongue on a one way trip to flavor town. I breathed fire as tears rolled down my cheeks. 
My stomach was full and so was my wallet. 
Despite not being able to taste anything the following day, the tastes of that sweet sweet broth from hell haunts my fantasies to this day. 
Bless this soup.
author: Andrew S.

description: 3.5 - it is a lot of MSG, although MSG is part of the ingredients for chong qing xiao mian. its very reasonably priced and thus you cant ask for too much with freshness and service..
author: Shuting Z.

description: Just kick-ass fantastic! Not too spicy that you can't taste your food. But just right amount of tingle. Definitely get the pork belly in Garlic sauce and any noddle dish, you can't go wrong! Worth the wait in line.
author: Helen Z.

description: Don't order anything labeled spicy here. Not because of the spice level but rather because of the ridiculous amount of chili oil in the broth (if you can even call it broth because all I could taste or see was chili oil). My beef & pickled mustard greens noodle soup was absolutely disgusting and even though I only ate a few bites, my stomach felt uneasy for hours. I had my husband try mine too and he agreed it was the worst Chinese food we have ever had (and we eat lots of Asian food). The staff isn't very friendly either which wouldn't have been a big deal if the food wasn't so bad.
author: Megan S.

description: If you desire amazing flavors and authentic cuisine, and care less about intimate service and surroundings, run to this place. This was our first visit, and whilst my son did not live in Chong Qing, we were both incredibly pleased with our meal. The Scallion Pancake was a great starter, and the Tan Tan Noodle soup was outstanding. The prices are quite reasonable, the service efficient in getting the food to your table; not so much in getting the check to you. It may be that we arrived not too far ahead of closing time. Great overall and I will return!!
author: Ma F.

description: I wanted to love you... but then you didn't have 担担面. Like, what? And the 麻婆豆腐 was not remotely 麻辣的. Maybe they left out the peppercorns cuz I'm not Chinese? Like, it still tasted good, still was cheap, and wasn't crowded... but whyyyyy. You were supposed to be the chosen one!
author: B H.

description: So food is not bad. Prices bit high for some things. Gets busy and food comes out slow sometimes. Good thing to note, boxes are $0.30 each on top of the $0.10 bag. People will probably just take it out of the tip, so why charge people for take-out boxes?
author: Food Is L.

description: Everything is decent (By that I mean 4 star quality) here. That's saying a lot because if you have been looking for a consistently high quality Chinese noodle house you'll know how difficult it is.  Since I found out about this place I've been back almost evey other day even though it's totally out of the way for me.  I love the cold noodle.  There's only one cold noodle on the menu.  Also recommend the Wuhan Hot Dry noodle.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Visited twice within a week from San Jose.  Good food, okay service, and not so pleasant experience at the 2nd time.  We ordered couple noodle items and 4 appetizers.  The noodles came quickly.  Waited after we finished our noodles and still no appetizers.  Finally, everything came and all tasted okay.  When the bill came, it looked a bit interesting.  Total bill was $44.60 plus $0.40 tax=$45 for the entire bill (wish I had taken a photo of this check).  I thought the total was off and odd but didn't want to argue after a good meal. Paid and left.  After came home, thought to check on the total including tax should be. It was no where near $45, the waitress had over charged us.  Even though not a lot, but sure didn't feel good.  If you ordered a lot like I did, please double check your bill.
author: C H.

description: The food is super authentic.  Yummy and numbing, but I can't overlook how dirty the restroom is. Why is it that Chinese restaurants and have clean restrooms. Would be 5 stars if this problem is addressed.
author: Ken C.

description: Amazing authentic chinese noodle dishes! Cheap, fast and quality! - if your looking for "american chinese food" this is not the place. No kung pao chicken here. And When they say the dishes are spicy, they ACTUALLY are spicy ! Which is sadly a rarity in most chinese restaurants in sf these days. Most likely due to a lack of faith in the american consumer- which admittedly can be a tad complacent at times... but this place is serving up it up real! I got the Tan Tan noodles. Delicious .
author: Pierce T.

description:
it is SOOOO good！
i dont have any expectation at first，but the noodles are so good！！！
best noodle place in bay area
although too many customers and long lines
author: Kimchi K.
